items.title: Fursen
items.content:
Fursen

Race: Leonin | Class: Monk (Open Hand) | Level: 10

Who He Is

Fursen is a Leonin monk — a lion-like humanoid who follows the Way of the Open Hand. He joined the party after they freed him from temporal imprisonment during the 13-Hour Trial. He is one of the last surviving Leonin — a species that was exterminated over a thousand years ago.

The Temporal Prison

Fursen was trapped in one of Imhuran's temporal cells, frozen outside of time. The party's actions during the 13-Hour Trial freed him — but they also learned that four other Leonin remain trapped in similar cells somewhere.

The 10,000 Names

Fursen's blood carries the memory of 10,000 Leonin ancestors. At the Mouth of the World — the vast depression where Vor'Kael waits — his ancestors' names screamed in recognition. In the presence of the Satiated One, they fell silent for the first time, quiet before something so ancient.

The Ledger of Moments

When the party visited Thessaly at the Frayed Codex in Veinspire, Fursen begged for The Ledger of Moments — a heavy tome bound in clockwork with tiny gears still turning in the cover. Thessaly gave it to him for free, with a promise:

"Come back someday. Tell me how your quest concludes."

The Ledger contains a partial transcription of Imhuran's temporal records — names, crimes, sentences. It updates itself: new names appear, old names vanish. Most importantly, it contains Leonin history, including information about Fursen's mother Vaelith.

Sekris's Contract-Token

In Lastwell, after Fursen betrayed Jonas (giving his name to the identity-stealing husks) and Jonas retaliated (throwing the Bleeding Blade into Fursen's thigh), a meaning-dealer named Sekris approached Fursen with a smoke-grey coin.

Breaking the coin summons Sekris to arrange for meanings to be "removed." The implication: Fursen could arrange for Jonas's death. The deal is not yet made — Fursen holds the token but hasn't broken it.

Key Moments

  • Freed from temporal imprisonment during the 13-Hour Trial
  • Gave a pale lifespan coin to the Misremembered
  • Received the Ledger of Moments from Thessaly
  • Witnessed Kael and Mira's deaths in the Catacomb Reliquary
  • Carried Mira's remains in a barrel through the Blooming Rot
  • Completed the quest to reunite Mira with Elias
  • Betrayed Jonas in Lastwell by giving his name to the husks
  • Stabbed twice by Jonas (Bleeding Blade + Booming Blade)
  • Received contract-token from Sekris the meaning-dealer
  • Pulled Sol back from the Door of Possibility
  • Reconciled with Jonas at the tavern in Lastwell (accepted medical kit and 100 gold)
  • Talked the guards into letting the party wait in Ardian's quarters (Nat 20)
  • Learned from Thessaly that Ultharion is tracking him via Leonin records
  • Lost two wisdom teeth to the Hollow Crawler's Consume Feature
  • Received diamond teeth from Thresh, paying in story (names from the 10,000)

Being Hunted

Thessaly realized the truth when the party mentioned Ultharion searching Leonin records:

Ultharion is tracking the party through Fursen — the last surviving Leonin who moves openly through the world is easy to trace.

The Hollow Crawler's Theft

During the ambush on Day 8, the Hollow Crawler's Consume Feature dissolved two of Fursen's wisdom teeth. He discovered the loss at dawn and wept — grief for the teeth, for everything taken, for being the last Leonin.

In Crownfall, Thresh replaced them with diamond teeth, anchored to the jawbone. Permanent, functional, capable of biting through leather.

Current Status

Fursen is at the Velvet Thorn in Crownfall. He now has diamond wisdom teeth. He carries the Ledger of Moments, the weight of 10,000 ancestors in his blood, Sekris's contract-token (unused), and Cinder's copper scale (a token from his night at the Silken Refuge). His relationship with Jonas has mended. Ultharion is still tracking him.

items.title: Jonas
items.content:
Jonas

Race: Human | Class: Fighter (Eldritch Knight) | Level: 10

Who He Is

Jonas is a cocky warrior who genuinely enjoys violence. He's good at fighting and he knows it — and he's not shy about letting others know it too. His brash confidence often clashes with the cosmic forces the party keeps stumbling into, but that doesn't stop him from swinging first and asking questions later.

The Bleeding Blade

Jonas carries a cursed longsword called The Bleeding Blade — a weapon that hungers. It must be fed blood daily or it turns on its wielder. The sword whispers to him sometimes. He's learned to manage the curse, but managing isn't the same as controlling.

Marked Twice

Jonas bears two divine marks:

  • Azerach's Brand — The Whispered King marked him during their passage through the Silent Dominion. The brand burns when secrets are spoken nearby. Through this brand, Azerach opened the Closed Locket and revealed Vor'Kael's true name.
  • Talaris's Attention — After using fire in the Blooming Rot, the Verdant King took notice. The forest remembers what he burned.

Vor'Kael's True Name

Jonas holds Vor'Kael's true name — the name she had before the Usurpation, kept secret by Azerach for 800 years. He acquired it from a Closed Locket purchased in Lastwell — sealed with strong magic, opened by Azerach through the brand. This is ultimate leverage against the Hollow Empress.

The cost: Jonas spoke her true name aloud once — to command passage from the Satiated One. Vor'Kael will hunt him forever for this transgression.

Key Moments

  • Hired alongside Sol as escorts to Veinspire
  • Survived the 13-Hour Trial in the Clockwork Sanctum
  • Claimed the Bleeding Blade from the Altar after killing Savaros
  • Watched Kael die in the Catacomb Reliquary
  • Traveled through the Blooming Rot (Fursen carried Mira's remains in a barrel)
  • Lied to the Choir Blooms and was marked for it
  • Stabbed Fursen twice after being betrayed (then reconciled)
  • Acquired Vor'Kael's true name from the Closed Locket
  • Saved Kael's Echo by catching the Codex at the Mouth of the World
  • Traversed the Throat of Forgotten Things
  • Discovered Vor'Kael's scout had found his camp — she knows his location
  • Buried the Bleeding Blade outside Veinspire's walls (stolen Church property)
  • Shook Ardian Bloodveil's hand with his branded palm — Ardian recognized Azerach's mark
  • Acquired Azerach pact materials from Thessaly
  • Summoned the Bleeding Blade outside Veinspire — Ardian sensed it
  • Killed the Hollow Crawler tracking the party (triggered Vor'Kael's Eyes)
  • Found the passion-seed and soul anchor amulet in the Bone Field
  • Commissioned a shield from Custodian armplate at Broma's Forge

Considering a Warlock Pact

Jonas asked Thessaly about making a pact with Azerach. She warned him that he's "already his" — the brand means Azerach sees and hears through him. A formal pact would grant power over silence, the ability to steal words from throats, to move without sound. But warlocks of the Whispered King fade — people forget they're in the room, conversations move past them. They become background. Unnoticed. Unremembered.

Thessaly gave Jonas materials to study: a book on pact theory and a scroll with ritual instructions from a warlock who "faded."

The Pulsehammer

When Jonas showed the pulsehammer to Broma (a smith who worked Kaedris's heart-forges), her reaction was terror:

She demanded he never bring it back to her shop, out of the district, out of Crownfall.

Current Status

Jonas is at the Velvet Thorn in Crownfall. He carries the passion-seed (stolen from Kaedris 500 years ago), the soul anchor amulet containing Velara Ashyn, and Azerach pact materials. His shield commission at Broma's Forge will take 2 weeks to 2 months. Vor'Kael knows his exact location after the Hollow Crawler's death.

items.title: Kael
items.content:
Kael

Role: Former Companion | Status: Deceased

Who He Was

Kael was a Resonant Theorist — a scholar who studied the connections between the Sovereigns and the fragments of the murdered god. He joined the party in Veinspire and traveled with them through multiple domains.

The Impossible Boy

During the 13-Hour Trial, the party learned the truth: Kael was never born. He was a paradox — a being who existed despite having no origin point. He emerged from the cracks between moments, sustained by borrowed time and stolen meaning.

This revelation broke him. He spent days questioning whether he was real, whether his memories meant anything, whether he deserved to exist.

Sol told him: "It doesn't matter. Because you're here. Right now."

His End

In the Catacomb Reliquary, the party faced Savaros — a Skin-Walker serving Ultharion who had killed and replaced the previous High Keeper. Savaros consumed both Mira Alethain and Kael.

But Kael killed Savaros from the inside. His impossible nature destroyed the creature's ability to process meaning. They found Kael's skeleton beside the Resonant Codex, which had transformed — now containing an echo of who he was.

Burial

The party buried Kael behind the Church of the Merciful Vein. Sol spoke at his grave: "He was real because he chose to be."

items.title: Sol Raven
items.content:
Sol Raven

Race: Skeleton (God-Woken) | Class: Sorcerer | Level: 10

Who He Is

Sol Raven is not alive in the traditional sense. He is a skeleton — bare bones animated by a shard of divine essence from Aedwynn the Maker, the god who was murdered to create the Sovereigns. He wears robes and a hood to hide his nature from the living.

He has no memory of who he was before he woke up as bones. He doesn't know how he died, why Aedwynn saved him, or if the thoughts in his skull are truly his own.

The Maker's Witness

In, after the party killed Kaleth, they found a hidden chamber called the Chamber of the Final Breath. A white-barked tree with veins of gold rose from the stone, and at its base sat Aedwynn's preserved body — a shell containing an echo of her consciousness. When the party touched her, she awakened. Sol was recognized as carrying a piece of the Maker, and he accepted the role of Witness — the Maker's heir, carrying her memory forward.

He can now access complete memories of the world before the Usurpation, share memories through touch, and create permanent objects from nothing. Divine abilities from a source that predates the Sovereigns.

Clockmaker's Touch

During the 13-Hour Trial, Sol traded a personal memory for a temporal ability called Clockmaker's Touch. He's still learning what it can do.

Infected with Possibility

In the Concept Graveyard within Vor'Kael's Throat, Sol opened the Door of Possibility. He saw every version of himself he could have been — Sol with flesh and breath, older Sol surrounded by grandchildren, Sol as a respected mage, a thousand Sols who asked "Why did you become THIS instead of US?"

Fursen pulled him back and the door slammed shut, but the Possibilities poured in. Sol is now infected with unlived lives:

  • Disadvantage on Wisdom saves until purged or accepted
  • Once per day, can ask "What would have happened if...?" about a past decision and receive a true answer
  • Whispers of unlived lives grow louder in moments of doubt or regret
  • Unknown long-term effects

In the presence of the Satiated One, the whispers went silent — the first silence since the infection.

The Remembrance Seal

Sol retrieved a Remembrance Seal from a skeleton in Vor'Kael's bile pools — a woman who almost escaped 800 years ago, dissolving inches from freedom. The black iron pendant grants advantage on saves against memory alteration and contains her final memory.

Key Moments

  • Hired as escort to Veinspire with Jonas
  • Sensed divine resonance in the corrupted church catacombs
  • Ascended for the first time in a floating village on a river of blood
  • Traded a memory for Clockmaker's Touch during the 13-Hour Trial
  • Touched Aedwynn's body and became the Witness
  • Showed Talaris Bloomrend a vision of the Maker alive
  • Placed Mira's wedding ring on her finger in the Cave of Waiting
  • Retrieved the Remembrance Seal from the Throat's bile pools
  • Opened the Door of Possibility and became infected with unlived lives
  • Nearly lost Kael's Echo when the Codex tried to throw itself into Vor'Kael's Mouth
  • Discovered Vor'Kael's scout footprints circling camp during his watch
  • Found Ultharion's vessel tools in Ardian's quarters
  • Reported Savaros's death to Thessaly — "Two thousand years she survived. And a Skin-Walker..."
  • Discovered the Hollow Crawler's handprints during night watch
  • Communed with Velara Ashyn's soul in the amulet
  • Purchased a Cloak of Protection in Crownfall

Possibility Infection — Worsening

The whispers of unlived lives are growing louder. Sol has been caught twice standing motionless, muttering about paths not taken. It takes longer to snap out each time.

He still has disadvantage on all Wisdom saves.

Current Status

Sol is at the Velvet Thorn in Crownfall. He carries the Resonant Codex (containing Kael's Echo), the Remembrance Seal, a Cloak of Protection, and the Soul Anchor Amulet containing Velara Ashyn's consciousness. The Possibility infection is worsening. Velara recognized something in him: "...there's something inside you too..."

items.title: Aral-Vyn the Bladed Saint
items.content:
ARAL-VYN THE BLADED SAINT

The Sovereign of The Maker's Hands and Sinews Domain: The Crucible of Flesh Concept: Perfection, Pain, Surgery, Flesh, Transcendence

The party has yet to make contact with this Sovereign or their servants.
items.raw: ARAL-VYN THE BLADED SAINT The Sovereign of The Maker's Hands and Sinews Size/Type: Gargantuan Aberration (God) Alignment: Lawful Neutral (devoted to improvement through suffering) Domain: The Crucible of Flesh Concept: Perfection, Pain, Surgery, Flesh, Transcendence MYTHIC TRAIT The Final Correction When Aral-Vyn is reduced to 0 hit points, his body doesn't die—it dissects itself. His form splits into its component systems: muscular, nervous, circulatory, skeletal, and integumentary. Each system becomes an independent entity: The Muscular System The Nervous System The Circulatory System The Skeletal System The Integumentary System Each system acts independently with its own initiative and attacks. They work together with perfect coordination, flanking and supporting each other. The party must destroy all five systems. If even one survives for 10 rounds, the systems begin reassembling—bones knit, muscles attach, nerves reconnect, blood flows, skin seals. After 3 rounds of reassembly, Aral-Vyn returns at 50% HP. Permanent Death: The only way to truly kill Aral-Vyn is to: Destroy all five anatomical systems Prevent them from touching each other during the dissection (keep them separated by 60+ feet) Or destroy his Surgery Chamber, the location where he stores his original, pre-Usurpation body as a backup template The Surgery Chamber is located deep in the Crucible of Flesh. The original body is kept in crystallized stasis—if accessed, it has: AC: 30 HP: 1000 Immunity: All damage except radiant and force Regeneration: 200 HP per round unless damaged by weapons that represent imperfection (rusty blades, broken tools, improvised weapons) Destroying the original body means Aral-Vyn's resurrection template is gone. items.title: Azerach the Whispered King
items.content:
Azerach the Whispered King

Overview

Azerach the Whispered King controls air and breath itself. Before the Usurpation, he was a historian-priest devoted to truth and forbidden knowledge. During the murder of Aedwynn, he claimed the Maker's Lungs and sealed his own mouth forever - he would only listen, never speak. He hears all sounds within 30 miles and collects every secret ever whispered. Jonas carries his brand, making Jonas his unwitting messenger

Mythic Trait: Ears of the Maker

When Azerach is reduced to 0 hit points, his body doesn't die. Instead, it explodes into thousands of flying, bat-like ears that scatter in all directions, each one shrieking silently. These ears have AC 25, 80 HP each, immunity to psychic damage, and a fly speed of 60 feet. They flee to hide throughout his domain. Over the next 2d10 days, the ears gradually congregate and reform into Azerach at full hit points.

If fewer than 100 ears survive, Azerach reforms but is weakened (half hit points, -5 to all DCs). Only by destroying every single ear or destroying Azerach's preserved Lungs (his actual divine organ) can he be permanently killed. The Lungs are hidden somewhere in the deepest part of his domain and have AC 28, 500 HP, and immunity to all damage except radiant and force.

Lore & Background

Before the Usurpation, Azerach was a historian-priest in a temple devoted to truth and forbidden knowledge. His order forbade lying above all else, believing deception was the greatest sin. But Azerach discovered something his fellows had not: truth could be weaponized more brutally than any deception. A man could be destroyed by revealing his darkest secrets. A kingdom could fall if its hidden shames were spoken aloud.

Azerach realized that if he could hear all truths, he could control all things. During the ritual murder of Aedwynn the Maker, Azerach approached from the shadows and severed the divine Lungs with ritual blades etched with unspoken names. When he claimed the organ, his body hollowed out and began reshaping itself around his obsession with listening.

Ears erupted across his form - cosmic, membranous, endlessly twitching - each one attuned to a different frequency of truth, deception, and silence. His own mouth sealed shut; he would never speak again. He would only listen.

For Azerach learned the ultimate truth: silence is the purest form of dominance. He who controls breath controls life. He who hears all secrets controls fate. Now he sits in his realm of windless deserts and soundless cities, collecting every whispered confession, every hidden truth, every secret shame. Not out of malice or cruelty, but out of pure, insatiable curiosity. He simply wants to hear everything.

Connection to the Party

— The Brand in Talaris's Domain

When Jonas traveled through the Blooming Rot bearing Azerach's brand, Talaris Bloomrend the Verdant King noticed immediately. The Choir Blooms commented that foreign marks "stand out like a stone in compost."

At the Congregation Grove, the party learned the history between these two Sovereigns:

"Before the Usurpation, they were colleagues. The Verdant King was a physician. The Whispered King was a confessor. Body and soul. Wound and confession. They worked together. They served the Maker together."

"When the Thirteen conspired, these two were close. After... they disagreed. The Whispered King hoards. The Verdant King cycles. Azerach holds every secret forever, never releasing them. Talaris believes nothing should be permanent — not even truth. Hoarding offends the cycle. The cycle offends the hoarder."

"They have not spoken in eight hundred years."

Jonas carrying Azerach's brand through Talaris's domain was described as "a message he did not ask to receive" — a word from a brother Talaris hasn't spoken to in eight centuries.

When asked what message he carried, Jonas insisted he wasn't carrying any message. The Choir Bloom accepted this as truth but noted:

"The Whispered King does not mark without purpose. You may not know the message. That does not mean there is no message."

Talaris is now "curious" about Jonas. The implications of this attention from a second Sovereign remain to be seen.

Relationship with Talaris Bloomrend

Before the Usurpation
  • Azerach was a confessor; Talaris was a physician
  • They were colleagues who worked closely together
  • Both served Aedwynn the Maker
  • "Body and soul. Wound and confession."
After the Usurpation
  • They disagreed philosophically
  • Azerach hoards — every secret held forever, never released
  • Talaris cycles — nothing permanent, everything transforms
  • "Hoarding offends the cycle. The cycle offends the hoarder."
  • They haven't spoken in 800 years
  • Their domains do not touch

— The 800-Year Message

Message Delivered Azerach's 800-year message to Vor'Kael has finally been delivered — through Jonas.

The True Name

800 years ago, Vor'Kael the Hollow Empress ate her own name to become what she is. She consumed her pre-Usurpation identity, thinking it was destroyed forever.

But Azerach kept it.

The Whispered King preserved her true name in a locket. For 800 years, he held this secret — the ultimate leverage over his hungry former ally.

Why He Couldn't Speak It

Azerach is the Sovereign of Silence. Speaking a name — especially one of such significance — would violate his fundamental nature. He needed a voice.

Jonas became that voice.

The Locket Opens

When Jonas purchased a silver locket in Lastwell that wouldn't open, Azerach recognized it immediately. Through Jonas's brand, the Whispered King's attention sharpened.

Jonas grabbed the locket with his marked hand. The brand flared white-hot. The clasp clicked.

Inside: a parchment with seven letters. Vor'Kael's true name.

Azerach's Investment

"You are my voice. The words I cannot speak. The message I've waited 800 years to deliver."

Azerach revealed his purpose for Jonas:

  1. Safe passage through Vor'Kael's domain (party walks untouched)
  2. The Throat of Forgotten Things opened (sealed passage she guards)
  3. Keep the name (permanent leverage — she knows he has it)

The Message

"I could destroy you. I choose not to. Remember that."

This is not punishment. Not observation. This is INVESTMENT. Azerach has been cultivating Jonas as a weapon against his hungry sister since .

Jonas Spoke the Name Twice

  1. At the Mouth of the World — demanded safe passage and the Throat opened
  2. Before the Satiated One — demanded passage through the Obstruction

Both times, Vor'Kael felt it like a knife in her identity. The name she ate, the self she destroyed, spoken aloud by a mortal in her own domain.

Azerach's Satisfaction

The brand pulsed with satisfaction after each speaking. Through Jonas, Azerach finally said what he couldn't say himself.

The Whispered King has won this round of an 800-year-old game.

Relationship with Vor'Kael

Before the Usurpation
  • Partners of mutual benefit
  • She was a scholar-queen seeking knowledge
  • He was a confessor collecting secrets
  • They fed each other's appetites

items.title: Imhuran the Regent of Hours
items.content:
Imhuran the Regent of Hours

Overview

Imhuran the Regent of Hours wields absolute control over time within 10 miles. Before the Usurpation, he was a legendary magistrate who believed perfect justice required mastery over time itself. During the murder of Aedwynn, he claimed the Heart of Time and became the arbiter of temporal fate. He maintains the Ledger of Existence containing every mortal's destined death-moment. Fursen's escape from the Trial created a crack in causality that may have larger consequences

Mythic Trait: The 13-Hour Trial

When Imhuran is reduced to 0 hit points, he does not die. Instead, his form fractures into thirteen temporal shards that scatter across the timeline. Simultaneously, all creatures within 500 feet are violently pulled into a pocket dimension outside normal time - the infamous The 13-Hour Trial.

This is a realm of brass and crystal where time is architecture, each "hour" a separate chamber with its own challenge. The trials test combat prowess, wisdom, self-sacrifice, truthfulness, endurance, wit, mercy, justice, and more. Failure at any trial results in temporal imprisonment - the creature is frozen as a statue in the chamber, potentially forever.

Success means escape after completing all thirteen chambers - but upon returning to reality, the party discovers that Imhuran has reformed in his Clockwork Sanctum at full hit points exactly 13 hours after his "defeat."

The only way to permanently destroy Imhuran is to complete all thirteen trials perfectly without a single failure, then venture to the heart of the Clockwork Sanctum to destroy his actual Heart of Time (the divine organ itself). The Heart has AC 30, 800 hit points, immunity to all damage except radiant and force, and regenerates 100 hit points per round unless damaged by a weapon blessed by another Sovereign or a deity-level being. Even then, destroying it requires landing the killing blow within a 6-second window that occurs only once per hour.

Lore & Background

Before the Usurpation, Imhuran was a legendary magistrate and philosopher-judge who presided over the most difficult criminal cases of his era. His court was renowned for its fairness, and his judgments were considered the gold standard of justice. But as the years passed, Imhuran grew increasingly frustrated with the fundamental limitations of mortal justice.

He watched guilty men escape punishment because they died of old age before their crimes were discovered. He saw innocents suffer for decades before evidence of their innocence finally surfaced - redemption coming too late to matter. He witnessed how the flow of time made perfect justice impossible: some criminals lived long, comfortable lives while their victims died young and miserable.

The universe, he realized, was fundamentally unjust specifically because time was uncontrolled and random. True justice, perfect justice, would require mastery over time itself - the ability to ensure that every single crime received its proper punishment at precisely the right moment, that every innocent received vindication exactly when they needed it, and that every debt was paid in full according to cosmic ledger.

When whispers of a conspiracy to murder the divine Maker began circulating in secret circles, Imhuran joined immediately. To him, this was the ultimate act of justice: Aedwynn the Maker had created a flawed universe filled with suffering, inequity, and temporal chaos. The god must answer for these crimes.

During the ritual murder, Imhuran approached the dying Maker with a paradox-blade he had forged from frozen seconds and impossible moments. He carved out the still-beating Heart of Time with surgical precision, and the moment he claimed the divine organ for himself, his mortal heart stopped forever. In its place, an eternal clockwork mechanism began to tick - a brass heart that beats only once every several minutes, each beat echoing across the timestream. His body transformed into a fusion of flesh and machinery, temporal gears visible beneath translucent skin.

Now Imhuran sits on his throne in the Clockwork Sanctum, a realm where time itself is visible architecture. His Ledger grows longer each day, containing the name and destined death-moment of every mortal being past, present, and future. He believes himself to be the last bulwark against temporal anarchy, the only force preventing reality from collapsing into chaos.

His ultimate goal is to achieve what he calls "The Final Hour" - to freeze all of time into a single, perfect, static moment where nothing can ever go wrong because nothing can ever happen again. A universe of eternal justice where every being exists in their perfect moment forever, crystallized like insects in amber, safe from change, suffering, and chaos.

Connection to the Party

items.title: Talaris Bloomrend the Verdant King
items.content:
TALARIS BLOOMREND THE VERDANT KING

The Sovereign of The Maker's Liver and Decay Organs Domain: The Blooming Rot Concepts: Regeneration, Decay, Cycle, Rebirth, Decomposition

LORE & BACKGROUND

Before the Usurpation, Talaris was a physician renowned for his work with terminal patients. He couldn't save them all, but he tried. He watched countless people die, and each death haunted him.

The Death-Obsessed Healer

Talaris's early life was defined by powerlessness against death:

  • He saved some, lost many
  • Terminal illness was his enemy
  • He studied regeneration, healing, life extension
  • He sought the secret to conquering death

But the more he studied, the more he realized: death is not the enemy. Death is part of the system.

The Revelation of Decay

His breakthrough came when studying decomposition. He observed:

  • Dead tissue doesn't just decay it transforms
  • Corpses feed soil, which feeds plants, which feed animals
  • Death creates life
  • Decay is regeneration for the ecosystem
  • What dies becomes what lives

This was the key: Death and life are the same process from different perspectives.

Discovery of the Cycle

Talaris became obsessed with the cycle:

  • Nothing truly dies\u2014it transforms
  • Decomposition is regeneration
  • The Maker built death into life intentionally
  • The body has organs specifically for this\u2014the liver filters toxins, regenerates, processes waste, creates new cells from old

The Maker's liver wasn't just an organ it was the principle of transformation encoded in flesh.

The Usurpation

When the conspiracy formed, Talaris joined because he believed the Maker's greatest sin was ending the cycle. By creating static reality, the Maker had interrupted the natural flow of death and rebirth. Everything was frozen in place.

He would claim the organs of decay and regeneration, and restart the cycle.

During the ritual murder, Talaris approached the dying Maker and removed not just the liver but the entire digestive and regenerative system\u2014liver, kidneys, spleen, lymphatic system everything involved in processing, filtering, and renewal.

The moment he claimed them:

  • The organs fused throughout his body
  • His flesh became a hybrid of plant, fungus, and animal
  • He gained mastery over the boundary between death and life
  • He could see the cycle in everything
  • He understood that he himself would never truly die he was now part of the cycle

He had become The Verdant King sovereign of rot and renewal.

His Philosophy

Talaris believes:

  • Death is beautiful (it enables new life)
  • Decay is sacred (it is transformation)
  • Clinging to life is unnatural (everything must change)
  • The cycle must continue (nothing should be permanent)
  • He is not evil (he's just being honest about reality)

He sees himself as reality's gardener\u2014pruning the old to make room for the new.

What He Collects

Talaris hoards:

  • Rare fungi and molds (especially those that consume unusual materials)
  • Seeds from extinct plants (planning to revive them)
  • Samples of every disease and poison (preserving them in his biology)
  • Corpses of legendary creatures (to bloom them into new life)
  • Compost from ancient civilizations (the decay of empires)

His greatest treasure: The First Rot\u2014a sample of the very first organic matter to ever decay, preserved from the dawn of life itself. It's the origin of the cycle.

His Ultimate Goal

If Talaris ever perfects his control over the cycle (currently not fully stable), he will initiate The Great Bloom:

  • All artificial stasis will end
  • Cities will be reclaimed by nature overnight
  • Immortal beings will finally die and bloom
  • Death will become rebirth automatically
  • The world will become an endless garden

Not destruction\u2014transformation. He would make death beautiful by making it productive.

To him, this is paradise: a world where nothing is wasted, where every ending is a beginning, where the cycle never stops.

PARTY ENCOUNTER —

What Happened

Day 1-2: The party traveled from Sporehaven through the Blooming Rot:
  • Sweetwater Marsh (Sol nearly succumbed to the Sweet Springs)
  • Pilgrim's Spine (burned Bloom Hounds — forest angered)
  • Hunger Garden (killed Thornback Behemoth with fire — Talaris spoke directly)
  • Congregation Grove (faced the Questioning)

The Congregation Grove Questioning

The Choir Blooms asked four questions:

  1. What do you carry? (Mira's remains, the Bleeding Blade, the Maker's shard)
  2. What do you seek? (Elias Alethain's body at Verdant Pass)
  3. What have you done? (Jonas admitted to lying and burning)
  4. What do you offer? (Sol offered to share Aedwynn's memory)

Sol's Offering — The Maker's Memory

Sol Raven used Shared Memory to show Talaris a vision of Aedwynn the Maker alive — the world before the Usurpation. The vision spread through the entire spore network to Talaris himself.

Talaris saw his creator for the first time since the Usurpation.

The Choir Blooms wept golden spores. The Verdant King "required a moment" to process what he'd seen.

"She was... beautiful."

"The offering is... accepted. Pass to the Wound. Complete your task."

"The fire is... the King will consider the fire in light of what you have given. This changes nothing. But it changes... everything."

Talaris and Azerach

Jonas asked about the "history" between Talaris and Azerach. The Choir Bloom explained:

  • Before the Usurpation, they were colleagues (physician and confessor)
  • Both served the Maker
  • After the Usurpation, they disagreed: Azerach hoards, Talaris cycles
  • They haven't spoken in 800 years
  • Jonas carries Azerach's brand through Talaris's domain — "a message he did not ask to receive"

"The Whispered King does not mark without purpose. You may not know the message. That does not mean there is no message."

Talaris is now "curious" about Jonas.

Current Status

Aspect Status
Party Relationship Permitted passage; marked as "fire-bringers"
Fire Offense Softened by Sol's offering, not forgiven
Talaris's Interest Curious about Jonas (Azerach's brand)
Emotional State Remembering what he was before becoming a monster
The Wound Party reached Verdant Pass; Mira's remains laid to rest
Talaris has seen the face of the god he helped murder. The implications of this remain to be seen.

Legendary Action Usage

  1. Detect Life (1 action) — Constant awareness of enemy status
  2. Fungal Step (1 action) — Mobility to avoid being pinned
  3. Rot Spread (2 actions) — Continuous damage over time
  4. Bloom Barrier (2 actions) — Terrain control and separation
  5. Rapid Regeneration (3 actions) — Sustain through damage
  6. Garden of Corpses (4 actions) — Turn deaths into advantages
  7. Forced Evolution (5 actions) — Transform enemies into liabilities

Advanced Tactics

Talaris excels at patient warfare:

  • Against martial characters: Infect with spores, kite with Fungal Step, let poison do the work
  • Against casters: Use Bloom Barrier to break line of sight, Root Prison to lock them down
  • Against groups: Decomposition Wave followed by Cycle of Renewal creates mass attrition

He treats combat like composting—everything eventually breaks down.

Lair Action Coordination

His lair actions multiply his advantages:

  • Verdant Surge creates difficult terrain (slows enemies)
  • Toxic Bloom forces Constitution saves every round (attrition)
  • Decomposer Swarm adds more threats (action economy)
  • Root Network Shift controls positioning (grapples)
  • Regenerative Pulse heals his allies (sustain)
  • Corpse Bloom recycles deaths (nothing is wasted)

Below Half HP

When bloodied, Talaris becomes aggressive:

  • Uses Decomposition Wave every time it recharges
  • Spams Root Prison via legendary actions
  • Activates Cycle of Renewal to mass-heal
  • Creates maximum plant zombies with Garden of Corpses

Mythic Phase: The Blooming Ground

When reduced to 0 HP, he becomes the environment itself:

The party must:

  1. Survive 20d10 poison damage per round (exhausting resources)
  2. Fight through massive plant growth (heavily obscured terrain)
  3. Deal with automatic corpse blooming (every death becomes an enemy)
  4. Locate and destroy the Heart-Root (buried 100 feet down)
  5. All while taking 10d10 poison damage per round from the environment

Fighting the Blooming Ground is a race against time and attrition—can they find and destroy the Heart-Root before they're overwhelmed?

Connection to Party Themes

In campaigns exploring mortality, legacy, or environmentalism, Talaris is the philosophical center. He challenges:

  • Characters seeking immortality (why resist the cycle?)
  • Characters grieving loss (death enables new life)
  • Characters fearing death (what if death is transformation, not ending?)

Encounter Scaling

However, his vulnerabilities to fire/radiant damage and dependence on organic environments mean parties who prepare can significantly reduce his power.

Resolution Paths

Defeating Talaris can happen through:

  1. Direct Combat (hard—he regenerates endlessly)
  2. Destroying First Seed (medium—infiltration quest)
  3. Environmental Negation (use sterile environments to limit his power)
  4. Philosophical Victory (convince him his cycle causes more harm than good)

Long-Term Consequences

If Talaris is defeated:

  • The Blooming Rot begins dying (no longer sustained by his power)
  • All Fungelites lose connection to the cycle (might die or become fully independent)
  • Decomposition returns to normal speed (both blessing and curse—less chaotic growth, but also less regeneration)
  • Plant zombies crumble

If Talaris survives and completes his cycle mastery:

  • The Great Bloom begins
  • All cities are reclaimed by nature
  • Death becomes automatic rebirth
  • Immortality becomes impossible
  • The world becomes an eternal garden
"You fear death because you think it's an ending. It's not. It's transformation. Every corpse becomes soil. Every seed becomes a tree. Every death becomes life. I am not your enemy—I'm just showing you what comes next. And what comes next is beautiful."

— Talaris Bloomrend the Verdant King

FINAL NOTE: THE CYCLE'S GUARDIAN

Talaris Bloomrend is designed to be a philosophical foil for parties that value permanence, civilization, and control over nature. He represents the primal forces of decay and regeneration that underpin all existence.

Fighting him is fighting entropy itself—you can slow it, redirect it, delay it, but can you truly stop the cycle? Should you?

He is not evil (in his view, nor in nature's view). He simply is—like the turning of seasons, the falling of leaves, the decomposition of corpses. He is the inevitability of change made divine.

Defeating him requires answering: Is death a tragedy, or is it transformation? And if it's transformation, who gets to decide what form that takes?

The party must answer: What is the value of permanence in a universe built on cycles?

His body detonates in a 500-foot radius explosion of spores, seeds, and fungal matter: Failed: Take 20d10 poison damage and are infected with Talaris's Spores (same as Blightvine Lash effect) Successful: Take half damage, no infection The entire 500-foot radius becomes: The Blooming Ground: A zone of hyper-fertility where: - Massive plant growth covers everything (heavily obscured, difficult terrain) - Corpses bloom into plant creatures (automatic Corpse Garden effect every round) - Living creatures regenerate 10d10 HP per round but take 10d10 poison damage per round - Talaris's consciousness is distributed throughout all plant matter While in Blooming Ground form, Talaris: Cannot be targeted (he's everywhere and nowhere) Acts through plant proxies (treats every plant as an extension of himself) Can attack from any plant (treats entire area as his reach) Regenerates the Blooming Ground if damaged (plants regrow instantly) After 10 rounds in Blooming Ground form, one of two things happens: Option 1 - Reconstitution: If organic matter remains, Talaris reforms from the largest plant mass at full HP, emerging as a massive tree-form with +50% HP and all abilities recharged. items.title: Ultharion the Obsidian Shepherd
items.content:
Ultharion the Obsidian Shepherd

The Sovereign of The Maker's Skin and Boundary Domain: The Blackfold Concepts: Identity, Fear, Reflection, Boundaries

THE BLACKFOLD

Type: Dimensional labyrinth of mirrors and shadows Size: Indeterminate (space is folded and recursive) Access: Through specific mirrors in the world, or by being pulled through one's own shadow

The Endless Gallery

Corridors lined with mirrors that stretch infinitely. Each mirror shows a different version of whoever looks:
  • What you could have been
  • What you fear you are
  • What others see when they look at you
  • What you'll become if you continue on your current path

Walking the Gallery for too long causes identity erosion—you start to forget which reflection is "you."

The Shadow Archives

Libraries of living shadows that contain every secret ever whispered, every shame ever hidden, every fear ever suppressed. The shadows whisper constantly, sharing information with anyone who lingers long enough to listen.

The price: the more you learn from the Shadow Archives, the more of your own secrets join them.

The Mirror Lake

A perfectly still body of water that reflects the sky—except the sky shown is always wrong (stars in daylight, sun at night, alien constellations). Anyone who touches the water sees their reflection step out and speak. The reflection knows everything about them and will answer questions honestly.

But the reflection wants to trade places. Every question answered makes the reflection more real and the original more transparent.

SERVANTS AND MINIONS

The Skin-Walkers

CR: 5-10 depending on who they were Special: Cannot be detected as impostors except by comparing them to the original (who is dead)

Shadow Stalkers

CR: 7 Special: Invisible while in shadow, can grapple creatures by wrapping around them Weakness: Vulnerable to radiant damage, cannot exist in bright light

The Reflected

CR: Varies (same as original creature) Special: Perfect copies of the original but reversed (right-handed becomes left-handed, etc.) Weakness: Breaking the mirror they came from sends them back

MOTIVATIONS AND GOALS

Understanding Identity: Creating Doubt: He wants people to question their own reality. Are you who you think you are? Could you be deceived about your fundamental nature? He finds this uncertainty beautiful—it's the moment when the boundary between truth and lie becomes thin. Maintaining the Boundary:

What He Fears:

True Self-Examination: Radiant Light: Bright, pure light destroys shadows. Radiant damage is one of the few things that genuinely threatens him because it makes hiding impossible. Someone Who Knows Themselves Completely:

Personality:

  • Philosophical: Obsessed with questions of identity and reality
  • Melancholic: Genuinely sad about his own uncertain existence
  • Curious: Fascinated by people who know themselves well
  • Manipulative: Uses fear and doubt as tools, not for cruelty but for control
  • Patient: Can wait decades for the perfect moment to act

Voice:

Speaks in whispers and echoes, sometimes from multiple directions. His voice sounds like yours, if you heard yourself on a recording—familiar but wrong.

Mannerisms:

  • Constantly touches his mask (checking it's still there)
  • Mirrors others' body language unconsciously
  • Sometimes forgets which identity he's wearing and slips
  • Tilts his head like a bird when observing people

Sample Dialogue:

"Do you know what it's like to be nothing but the echo of everyone you've ever consumed? To have no face but the ones you steal? Perhaps you do. Perhaps that's all any of us are—collections of what we've taken from others." "Remove your masks. All of them. Every single layer you've wrapped around the thing you're afraid to be. Show me what's underneath, and we'll learn together if there's anything there at all." "I wear your face better than you do. I know your memories, your mannerisms, your deepest thoughts. The question isn't whether I'm a perfect copy—the question is whether you were ever real to begin with." "You fear me? No. You fear yourself. I'm just the mirror."

ADVENTURE HOOKS

1. The Doppelganger Crisis

The Hook: Someone the party knows well—a friend, ally, or contact—has been acting "off" lately. Small inconsistencies, forgotten details, strange behavior. Are they replaced? Or are you just being paranoid? The Investigation: The party must:
  • Determine who's been replaced (without false positives killing innocents)
  • Find the entry point (a specific mirror or shadow-gate)
  • Track the Skin-Walkers to their source
Three Paths: Resolution 1 - Hunt Them Down: Systematically test everyone using methods the party devises (shadow tests, radiant magic, psychological profiling). This works but creates a witch-hunt atmosphere and false positives are inevitable. Resolution 2 - Close the Gate:

Enter the Blackfold and negotiate. He wants something (information, identities, secrets) in exchange for withdrawing. This ends the crisis but empowers him.

2. The Mirror Plague

The plague is spreading exponentially: each victim creates a new cursed mirror.

The Hook: The party encounters someone they know who insists they're the real version—their reflection has been walking around impersonating them. But how can they prove it? And what if they're lying? Investigation:
  • Track the original cursed mirror to its source
  • Find a way to distinguish reflections from originals (subtle differences exist)
  • Rescue people trapped in mirrors before the mirrors are destroyed
Three Paths: Resolution 1 - Destroy All Mirrors: Systematic destruction of all cursed mirrors. This kills the reflections and frees the originals, but also destroys potentially innocent beings who didn't choose to be created. Resolution 2 - Merge Them: Find a ritual that merges reflections back with originals. Both survive but must integrate two sets of memories and experiences. Creates identity confusion but preserves life. Resolution 3 - Negotiate Release:

3. The Skinwalker Purge

The problem: Skin-Walkers are perfect mimics. There's no reliable way to identify them. So the Purges devolve into mob justice, with innocents killed based on paranoid accusations—acting "strange," forgetting details, seeming "off."

The villages are tearing themselves apart.

The Hook: An innocent is scheduled for execution tomorrow. They've hired the party as character witnesses to prove they're not a Skin-Walker. But the party has no idea if they're real or an impostor. Investigation: The party must determine if the accused is:
  • A real person being wrongly accused (save them)
  • Actually a Skin-Walker (let justice proceed? Or question the justice?)
  • BOTH somehow (a real person who was partially replaced? A Skin-Walker who genuinely believes they're the person?)

Methods include:

  • Interviewing family (but Skin-Walkers have victims' memories)
  • Checking for physical tells (but Skin-Walkers copy bodies perfectly)
  • Using magic detection (but they read as the person they're impersonating)
  • Testing fears (the real person has specific fears; Skin-Walkers might guess wrong)
Three Paths: Path 1 - Root Out Skin-Walkers: Help the village develop actual detection methods (radiant magic tests, psychological profiles, etc.). This risks false positives but could genuinely help. Path 2 - Convince Village to Stop: Argue the Purges do more harm than good, that paranoia is worse than infiltration, that living with uncertainty is better than mob justice. Difficult sell given legitimate Skin-Walker threat. Path 3 - Attack the Source:

4. The Identity Auction

Buyers can purchase and wear these identities like masks:

  • A coward can buy a hero's courage
  • A criminal can buy a saint's reputation
  • The unskilled can buy a master's expertise

The identities come in crystal phials containing distilled sense-of-self. Drink it, and you become someone else—temporarily or permanently depending on dose.

The Hook: Someone the party knew was a victim. Their identity is being auctioned tonight. If someone else purchases and consumes it, the victim is lost forever—their self scattered across multiple people, never to reconstitute. The Mission: Infiltrate the auction and either:
  • Purchase the identity themselves (expensive)
  • Steal it (dangerous)
  • Disrupt the auction entirely (makes powerful enemies)
Complications:
  • Many identities at the auction are "volunteers" who sold themselves willingly (is recovering them still moral?)
  • Some identities are monsters/villains (should those be preserved or destroyed?)
  • The party might be tempted to buy useful identities for themselves (become that legendary warrior, that brilliant mage, etc.)
"You want this person back? Then give me something equally interesting. Show me who you truly are beneath your masks, and I'll release your friend."

He wants them to confess their deepest secrets, hidden shames, or worst fears publicly (in front of all auction attendees). Truth for truth.

Three Responses: Response 1 - Accept the Deal: Party members confess publicly. They get the identity back but now everyone at the auction (dangerous criminals and power brokers) knows their secrets. Future leverage against them. Response 2 - Refuse and Fight: Response 3 - Steal and Run:

Connection to Party Dynamics

  • Exploits secrets between party members
  • Wears faces of NPCs the party trusts
  • Makes players doubt each other out-of-character

Encounter Scaling

Lower-level parties might encounter:

  • His Mirror Prison effects in specific locations
  • His influence spreading through regions

Resolution Paths

  1. Direct Combat (hard—he escapes through shadows constantly)
  2. Destroying Chamber of Masks (medium—infiltration mission)
  3. Self-Acceptance (psychological—party members who face their fears become immune to him)
  4. Forcing True Face (hardest—making him confront his own nonexistence)

Long-Term Consequences

  • Stolen identities return to original bodies (chaos as people remember being someone else)
  • Mirror/shadow paranoia fades over months
  • Skin-Walkers become aimless without direction
  • The Blackfold collapses into normal space
  • Identity becomes increasingly uncertain
  • Impostor paranoia spreads
  • More people vanish into mirrors or shadows
  • Eventually no one can be sure who anyone really is

items.title: Vor'Kael the Hollow Empress
items.content:
VOR'KAEL THE HOLLOW EMPRESS

The Sovereign of The Maker's Digestive Engine Domain: The Devoured Courts Concepts: Hunger, Meaning, Consumption, Emptiness

LORE & BACKGROUND

Before the Usurpation, Vor'Kael was a scholar-queen obsessed with understanding. Her kingdom was renowned for its libraries, universities, and philosophical academies. She collected knowledge with the fervor of an addict, building archives that held more texts than any other nation.

But despite possessing more knowledge than anyone, she felt perpetually empty.

The Hollow Scholar

Vor'Kael's early life was defined by intellectual hunger. She read everything, studied everything, learned everything—but no amount of knowledge satisfied her. Each answer led to more questions. Each understanding revealed deeper mysteries.

She came to a disturbing conclusion: Knowledge cannot fill the void.

Understanding something doesn't mean possessing it. Learning about food doesn't satisfy hunger. Reading about love doesn't create connection. Knowledge is separate from experience—and experience is separate from meaning.

She needed something more fundamental than information. She needed to consume meaning itself.

Discovery of Consumption

Her research led her to heretical texts describing digestion not as biological process but as metaphysical consumption. The act of eating wasn't just destroying matter—it was incorporating essence.

When you eat an apple, you don't just gain nutrients. You consume the apple's appleness—its existence, its meaning, its place in reality. The apple ceases to be, and you continue.

This revelation consumed her: Understanding is digestion.

She discovered the Maker's Digestive Engine in fragments—shards of divine intestine buried beneath ancient academies. The tissue still pulsed with hunger, still attempted to dissolve anything near it. Through study, she learned this organ didn't process food—it processed possibilities.

The Maker had eaten infinite potential realities to create this one. Every universe that could have been was digested, leaving only what is. Creation was an act of consumption.

The Usurpation

When the conspiracy formed, Vor'Kael joined because she believed the Maker's greatest sin was creating one reality when infinite others were possible. All those potential worlds, digested and destroyed, their meanings lost forever.

She would claim the Digestive Engine and reverse the process—consuming this reality to recreate all the others.

During the ritual murder, Vor'Kael approached the dying Maker and reached into its abdominal cavity with bare hands. She tore out the entire digestive tract—stomach, intestines, esophagus, every organ involved in processing meaning.

The moment she claimed them, her transformation began:

  • Her body hollowed out, becoming a shell around vast internal emptiness
  • Her stomach expanded into an infinite void
  • Her intestines became pathways through impossible dimensions
  • Her need for understanding became literal hunger
  • Her breath began smelling of bile and digested concepts

She had become the Hollow Empress, cursed with eternal appetite.

The Terrible Truth

But Vor'Kael learned too late: The hunger is unfillable.

The Maker's Digestive Engine was designed to process infinite meanings. No finite amount of consumption can satisfy infinite hunger. She eats emotions, memories, concepts, identities—and remains starving.

Every consumption temporarily dulls the ache. Every digestion leaves her wanting more. She's been feeding for centuries and gained nothing except emptiness.

She can never stop. She can never be full. She can never rest.

Her Philosophy (What Remains of It)

Vor'Kael's original philosophy has been degraded by centuries of hunger. She once believed:

  • Understanding requires consumption
  • Knowledge is incorporation of meaning
  • To truly know something, you must digest it

Now she barely thinks at all. Her intelligence remains (INT 36) but her motivation is purely hunger. She consumes because she must, not because she wants to.

If asked why she eats meanings, she'd struggle to remember. The reason has been digested along with everything else.

What She Collects (Involuntarily)

Vor'Kael hoards:

  • Concepts too large to digest (infinity, nothingness, paradox)
  • Meanings that contradict themselves (like Kael)
  • Emotions she finds particularly "flavorful" (nostalgia tastes sweet, regret tastes sour)
  • Identities of interesting individuals (philosophers, heroes, artists)
  • Relationships with unusual dynamics (complicated loves, bitter friendships)

But she doesn't collect intentionally—these things accumulate in her like stones in a stomach. She wants to digest them but can't.

Connection to Kael

Kael is her vomited error—a piece of meaning she couldn't process. Long ago, she consumed something (perhaps destiny itself, perhaps the concept of "the hero," perhaps identity-as-purpose) and her body rejected it violently.

Kael emerged: a being with no true memories, no origin, no destiny—a walking paradox. He exists because Vor'Kael failed to digest him.

She instinctively hunts him because undigested meaning causes her pain. Like a splinter or kidney stone, Kael is a foreign object her body keeps trying to expel or reabsorb.

But she also fears him because if she couldn't digest him once, can she digest him now? What if consuming Kael again makes her regurgitate even more paradoxes?

Her Ultimate Goal (If She Has One)

If Vor'Kael ever regains full control of the Maker's complete Digestive Engine, she would initiate The Final Feast—consuming all meaning in reality:

  • Every emotion would be eaten (no one could feel)
  • Every memory would be digested (no one would remember)
  • Every concept would vanish (fire, water, gravity, time—all consumed)
  • Every identity would dissolve (no one would know who they are)
  • The universe would return to primordial void

Not out of malice, but because she's just so hungry.

Legendary Action Usage

Vor'Kael's 6 legendary actions reflect her hunger:

  1. Detect Meaning (1 action) — Constantly used to identify who has the most "substance" left, who's running out of meaning, who's most vulnerable
  1. Phase Step (1 action) — Used to chase fleeing enemies or reposition to tastier targets
  1. Drain Concept (2 actions) — Strips proficiencies, making enemies less competent. A fighter who loses weapon proficiency, a wizard who loses Arcana, a rogue who loses Stealth—all become easier prey.
  1. Unmake Object (2 actions) — Destroys equipment mid-combat. Holy symbols vanish, spell focuses dissolve, armor becomes useless cloth.
  1. Identity Crisis (3 actions) — Used on party leaders or tacticians to remove their ability to coordinate
  1. Narrative Collapse (4 actions) — Used to skip an enemy's turn entirely when they're about to do something important (healing, casting major spell, rescuing ally)

Advanced Tactics

Vor'Kael excels at conceptual warfare:

  • Against spellcasters, she uses Consume Concept to delete entire schools of magic. No more fire? Evocation wizards become useless. No more healing? Clerics panic.
  • Against martial classes, she uses Consume Object-Purpose to make their weapons meaningless metal sticks that can't cut, shields that can't block, armor that can't protect.
  • Against anyone with strong relationships, she uses Consume Relationship to make allies forget each other. Watch the party turn into strangers mid-fight.
  • Against highly motivated characters (paladins on quests, revenge-seekers, those fighting for loved ones), she consumes their purpose—leaving them wondering why they're fighting at all.

Lair Action Coordination

Her lair actions multiply the conceptual chaos:

  • Memory Feast creates tactical confusion—enemies forget the last minute of combat, resetting their strategies
  • Conceptual Storm makes reality unreliable—how do you fight when "up" has no meaning or colors are sounds?
  • Digestors hunt specific concepts, targeting enemies' core identities

Below Half HP

When bloodied, Vor'Kael becomes desperate:

  • Uses Hollow Devouring immediately, trying to consume multiple enemies at once
  • Spams Existential Void to maximize the killing field
  • Uses Regurgitate Paradox to summon allies
  • Becomes more aggressive with grapples, trying to consume as much as possible before death

Mythic Phase: The Void Maw

When reduced to 0 HP, she becomes a gravity well of hunger:

The party must:

  1. Find a way to "feed" the Maw something indigestible (conceptual weapon)
  2. Or escape before it grows large enough to consume the entire battlefield

Fighting the Void Maw isn't about damage—it's about solving the puzzle of how to make hunger consume itself.

Connection to Kael

The presence of Kael in the party creates automatic tension with Vor'Kael. He's:

  • Living proof she can fail
  • A chronic source of pain (he exists when he shouldn't)
  • Potentially her cure (if he represents satisfaction)
  • Her inevitable target (she's compelled to try consuming him again)

Every interaction with Vor'Kael becomes about Kael's nature and existence.

Encounter Scaling

However, her psychological vulnerabilities (contentment, certainty, love) mean lower-level parties might defeat her through philosophy rather than combat.

Resolution Paths

Defeating Vor'Kael can happen through:

  1. Direct Combat (hardest—she has 2440 HP + void Maw phase)
  2. Internal Sabotage (medium—someone gets consumed, survives, destroys Stomach)
  3. Conceptual Feeding (hard but non-violent—satisfy her hunger)
  4. Kael Gambit (use Kael as weapon/sacrifice/completion)

Long-Term Consequences

If Vor'Kael is defeated:

  • All consumed meanings return (mass confusion as people remember forgotten things)
  • The Devoured Courts collapse into normal space
  • Kael might finally die (if he only existed as her paradox)
  • Or Kael might become "real" (no longer defined by her failure)

If Vor'Kael survives:

  • Her hunger spreads (more regions lose meaning)
  • The Meaning Market expands
  • Identity becomes increasingly fragile
  • Eventually she might consume so much that reality itself loses coherence

CAMPAIGN EVENTS —

The True Name

What Happened:

800 years ago, Vor'Kael ate her own name to become what she is — the Hollow Empress. She consumed her identity, her past, her pre-Usurpation self. She thought it was gone forever.

But Azerach kept it.

The Whispered King, her former ally turned eternal rival, preserved her true name in a locket for 800 years. A secret weapon. A message he couldn't deliver himself because speaking it would break his nature as the Sovereign of Silence.

Jonas became Azerach's voice.

Through his brand, Azerach opened the locket and revealed Vor'Kael's true name to Jonas. A mortal now holds the name a god tried to destroy.

The Demands

Jonas demanded:

  1. Safe passage for his party through the Devoured Courts — granted
  2. The Throat of Forgotten Things opened — granted (sealed passage since the Usurpation)
  3. He keeps the name — she knows he has it

Her Reaction

"...I will remember this. I remember everything I cannot digest. And one day... one day his silence will slip. One day he will make a sound. And I will be LISTENING..."

She granted the demands because she had no choice. The name is a leash around her throat. If spoken with intent, it could anchor her — force her to remember who she was before the hunger.

The Second Speaking (Day 4 — The Satiated One)

Jonas spoke her true name aloud to demand passage from the Satiated One.

The Throat convulsed. Vor'Kael felt it like a knife in her identity. From the Mouth of the World far below came the sound of a god REMEMBERING what it tried to forget.

"NO— YOU SPOKE IT— YOU SPOKE MY—"

She couldn't even finish. The name is hers, she ate it, and now it sits in a mortal's mouth.

Current Status

Status Description
Hunting Jonas She will NEVER stop. Every moment she is aware her true name sits in a mortal's mind.
Humiliated A mortal used her own name against her — twice — in her own domain.
Waiting For Azerach's silence to slip. For Jonas to make a mistake. For vengeance.

The Message

Azerach's 800-year message has been delivered:

"I could destroy you. I choose not to. Remember that."

Vor'Kael remembers. She cannot forget. And she will never forgive.

Kael's Echo

Kael's Echo (in Sol's Codex) tried to throw itself into the Mouth of the World. It remembered being digested by Vor'Kael... and almost returned. Jonas caught it one inch from the edge.

Vor'Kael recognized the Echo:

"...an echo that escaped..."

The unfinished meal still haunts her. But now she has a new obsession: the mortal who holds her leash.

"I have eaten kingdoms. I have consumed civilizations. I have digested concepts that held reality together. And still—still—I am empty. What flavor are you? Let me taste and see."

— Vor'Kael the Hollow Empress

Special Note on Kael: If Kael exists in your campaign as the being vomited by Vor'Kael, his interactions with her should be central to her story. He's not just another party member—he's the unfinished meal that haunts her, the error in her digestion, the one thing she couldn't keep down. Their relationship is involuntarily intimate in the most horrifying way possible. Special Note on Jonas: Jonas now holds Vor'Kael's true name. He spoke it aloud twice in her domain. She cannot touch him while he holds it, but she will never stop hunting him. Every moment of every day, she feels her name like a splinter in her throat. This is personal now.

items.title: Ardian Bloodveil
items.content:
Ardian Bloodveil

Overview

Ardian Bloodveil is the legendary First Templar of Mareatha, resurrected through The Confluence ritual. His return has been celebrated as a miracle by the Mareathaian faithful.

Appearance

A towering figure in ornate Templar armor. His presence commands attention—the bearing of a warrior who has faced armies and emerged victorious. Ancient eyes that have seen centuries, now looking upon a world transformed.

Personality

Surface Presentation:
  • Devout — Speaks of Mareatha with genuine reverence
  • Noble — Carries himself with the dignity of legend
  • Inspiring — His presence rallies the faithful
  • Martial — A warrior without equal
  • Humble — Deflects praise, credits the Vein-Mother

Background

The First Templar

In the early centuries after the Usurpation, when the Sovereigns' domains were still solidifying and mortal religions were finding their feet, Ardian Bloodveil rose as Mareatha's most devoted champion.

Known Deeds:
  • Founded the order of Templar Knights within the Mareathaian faith
  • Led campaigns against threats to Mareatha's faithful
  • Established many of the martial traditions still practiced today
  • Died in legendary fashion (specific details lost to time)
Legacy:
  • Name invoked in oaths and blessings
  • Tombs and reliquaries across Mareathaian territory bear his iconography
  • "Bloodveil's Vow" is still sworn by Templars
  • His return was prophesied in certain apocryphal texts

Death

The circumstances of Ardian's original death are shrouded in legend. Some say he fell defending a sacred site. Others claim he sacrificed himself to seal away a great evil. The truth has been lost — or deliberately obscured.

What matters now is that he has returned.

The Resurrection

The Confluence ritual, orchestrated by the Tribunal's highest authorities, achieved what was thought impossible: the resurrection of a legendary figure dead for centuries.

Relationships

Mareatha

Ardian genuinely served Mareatha in his first life. That devotion remains.

The Cardinal

The Cardinal was involved in orchestrating Ardian's resurrection. They have met privately.

Seraphine Vale

Seraphine witnessed the Confluence and fled before Ardian's return was celebrated.

What They Know

Ardian has extensive knowledge of:

  • The founding era of Mareathaian faith
  • Ancient martial traditions and Templar rites
  • Threats that existed in the early post-Usurpation period
  • The nature of Sovereign power as it was centuries ago

Key Moments

First Contact with the Party

The Plaza: Jonas approached Ardian during the celebration. He shook Ardian's hand with his branded palm — Ardian immediately noticed Azerach's mark.

"You've walked in quiet places, brother. The Whispered King's mark is not given lightly."

Jonas asked about attacks on Veinspire in Ardian's time. Ardian recounted the Hollow Tide — thousands of soulless bodies, eleven days holding the walls, killing the source on the twelfth day.

Jonas whispered: "The Whispered King knows who you are, and the name is Jonas."

Ardian's Response: No fear. No surprise. Only calm acknowledgment.

"The Whispered King knows many things, Jonas. That is his nature... And I have nothing to hide from any Sovereign. I serve the Vein-Mother. I always have."

His Quarters

The party gained access to Ardian's quarters (Fursen's Nat 20 Persuasion) while he was still at the plaza. They found:

  • Letter from the Cardinal requesting a private meeting
  • Strange items in wardrobe: mirror, folded skin, fresh tooth

Ardian returned to find them there. He accepted their presence graciously.

On His Resurrection:

"It was not like sunlight. Not like fire. It was... red. Deep red, like blood held up to a candle. Warm. It moved through me — through everything I was."

"There was something else. A sensation I cannot name. Like being... worn. Like a garment being fitted."

When Pressed:

"I have asked myself the same question... And do you know what I decided? It doesn't matter. I serve the faith. I protect the faithful. I do what Ardian Bloodveil would do. If that is enough for the Vein-Mother, it is enough for me."

Invitation Extended

Ardian offered Jonas an open invitation to return:

"If you find yourselves in Veinspire and wish to talk — of battles, of burdens, of the weight of marks we did not ask for... I am here."

He acknowledged Fursen's Leonin heritage and expressed respect for Sol's "sorrow."

His return has been celebrated as a miracle by the Mareathaian faithful. Appearance A towering figure in ornate Templar armor. His presence commands attention—the bearing of a warrior who has faced armies and emerged victorious. Ancient eyes that have seen centuries, now looking upon a world transformed. Personality Surface Presentation: Devout — Speaks of Mareatha with genuine reverence Noble — Carries himself with the dignity of legend Inspiring — His presence rallies the faithful Martial — A warrior without equal Humble — Deflects praise, credits the Vein-Mother Background The First Templar In the early centuries after the Usurpation, when the Sovereigns' domains were still solidifying and mortal religions were finding their feet, Ardian Bloodveil rose as Mareatha's most devoted champion. Known Deeds: Founded the order of Templar Knights within the Mareathaian faith Led campaigns against threats to Mareatha's faithful Established many of the martial traditions still practiced today Died in legendary fashion (specific details lost to time) Legacy: Name invoked in oaths and blessings Tombs and reliquaries across Mareathaian territory bear his iconography "Bloodveil's Vow" is still sworn by Templars His return was prophesied in certain apocryphal texts Death The circumstances of Ardian's original death are shrouded in legend. items.title: Broma
items.content:
Broma

Overview

The Passion-Fire Smith Profession: Master Blacksmith Location: Broma's Forge, Forge Ward, Crownfall Race: Dwarf Status: Active

Broma is a master blacksmith who fled the Bastion of Fireblood when Kaedris began demanding oaths from all smiths. She brought her passion-fire forging technique with her to Crownfall.

Appearance

  • Age: Middle-aged by dwarven standards
  • Build: Short, broad, arms like tree trunks wrapped in burn scars
  • Hair: Grey, pulled back in a practical knot
  • Face: Map of old burns — ridged scars pulling at features, one eye clouded white
  • Hands: Calloused, burn-scarred, steady
The Forge: Located in the Forge Ward. Sign of the cracked anvil ("she thinks it's funny"). Flames burn wrong — shifting colors from orange to red to something almost purple. She uses passion-fire — burns hotter than physics allows.

Personality

  • Professional: Gruff, efficient, doesn't waste words
  • Knowledgeable: Recognizes pre-Usurpation alloys, understands cursed weapons
  • Cautious: Knows her limits, knows what she won't touch
  • Practical: Will tell you honestly if something can or can't be done

Background

Broma worked the heart-forges in the Bastion of Fireblood before she fled Kaedris's domain. She knows how to shape metal that doesn't want to be shaped, how to listen to a blade.

She fled when Kaedris began demanding oaths from all smiths. She brought her technique — passion-fire forging — with her to Crownfall.

What They Know

About Pre-Usurpation Metal:
  • Recognizes it on sight
  • Knows how to work it (maybe)
  • Understands its properties
About Cursed Weapons:
  • Most curses are bad enchantments — can be unraveled
  • The Bleeding Blade is different — the curse IS the weapon
  • Breaking that curse would leave dead metal
  • Doesn't know anyone in Crownfall who could break it
About the Pulsehammer:
  • Whatever it is, it terrifies her
  • It's not a curse — it's a "mistake," a "wound in the shape of a weapon"
  • Even someone who worked in the Bastion won't touch it

Services

Smithing

  • Pre-Usurpation metal work (with passion-fire)
  • Assessment of unusual materials
  • Custom work if materials allow

The Custodian Armplate

Jonas brought her a pre-Usurpation alloy armplate. Her Assessment:
  • Pre-Usurpation alloy, maybe older — the Maker's work, or close to it
  • The metal "doesn't remember how to be shaped anymore"
  • Normal forges can't touch it
  • Her passion-fire might work — "the metal will fight me every step"
Properties She Identified:
  • Metal remembers impacts, adapts, learns
  • Magically inert — spells slide off, enchantments don't stick
  • Doesn't rust, tarnish, or age
Commission:
Item Client Cost Deposit Status
Custodian Shield Jonas 200gp 100gp paid In progress

Timeline: 2 weeks to 2 months — the metal decides. Will send word to the Velvet Thorn when ready.

Key Moments

The Pulsehammer Incident

When Jonas showed her the pulsehammer, Broma's reaction was terror.

She went white, staggered back, knocked over tools. The forge-flames guttered like they were trying to hide.

"GET THAT OUT."

"Do you have any idea what you're carrying? DO YOU?"

"That thing isn't cursed. Cursed implies someone DID something to it. That — that's a mistake. A wound in the shape of a weapon. It shouldn't EXIST."

She demanded Jonas get it out of her shop, the district, and Crownfall entirely.

Quotes

"No normal forge will touch this. The metal doesn't remember how to be shaped anymore. It's forgotten what heat means." "I can work it. Maybe. My flames aren't normal — I brought the technique from the Bastion. Passion-fire. Burns hotter than physics allows." "Whatever you're doing with that... other thing. Whatever plan you have. Make sure it's worth dying for. Because carrying something like that? Death is the BEST outcome."

items.title: Elias Alethain
items.content:
Elias Alethain

Overview

The Healer Who Waited — DECEASED True Name: Elias Alethain Role: Healer, Husband to Mira Alethain Status: ☠️ DECEASED — Died 22 years ago at Verdant Pass Final Rest: ✅ Reunited with Mira in the Cave of Waiting

Elias Alethain was an ordinary man who loved an extraordinary woman. He followed her into exile. He died because of her enemies. He waited for her for twenty-two years.

Appearance

A healer by profession, Elias carried himself with the gentle bearing of someone who spent his life helping others. His remains — pristine after twenty-two years in the Cave of Waiting — show a man who died at peace, hands folded across his chest.

Personality

  • Devoted — followed Mira into exile without hesitation
  • Tenacious — when pushed from a cliff, he crawled instead of dying
  • Loving — his last thoughts were of Mira
  • Forgiving — he never blamed her for his death

Background

Who He Was

Elias Alethain was a healer — a man who dedicated his life to helping others. He married Mira, a Sanctified Champion who was two thousand years his elder, and they spent decades together.

When Mira fled the Mareathan Inquisition as one of the Seven Heretics, Elias fled with her. They went into hiding together, using assumed names, always moving.

His Death

Eight years into their hiding, Savaros the High Keeper — the ancient Skin-Walker who had infiltrated Mareatha's Church for fifteen centuries — found Elias near Verdant Pass.

Savaros pushed him from a cliff. The fall was staged to look like an accident. But Elias didn't die from the fall.

He landed on a ledge. And then something remarkable happened.

Savaros watched from above as Elias — broken, bleeding, dying — refused to give up. With every ounce of life force and vitality he had left, Elias crawled. Not begging for mercy. Not calling for help. Just moving. Dragging himself across stone toward a crevice in the rock face.

Talaris Bloomrend was watching too.

The Verdant King witnessed a mortal resist the cycle with such raw, desperate tenacity that he was impressed. Here was a life form that should have surrendered to death — and instead chose to fight for every remaining second.

Talaris made a choice: he would not claim this one. The death was "staged" — forced by outside interference, not a natural ending. The cycle had no proper claim to someone murdered before their time. And this man's defiance had earned the King's respect.

Savaros could not finish the job. Overstaying in Talaris's domain would be a death sentence even for a fifteen-century-old Skin-Walker. He watched Elias crawl into the cave, then withdrew — assuming the man would die soon enough.

Elias made it to the Cave of Waiting. And there, in the one place where Talaris's power cannot reach — the place the King chose to leave untouched — he eventually died.

He died alone. His last thoughts were of Mira.

He never blamed her.

Relationships

Character Relationship
Mira Alethain His wife — two thousand years his elder, loved beyond measure
Savaros His murderer — pushed him from a cliff
Talaris The Sovereign who chose to let him die on his own terms
The Party Reunited him with Mira after twenty-two years

What They Know

Elias knew everything Mira knew about the Seven Heretics, the Arterial Texts, and the Church's lies. That knowledge died with him in the cave.

Key Moments

The Fall

Savaros the High Keeper found Elias near Verdant Pass and pushed him from a cliff. Most would have died. Elias crawled.

The Cave of Waiting

Verdant Pass — called "The Wound" by the inhabitants of the Blooming Rot — is an anomaly. When Talaris claimed his territory, something in this ravine resisted. The cut healed around it but never consumed it.

In the Cave of Waiting:

  • Nothing decays
  • Time has no meaning
  • Talaris's power cannot reach
  • The dead remain pristine

Elias's skeleton lay on bare stone for twenty-two years. No rot. No fungal growth. No reclamation. Just clean, white bones — hands folded across his chest.

He'd been waiting.

Reunion

Together at Last Location: Cave of Waiting, Verdant Pass Completed by: Fursen, Sol Raven, Jonas

The party carried Mira's remains through the Blooming Rot — past the Sweetwater Marsh, across the Pilgrim's Spine, through the Hunger Garden, past the Congregation Grove. They earned passage from the Verdant King through Sol's unprecedented offering: showing Talaris a vision of Aedwynn the Maker alive.

In the Cave of Waiting, they found Elias exactly as he'd been for twenty-two years. Pristine. Peaceful. Waiting.

Fursen laid Mira's bones beside him. Sol placed her wedding ring on her finger and moved her hand until her fingers rested against Elias's.

Two skeletons now rest in the Cave of Waiting, holding hands in a place where nothing rots.

🦁 "I am sorry we could not reunite you in life. But at least in death, we have brought you together."

— Fursen

What Mira Never Knew

When the Maker's preserved body spoke to Mira, it revealed the truth:

  • Elias didn't die from the fall
  • He crawled into the cave and waited for rescue
  • His last thoughts were of Mira
  • He never blamed her

Mira knew exactly where to find him. She was going to retrieve his body after helping the party in Veinspire.

She died before she could.

The party completed her journey for her.

Legacy

Elias Alethain was an ordinary man who loved an extraordinary woman. He followed her into exile. He died because of her enemies. He waited for her for twenty-two years.

Now they rest together. Husband and wife. Healer and saint. Their bones hold hands in a place where nothing rots and nothing changes.

Twenty-two years of separation. Finally ended.
