items.title: Church of the Merciful Vein
items.content:
Church of the Merciful Vein

Overview

Lesser District Sanctuary Type: Mareathan Church (neighborhood level) Location: Outer district of Veinspire, away from the central cathedral Function: Local worship, community healing, Inquisition support Current Occupant: High Inquisitor Seraphine Vale (positioned to intercept the heretics)

Description

A modest cathedral by Veinspire standards — which still makes it grander than most buildings in the realm. The Church of the Merciful Vein serves the faithful of one of Veinspire's lesser districts, far from the central cathedral but no less devoted to the Vein-Mother's cause.

The Sanctuary

The main chamber is a long nave with high vaulted ceilings supported by ornate columns. Stained glass windows line both walls, depicting scenes of Mareatha's mercy — healing the sick, purifying the corrupted, granting peaceful death to the suffering. Light streams through in golden shafts, illuminating dust motes like drifting prayers.

Key Features:
  • Central Aisle: Dark carpet runner between rows of wooden pews, leading to the altar
  • The Pews: Rows of seating for perhaps two hundred faithful, worn smooth by generations of use
  • The Columns: Carved stone pillars supporting the ceiling, decorated with arterial motifs
  • The Altar: Raised hexagonal platform with a statue of Mareatha in her "Merciful Aspect" — an angelic figure with outstretched wings, hands open in blessing
  • The Blood Pools: Shallow basins set into the checkered floor at key points — filled with sanctified blood for rituals and blessings (these are functional, not decorative)
  • Brass Chandeliers: Ornate lighting fixtures with dozens of candles, casting warm light across the stone

The Statue

The central statue depicts Mareatha as a healer — wings spread protectively, face serene, hands offering benediction. This is the aspect shown to common worshippers, though they understand it represents only one face of their goddess. The faithful here know the Inquisition's work is necessary — mercy and judgment are two hands of the same body.

Mira remembers when this statue was carved. She remembers the sculptor's name.

The Blood

The pools of blood on the floor are a standard feature of Mareathan churches. They serve multiple purposes:

  • Blessing: The faithful dip fingers in sanctified blood before prayer
  • Healing: Minor wounds can be treated by immersion
  • Detection: The blood responds to heresy, supposedly rippling in the presence of the unfaithful
  • Communion: During high holy days, the blood is consumed

The blood is replenished weekly through "donations" from the faithful. Participation is voluntary. Officially.

Atmosphere

Sensory Details Sight: Golden light through stained glass. Dust motes drifting like lazy spirits. The dark gleam of blood pools catching candlelight. Shadows pooling between the columns. Sound: Echoing footsteps on checkered stone. The creak of old pews. Distant hymns from deeper chambers. The soft drip of blood into basins. Smell: Incense — thick and cloying. Old wood and older stone. The copper tang of blood beneath everything. Feel: Cool air despite the candlelight. The weight of centuries. The sense of being watched by something that bleeds.

The Church's Faith

Righteous Servants

The Church of the Merciful Vein — like all Mareathan churches — fully supports the Inquisition's holy work. The local priests and faithful:

  • Know heretics are hunted, interrogated, and executed
  • Believe this is righteous and necessary work
  • Support the Inquisition completely and without reservation
  • Understand that heresy is a disease that must be cut out
  • Accept that the party are genuine heretics who deserve judgment

They are not naive about what the Inquisition does. They simply believe it is holy and necessary. When Seraphine orders guards to capture fleeing heretics, the priests nod in approval. When interrogations happen in cathedral basements, the faithful pray for the heretics' souls.

This is what makes the Mareathan Church so effective — it's not built on hidden cruelty, but on cruelty that the faithful genuinely believe is mercy.

— Kael's Burial

Behind the Church After Kael's death in the Catacomb Reliquary, the party buried him behind this church — in Seraphine's territory, with her implicit permission after her faith was shattered. Buried: Kael (Resonant Theorist, ontological anomaly) Grave: Unmarked, behind the church Eulogy: Sol Raven spoke: "He was real because he chose to be."

The boy who wondered if he was real now rests behind a church dedicated to a goddess whose doctrine is built on lies. There's poetry in that, somewhere.

items.title: Dusthollow
items.content:
Dusthollow

Type: Settlement | Status: Neutral Territory

Overview

A small waystation located half a day west of the Pallid Crossroads. Contains the Dry Cup tavern, stables, and a handful of residences. Perhaps a dozen permanent residents. Neutral ground used as a staging point for travelers.

The Vorath Encounter

The party learned that Vorath — a Tribunal agent hunting Mira — was camped at Dusthollow. They investigated his room at the Dry Cup and found:

  • Evidence connecting him to the Tribunal and Seraphine Vale
  • A sealed letter from "K" (Kaleth Vorn) with orders to capture Mira alive
  • Instructions to interrogate her about the Arterial Texts

The Kill

The party rode back through the night to catch Vorath before he could flee. They arrived before dawn to find him at the stables, preparing to escape on horseback.

Jonas threw his hammer (missed, hit the horse instead). Vorath was thrown from the saddle and surrendered, offering information for his life.

Mira bashed his head in with her fist. No hesitation.

Intelligence from Speak with Dead

The party interrogated Vorath's corpse:

  • "Who is K?" — "Kaleth Vorn. Tribunal Hand. Veinspire Catacomb. Seraphine's superior — gives her orders."
  • "The Arterial Texts?" — "The Vein-Mother's mortal writings. Her doubts. Her failures. Words before divinity. The Tribunal must destroy them. Alethain knows where they are hidden."
  • "State of Veinspire?" — "Theorists scattered. Three cells discovered. Executions public. The Church fears what stirs beneath. The Mother's heart beats... irregular."

Significance

This was the moment Mira permanently left her old life behind. After killing Vorath, she could never return to the Pallid Crossroads without endangering the settlement. From here, there was only forward — toward Veinspire, toward vengeance, toward death.

items.title: Lastwell
items.content:
Lastwell

Overview

Lastwell is the final settlement before the Devoured Courts where meaning begins to fade. The last place travelers stop before entering Vor'Kael's domain. Here, at the threshold, meaning itself begins to thin - colors are muted, words come harder, purpose feels distant. The town exists because someone has to warn travelers before the grey takes over

Overview

Lastwell is the final settlement before the Devoured Courts. Here, at the threshold of Vor'Kael's domain, meaning itself begins to thin. Colors are muted. Words come harder. Purpose feels distant.

The town exists because someone has to warn travelers. Someone has to be the last voice that speaks clearly before the grey takes over.

Atmosphere

  • Colors: Muted, washed out, trending toward grey
  • Sound: Conversations feel like they take effort
  • Air: Smells faintly of nothing — absence of scent
  • Feeling: A gnawing emptiness in the chest

The closer you get to the Devoured Courts, the harder it becomes to remember why anything matters.

Key Locations

The Husk Pen

A pen containing husks — people who have lost their meanings. They exist, but they are nothing. They had names once, purposes, identities. Vor'Kael's border effect stripped them away.

What Husks Are:
  • Former people who ventured too close to the Devoured Courts
  • They exist but don't know why
  • They reach for meanings that aren't theirs
  • They can taste identity when it's offered
The Throat of Forgotten Things:
  • Fursen whispered "Sir Jonas" to the husks
  • The husks tried to claim Jonas's name, pulling at his identity
  • Jonas threw the Bleeding Blade at Fursen, wounding his thigh
  • Leonin blood (carrying 10,000 ancestors) spilled
  • Vor'Kael was alerted to something interesting at her border

The Last Hearth Tavern

The only establishment still functioning in Lastwell. Run by Marra, a woman who wants nothing more than for dangerous people to leave.

What's There:
  • Tasteless food (meaning fading from the ingredients)
  • Watered-down ale
  • A fire that doesn't feel warm
  • Locals who've learned not to care about anything
The Throat of Forgotten Things:
  • Jonas struck Fursen with Booming Blade after catching him stealing
  • Fursen met Sekris, a meaning-dealer
  • Fursen took Sekris's contract-token
  • Jonas purchased the Closed Locket from the smith

The Smith

A craftsman who works in metal but whose creations often lose their function. He sold Jonas the Closed Locket — a silver container that wouldn't open, containing whispers.

The locket held Vor'Kael's true name, preserved by Azerach for 800 years.

The Greeter

A man who has lost his own name. He only remembers his function — to warn travelers.

His Warnings:
  1. Don't speak your name beyond this town
  2. Don't accept food from strangers
  3. Don't answer Questioners
  4. If something asks who you are, don't tell it
  5. If you start forgetting why you're traveling, turn back

He can't remember his own advice sometimes. He just knows it's important.

NPCs

NPC Role Status
The Greeter Warns travelers Fading — lost his name
Marra Tavern keeper Wants outsiders gone
Sekris Meaning-dealer Active — gave Fursen a contract-token
The Smith Craftsman Sold Jonas the Closed Locket

Dangers

Danger Description
Meaning Drain Extended time in Lastwell causes memories/emotions to fade
Husks Will try to claim your identity if you offer it
Questioners Vor'Kael's faceless scouts; answering them gives her information
Sekris Predatory meaning-dealer; trades in desperation

events

The party stopped in Lastwell before entering the Devoured Courts.

Key Events:
  1. The Greeter warned them about the dangers ahead
  2. Fursen betrayed Jonas at the husk pen (gave his name to the husks)
  3. Jonas stabbed Fursen twice (Bleeding Blade throw, Booming Blade strike)
  4. Fursen met Sekris and took his contract-token
  5. Jonas bought the Closed Locket (containing Vor'Kael's true name)
  6. Party dynamics fractured

Why "Lastwell"

The town is named for being:

  • The last well of clean water before the Devoured Courts
  • The last place where words flow easily
  • The last settlement where people still remember why they settled
  • The last chance to turn back

Beyond Lastwell, there is only grey.

items.title: Lesser Sacral District
items.content:
Lesser Sacral District

Overview

The Quiet Faith Type: District of Veinspire Character: Smaller churches, lower security, diluted divine presence Notable Locations: Church of the Merciful Vein, The Frayed Codex, The Whetstone and Anvil First Explored:

Description

The Lesser Sacral District isn't the heart of Veinspire — that's the Grand Cathedral. But things happen here. Quiet things. The kind the Church doesn't put in sermons.

The walls breathe like everywhere in Veinspire. The distant heartbeat pulses. But the divine presence is diluted — background noise rather than the overwhelming pressure near the Cathedral.

Shutters are often closed. The faithful stay indoors when the Inquisition hunts. Even those with nothing to hide know that innocence is no protection.

Points of Interest

The Church of the Merciful Vein

  • Small congregation, mostly district residents
  • Seraphine Vale's current station
  • Catacombs beneath connect to older tunnel networks
  • Tribunal uses tunnels for moving prisoners "and other things"
Status: Party confronted Seraphine here.

The Frayed Codex

  • Bookshop two streets south of the church
  • Run by Thessaly (ancient, knowledgeable)
  • Public: Hymnals and devotional texts
  • Actual: Restricted texts, pre-Usurpation fragments, forbidden knowledge
  • "If you need information that isn't in any official archive... she might have it. Might not. Depends if she likes your face."
Status: Party purchased The Doctrine of Still Air (75 gp). Fursen received The Ledger of Moments (free with promise).

The Whetstone and Anvil

  • Smithy on corner where two narrow streets meet
  • Run by Garrett (mid-fifties, burn scars, doesn't talk to Church)
  • Equipment repair and sales
  • Pre-Sovereign gear available (expensive)
  • Information source about district and legends
Status: Party had Custodian armplate assessed. Jonas did not purchase items.

The Copper Vein

  • Tavern on district's edge
  • Neutral ground — Inquisitors drink there, so do smugglers
  • Barkeep: Hollow Cren — hears everything, shares for coin or favor
  • "You want rumors about what's happening in the Church? That's where they flow."
Status: Not yet visited.

The Memorial Ossuary

  • Public bone-house three blocks north
  • Where the district buries its dead (after Church takes their tithe)
  • Open to visitors during daylight
  • Also where certain people meet when they don't want to be overheard
  • "Hard to spy on a conversation when you're surrounded by ten thousand skulls."
Status: Not yet visited.

The Catacomb Gate

  • West side of district
  • Main Tribunal checkpoint
  • Heavy guard
  • Where prisoners go to the deep cells
  • Kaleth Vorn operated near here ("Catacomb Reliquary")
Status: Handler from this area was eliminated by party.

Sister Mavel's Hospice

  • East end of district
  • Run by excommunicated healer
  • "Disagreed with how the Inquisition treated the sick"
  • Church pretends not to notice because she takes cases they don't want
  • Healing without Church attention
Status: Not yet visited.

Current Situation

Immediate Concerns

  • Handler's absence will eventually be noticed
  • Seraphine's cover is fragile
  • The Confluence approaches (days away)
  • Savaros and the Catacomb Reliquary are nearby

items.title: Monastery of Still Blood
items.content:
The Monastery of Still Blood

Overview

Sacred Gathering Place of the Mareathan Church Type: Religious monastery / Clergy gathering site Location: Beneath Mareatha's Heart, outside Veinspire Affiliation: Church of the Merciful Vein Purpose: Major clergy gatherings, including the Confluence

Why "Still Blood"

At the base of Mareatha's Heart — the mountain-sized divine organ that pumps through Veinspire — blood pools and settles. Unlike the rushing arterial tunnels above, the blood here is slow. Thick. Nearly motionless.

The faithful call this sacred: "Where the Vein-Mother's blood rests, so too may her servants find stillness."

The truth is less poetic. Blood that doesn't flow is blood that doesn't carry Mareatha's attention. Her consciousness rides the pulse, the rush, the living current. Here, in the still places, she is... distant. Unfocused. The clergy interpret this as peaceful sanctuary.

The Cardinal knows it for what it is: a blind spot.

Description

First Impression The monastery grows from the flesh like a tumor given purpose. Walls of calcified blood-rock rise in arches and cloisters, threaded with darkened veins that no longer pulse. Above, the Heart looms — vast beyond comprehension, its rhythm felt in the bones rather than heard. But here, at its base, the eternal drumbeat grows muffled. Quiet. The air smells of old iron and incense. The blood in the channels does not flow. It sits, dark and mirror-still, reflecting torchlight like black glass.

Layout

The Pilgrim's Descent

The only surface approach — a road of calcified blood that winds down from Veinspire over three days of walking. Pilgrims travel in silence, shedding worldly concerns with each step. By the time they arrive, they are meant to be spiritually prepared for the stillness.

Features:
  • Wayshrine stations every few hours
  • No inns or shelter — pilgrims sleep on the road
  • Final descent through a narrow canyon of dried blood-rock
  • The Heart becomes visible on day two, growing impossibly large

The Threshold Gate

The monastery's entrance — a massive valve of hardite (calcified divine tissue) carved with scenes of Mareatha's mercy. It opens only for those bearing the Church's seal or during scheduled gatherings.

Features:
  • Two Custodian guardians (constructs) flank the entrance
  • Detection wards identify divine alignments
  • Opens inward with a sound like a held breath releasing

The Veinal Cloisters

Living quarters for resident monks and visiting clergy. Simple cells carved into the blood-rock, connected by walkways threaded with dormant veins.

Features:
  • 200 individual cells
  • Communal dining hall (blood-broth and bread)
  • The veins in the walls occasionally twitch — Mareatha dreaming
  • Whispered prayers echo strangely

The Pulse Chambers

Meditation cells built where the Heart's rhythm is still faintly felt. Used for spiritual trials, deep prayer, and — during the Confluence — private confessions.

Features:
  • Soundproofed by layers of tissue
  • The heartbeat here is hypnotic; extended exposure induces trance states
  • Confessions heard here feel compelled — the rhythm loosens tongues
  • The Cardinal listens to every confession through shadow-channels

The Sanctuary of the Settling

The main worship hall. A vast chamber where the blood pools inches deep across the floor, perfectly still. Clergy walk through it barefoot, their passage leaving no ripples.

Features:
  • Blood is real but preserved — neither living nor rotting
  • Walking through it is meant to symbolize immersion in Mareatha's grace
  • The altar rises from the pool's center
  • During major ceremonies, the blood glows faintly crimson

The Lowest Sanctum

The deepest chamber, directly beneath the Heart's foundation. Where the Confluence gathers.

Features:
  • Accessible only to Cardinals and above
  • A perfect circle of still blood surrounds a raised stone platform
  • The ceiling is the underside of the Heart itself — raw divine tissue
  • Acoustics carry whispers perfectly; secrets spoken here do not stay secret
  • The Cardinal's preferred hunting ground

The Confluence

A legitimate gathering of the Church's highest leadership, held every few years at the Monastery of Still Blood. Officially, it serves to:

  • Align Church doctrine across regions
  • Hear reports from Cardinals and Bishops
  • Conduct high-level confessions and absolutions
  • Make major ecclesiastical decisions

Attendees

Rank Number Role
The Pontiff 1 Supreme leader of the Mareathan Church
Archbishops 3-5 Regional heads
Bishops 20-30 Diocesan leaders
Tribunal Representatives 4-6 Including Seraphine Vale (usually)
Attending Clergy 50-100 Scribes, aides, confessors

Schedule (Typical)

Day Events
Day 1 Arrival, purification rituals, opening prayers
Day 2 Regional reports, doctrinal discussions
Day 3 Private confessions in the Pulse Chambers
Day 4 Tribunal matters, heretic condemnations
Day 5 The Pontiff's address, major decisions
Day 6 Closing ceremonies, departures begin

What the Cardinal Does

Day 1-2: Identifies targets. Who has secrets? Who is vulnerable? Who would make a valuable identity to steal? Day 5: Reports to the Pontiff with perfect loyalty — while cataloging everything for his true master. Day 6: Selects one or two targets for future consumption. Not now — too obvious. But in six months, a Bishop will disappear, and the Cardinal will have a new skin to wear.

Atmosphere

Sounds

  • The muffled heartbeat — felt more than heard
  • Whispered prayers echoing off blood-rock
  • Footsteps through still blood — no splashing, just soft displacement
  • Occasional twitch of dormant veins — a wet, muscular sound

Smells

  • Old iron (the blood)
  • Incense (constant)
  • Cold stone and older decay
  • Something faintly sweet beneath it all — preserved flesh

Sights

  • Crimson and black everywhere — blood-rock, dried veins, dark robes
  • Torchlight reflecting off perfectly still blood pools
  • The Heart above — impossibly vast, its surface textured like muscle
  • Clergy moving in silence, barefoot, blood-stained to the ankles

The Wrongness

  • Too quiet. Mareatha's domain should pulse with life. This place... waits.
  • The blood doesn't behave like liquid. It parts for the faithful. It clings to intruders.
  • Sometimes, in the corner of your eye, the still blood ripples — but when you look, it's perfectly flat.

Potential Infiltration Approaches

Approach Difficulty Notes
Pilgrim's Descent Medium Three days exposed; requires disguise; checkpoints
Arterial Tunnels Hard The party knows these; connects to monastery's lower levels; risk of guardians
Pose as Clergy Hard Requires stolen robes, forged seals, knowledge of rituals; one wrong word exposes them
During Confluence Very Hard Maximum security, but also maximum chaos and crowds
Through the Heart Itself Extreme Literally entering Mareatha's divine organ from above; possible but insane

Key NPCs (During Confluence)

The Pontiff — Venerus the Still

The supreme leader of the Mareathan Church. Ancient, frail in appearance, but spiritually formidable.

  • Level: 18 Cleric (Life Domain, reflavored as Blood)
  • Demeanor: Serene, soft-spoken, genuinely faithful
  • Secret: Knows something is wrong with the Church but cannot identify what
  • Danger: Would die defending the faith; commands divine power sufficient to challenge the party

The Cardinal — [Name Unknown]

The Skin-Walker. Savaros's superior. Older, more powerful, more patient.

  • CR: 19+ (to be developed)
  • Demeanor: Warm, avuncular, trusted by all
  • Danger: Will not fight unless cornered; prefers to destroy enemies politically

Prior Aldric

The monastery's resident leader. A true believer who maintains the sacred spaces.

  • Level: 9 Cleric
  • Demeanor: Humble, devoted, easily manipulated
  • Secret: None — genuinely innocent
  • Use: Could be an unwitting ally or a tragic casualty

Story Hooks

Information Gathering

The party needs intelligence about the Confluence, the Cardinal, or Church operations. The monastery's archives contain centuries of records.

Assassination

Target the Cardinal during the Confluence. Maximum security, but also the only time his location is predictable.

Rescue

Someone important (an ally? a captured heretic?) is being held in the Pulse Chambers before condemnation.

Sabotage

Disrupt the Confluence itself. Expose the Cardinal's true nature to the assembled clergy. Watch the Church tear itself apart.

The Arterial Texts

Mira mentioned the texts are hidden in an "Unclaimed Pocket." Could there be a path from the monastery's depths to such a place? The still blood might hide doorways to nowhere...

items.title: Sporehaven
items.content:
Sporehaven

Overview

Pilgrim Village in the Blooming Rot Type: Settlement — Pilgrim Way-Station Domain: Talaris Bloomrend the Verdant King Region: The Blooming Rot (Talar'Noth)

Sporehaven is a small village deep within the Verdant King's domain, grown rather than built. It serves as a waystation for pilgrims seeking the "Verdant Crown" � willing transformation into the cycle of death and rebirth that Talaris embodies.

The settlement emerges from the jungle like a growth rather than a construction. Buildings are living trees bent into walls, roots woven into floors, mushroom caps forming roofs. Vine bridges connect the larger structures.

Atmosphere

The Smell: Overwhelming compost. Rich, dark, fertile. The smell of things becoming other things � not unpleasant, but inescapable. The People: Human, mostly. But the longer you look, the more you notice:
  • Bark patches on skin like birthmarks
  • Mushrooms sprouting from shoulders, necks, scalps
  • Eyes with faint green luminescence that shift shades based on emotional state
  • Movements that are slightly too slow, too calm, too patient

The residents are Spore-Touched � pilgrims who chose to join the cycle willingly. They bloom slowly, beautifully. When they die, they become the garden. When the garden dies, it becomes them again.

The Eyes: The green luminescence in a Spore-Touched's eyes is not static:
  • Shade shifts with emotion � darker greens for sorrow or contemplation, brighter greens for curiosity or warmth, pale almost-yellow for alarm
  • Pulses when communicating with brethren � a visible ripple of light passes between Spore-Touched when they share awareness through the fungal network
  • This pulsing is involuntary � they cannot hide when they are "speaking" to each other or to the King

Key Locations

Architecture

  • Buildings: Living trees bent into walls, not constructed
  • Roofs: Mushroom caps of impossible colors
  • Walkways: Vine-woven bridges between structures
  • Lighting: Bioluminescent fungi (soft greens and blues)

The Pilgrim's Rest

An inn grown from three intertwined trees for travelers:
  • Moss-bedding rooms
  • Hookah room with grown-gourd pipe and brazier
  • Rooms rent for 4 gold per night
  • Payment bowl absorbs into root-floor within minutes

Tavern

Hollowed-out trunk with fungal shelves and root-stools:
  • Mushroom stew
  • Bread that tastes of honey and soil
  • Fermented fruit drink
  • Food is strange but good � too good

Notable NPCs

The Elder Woman

Role: Village spokesperson / informal leader Appearance:
  • Elderly, moss growing in grey hair
  • Bark creeping up her knuckles
  • Eyes with green luminescence (shifts to warmer shades when speaking kindly)
  • Smile that never quite wavers
Demeanor: Patient, unhurried, warm but unsettling. Speaks in rustling-leaves laughter. Knowledge:
  • Knows the path to Verdant Pass ("The Wound")
  • Understands Sovereign marks and their implications
  • Connected to the King through the Spore-Touch � "What he knows, we feel. Dimly."
Key Quotes:
  • "You carry preserved death with you. Interesting. The King will have... opinions about that."
  • "The King doesn't give. Everything that enters the Green becomes part of the cycle. Eventually."
  • "If the King speaks to you � answer honestly. He already knows the truth. Lies just make him hungry."

The King's Awareness

The villagers explained that the Verdant King senses all life within his domain:

  • Root Network: The King has been "tasting your footsteps" since the border
  • Shared Perception: The Spore-Touched feel what the King knows, like "hearing a conversation through a wall"
  • Detection: They could sense Mira's bones in the barrel � "power, old power, the kind that makes the cycle itch"
On Sovereign Marks: The elder woman noted that foreign Sovereign marks "stand out like a stone in compost" to the King:
  • Some marks he ignores (petty claims)
  • Some marks he finds interesting (messages between Sovereigns)
  • Some marks belong to Sovereigns he has "history" with � those he pays attention to
Communication Through Eyes: When the elder woman spoke of the King's awareness, her eyes pulsed faintly � indicating she was relaying information through the network, not just speaking from memory.

Directions to Verdant Pass

Distance: Two days' travel southeast Route: Through the Hunger Garden, past the Congregation Grove, into the foothills Destination: "The Wound" � a cliff where someone fell long ago, a cave below where something crawled to die but "didn't finish dying"

The body in Verdant Pass has refused to rot for twenty-two years. The King has tolerated this anomaly � no one knows why.

Key Moments

Party Visit

  • Party arrived Day 1 in the Blooming Rot
  • Jonas roared to announce their presence
  • Fursen asked about caves near cliffs � learned of "The Wound"
  • Jonas asked about Sovereign marks (without revealing his brand)
  • The elder woman noticed his curiosity: "Why do you ask?"
  • Party ate at tavern, rented room at Pilgrim's Rest (4 gold)
  • Rested overnight before continuing to Verdant Pass

Party's Cover Story

  • Fursen explained they carry bones of someone who wanted to reunite with her husband
  • She died before she could
  • They're completing her journey
  • The elder woman found this "beautiful, in its way"

The Ashen Realms

The Corpse-Continent

The world existed before Aedwynn's death, but when the Maker was slain, the land conformed to the shape of her corpse. The Thirteen Sovereigns now rule domains built from her stolen organs.

The Domains

  • Ossathar (North-Central) — Vortegas the Bone-Warden

items.title: The Blooming Rot
items.content:
The Blooming Rot

Domain: Talaris Bloomrend the Verdant King | Type: Living Forest

Overview

The Blooming Rot is not a forest — it IS Talaris Bloomrend. Every tree, every fungus, every blade of grass is connected through his consciousness. The forest watches because the Verdant King watches. It remembers because he remembers.

Death feeds life here. Corpses bloom into flowers. Decay becomes growth. The cycle never stops.

1. Sporehaven — Entry Point

A pilgrim waystation of fungal huts and moss-draped shelters clustered around a massive dead tree called the Pilgrim's Rest. Interior lit by bioluminescent fungi. Air smells of damp earth and cooking spores.

Residents are "Spore-Touched" — pilgrims who chose willing transformation into the cycle. Bark creeps up their skin, moss grows in their hair, their eyes glow with green luminescence.

What the party learned: The Verdant King has been "tasting their footsteps since the border." He sensed the preserved death (Mira's bones) they carried. Foreign Sovereign marks "stand out like a stone in compost." Honesty is mandatory — the King detects lies.

2. The Sweetwater Marsh

A low-lying wetland where the forest floor gives way to black water and tussock islands. The water is crystal clear — deceptively so. It's filtered through fungal root systems but carries addictive properties.

Hazard: Sweetwater Compulsion. Those who drink become charmed and compelled to stay. After 24 hours, the compulsion strengthens. After 48 hours, victims begin to calcify. The "Dreaming Stones" visible throughout the marsh are pilgrims who drank and never left — calcified, overgrown, still breathing.

3. The Pilgrim's Spine

A long, winding ridge of compacted earth and ancient root systems rising above the forest floor. The safest route through mid-forest — elevated above the worst predators, marked with fungal lanterns that glow at night.

Hazard: Narrow path. Some sections require careful navigation. The drop is 30-60 feet into dense undergrowth. Things move in the shadow below, looking up at the lit path, waiting for someone to fall.

4. The Hunger Garden

A vast basin where the forest is "wrong." The canopy is so thick no sunlight reaches the floor. Everything is lit by bioluminescence — beautiful and deadly. Plants have learned animals are food. Animals have learned plants are food. This is Talaris's digestive system at its most active.

Hazards: Natural darkness (only bioluminescence). Active predation — encounters every 30 minutes. Maw of the Garden traps (pit traps that digest). Gullet Vines. Corpse Lily Lurkers. Thornback Behemoths that everything avoids.

The Bone Trail — previous pilgrims' remains mark the "safe" path.

5. The Congregation Grove

A ring of thirteen massive trees (each over 200 feet tall) surrounding a clearing of soft moss and perpetual green twilight. Sacred site where Talaris listens. Air thick with spores that "think."

The Choir Blooms questioned the party:

  • "What do you carry into the King's domain?"
  • "What do you seek at the Wound?"
  • "Who sent you, and why?"
  • "What would you offer for passage?"

The party gave honest answers — they carried the bones of someone who wanted to reunite with her husband. Honest answers are rewarded. Lies are detected and punished.

6. Verdant Pass (The Wound)

A scar where the Blooming Rot simply stops. See separate entry.

Party History

The party traveled through the Blooming Rot carrying Mira's remains. They burned creatures twice with fire (angering the forest). But at the Congregation Grove, Sol shared a memory of Aedwynn the Maker with Talaris — the Verdant King saw his creator alive for the first time since the Usurpation. The Choir Blooms wept golden spores.

Talaris said: "She was... beautiful."

The fire is not forgiven. But the memory changed something.

items.content:
The Chamber of the Final Breath

type: location

region: Veinspire Catacombs

sovereign: none (Pre-Usurpation)

status: active

visited: true

sessions:

- 17

tags:

- location

- pre-usurpation

- sacred

- aedwynn

The Chamber of the Final Breath

The Door

Opening: When the brass key is inserted, the door unfolds along impossible angles — origami geometry, sections rotating inward, folding into itself like paper.

The Chamber

Physical Description

  • Size: Cathedral-vast, impossibly larger inside than out
  • Ceiling: Stretches into darkness that feels like sky
  • Walls: Curve inward like the inside of a ribcage, smooth and shaped
  • Floor: Living rock, warm to the touch
  • Lighting: Golden luminescence from the tree — the color of dawn

The Body

Note: The Sovereigns took his organs — lungs, heart, skin, brain, all of it. This is something else. A shell. An echo. The part of him that couldn't be carved up and divided.

The Gifts

When touched, the Maker's presence can still communicate — an echo of consciousness, fading but present.

Gifts Given:
Recipient Gift Description
Jonas Offered, Refused Golden seed — counterweight to Azerach's brand
Fursen The Names Complete Leonin ancestral memory
Sol Raven The Witness Maker's heir, divine memory, creation power
Mira Knowledge Location of Elias's body
Kael None Did not touch the body
The Golden Seed: Was in the Maker's folded hands for 2,000 years. Now inside Sol Raven.

Significance

To the World

  • Last remnant of Aedwynn that wasn't divided among the Sovereigns
  • Contains the Maker's final message and gifts
  • Proof that something of the old world survived
  • Protected by wards no Sovereign can breach

To the Party

  • Jonas learned what Azerach's brand truly is (and refused help)
  • Fursen received his people's stolen history
  • Sol became the Maker's Witness
  • Mira learned where to find her husband's body
  • Kael did not interact — significance unknown

Protections

The chamber appears to have ancient wards:

  • No enemies found them during 8-hour rest
  • The Maker's presence may still guard the space
  • Azerach's brand went silent inside — Sovereigns cannot observe here
  • Safe haven in hostile territory

Current Status

  • Door remains open (folded geometry)
  • Tree still hums with ancient power
  • Body unchanged — peaceful, smiling
  • Golden seed no longer in hands (given to Sol)
  • Party used as safe rest location

items.title: The Clockwork Caravanserai
items.content:
The Clockwork Caravanserai

Overview

Attribute Details
Type Mobile fortress / Temporal marketplace
Location The Membrane between Silence and Time
Status Destroyed (collapsed into crater)
Affiliation The Horologers (refugees from Imhuran's domain)

Description

A fortress of brass and steel crawling on a hundred insect legs, half buried, half afloat. Each leg ended in a sand-bell: when it stepped, the bells tolled, and the dunes rippled outward in concentric waves. Ladders and chains hung down its sides; small lights moved across its surface — lanterns, people, maybe both. The air smelled of oil, old incense, and roasted metal.

At its center hung a massive gear-halo, slowly rotating, projecting a beam of cold light that counted seconds across the sand.

Banners of mismatched cloth fluttered from the hull, bearing the sigil of an open clock face with an eye at its center: the symbol of the Horologers.

The Toll

To enter the Caravan, travelers must pay one of three tolls:

Toll Effect
Years Lose a measure of time (cosmetic aging); the Caravan owes "interest"
Breath Exhale into a glass vial; lose half maximum breath for a day
Truth Speak a confession that causes pain; recorded permanently

Key Locations

The Market of Lost Seconds

An open bazaar suspended in motion. Bridges of chain linked tents and pavilions together, each glowing with different-colored light. Merchants in masks traded not goods but moments: bottled laughter, sealed tears, captured seconds.

The Broker's Pavilion

A tent of black silk and bone beads. Its keeper, Master Caldris, traded in lost potential: years, dreams, and destiny fragments.

The Chronometer Forge

A pit where discarded timepieces melted and reformed into weapons or armor that manipulated duration.

The Observation Deck

Overlooked the desert. The runes in the sky orbited closer here.

The Sleeping Quarters

Cages hung from chains, swinging slowly; those who slept there dreamed out of order.

The Lower Decks

Where the Echo Collector resided, trading in voices, gods, and cores. Dream cages lined the corridors, harvesting vapors from sleepers.

Destruction

When Jonas bonded the Warden's Core by placing it in the right conduit of the Echo Collector's vault, the awakening triggered a temporal cascade. The entire Caravan shuddered with each pulse of the newly-awakened god-fragment.

The structure imploded, folding into itself like a dying clock. Only a crater remained — a shallow bowl filled with fragments of gears and shards that glittered faintly, humming the same broken rhythm as Jonas's new heart.

Notable Inhabitants

NPC Role Fate
Horologer Guards Security; porcelain-masked constructs Destroyed with Caravan
Marn the Glasswright Merchant; bottler of moments Unknown
The Echo Collector Broker of divine relics Unknown

items.title: The Clockwork Sanctum
items.content:
The Clockwork Sanctum

Domain: Imhuran the Regent of Hours | Type: Temporal Realm

Overview

The Clockwork Sanctum is a realm where time is tangible. Mountain-sized gears turn through different time periods. Hourglass monoliths contain compressed decades. Rivers of liquid chronology flow through fractured courtrooms that replay trials forever. Prisons hold inmates who age a century per day. Caverns exist where time reverses with each breath.

Everything serves a schedule. The Regent's servants move on precise timetables, their lives measured to the second. Citizens experience different time rates based on social class. Waste is heresy. Inefficiency is sin.

The party was pulled into the Clockwork Sanctum and forced to endure a divine sentencing machine — thirteen hours compressed and stretched through impossible temporal spaces.

The Trials

  • Hours I-III: The Arterial Collapse (testing temporal pressure), the Infinite Loop (a corridor repeated endlessly — they had to find the "false segment"), and the Choir of Shadows (echoes of dead Sovereign-worshippers)
  • Hours IV-V: Discovery of the Frozen Moments — temporal prisons where Fursen was held
  • Hour XI: The Frozen City — a city suspended in time. The party encountered a bookkeeper who offered to trade memories for passage. Sol traded a personal memory for Clockmaker's Touch — a temporal manipulation ability.
  • Hour XII: The Critical Hour — the trial attempted to erase Kael as an "ontological anomaly." It proved he "should not exist" and tried to erase him from reality. Kael survived despite being declared impossible.
  • Hour XIII: Expulsion — the trial declared the party "metaphysical errors" and violently expelled them

What Happened to Each Party Member

  • Sol Raven: In the Frozen City (Hour XI), traded a personal memory to the bookkeeper for Clockmaker's Touch — a temporal manipulation ability that deepened his connection to pre-Sovereign power
  • Jonas: Attempted to intimidate Imhuran directly. Received a temporal brand on his chest as punishment — spreading corruption that was later cleansed by Mira at the Pallid Crossroads
  • Kael: Hour XII proved he is an ontological anomaly — absent from Imhuran's temporal ledger. Revealed as a fragment vomited by Vor'Kael the Hollow Empress. A being with no origin point who exists despite never being born.
  • Fursen: Found imprisoned in temporal stasis — frozen outside of time, aware but unable to move for what may have been centuries. The party freed him during Hours IV-V. Fursen had served his sentence — the party simply collected him upon release.

Significance

The trial attempted to break them but failed. They survived divine judgment that should have destroyed them and were declared "certified anomalies that reality itself cannot properly process."

items.title: The Devoured Courts
items.content:
The Devoured Courts

Sovereign: Vor'Kael the Hollow Empress Location: Vor'Khalem region, southwestern Stolen Aspect: Hunger and Meaning Concept: Hunger, Consumption, Dissolution of Meaning Size: ~470,000 square miles

Overview

The Devoured Courts is where meaning goes to die. This region has been warped by Vor'Kael's stolen power over hunger and meaning—the divine aspect of consumption she ripped from Aedwynn. The territory exists in perpetual consumption. Here, everything is eaten: food, objects, ideas, identities, purpose itself.

It is a realm where meaning itself is digestible, where purpose dissolves, and where hunger is the only truthful emotion.

Law of Hunger

Vor'Kael enforces the Law of Hunger throughout her realm:

  • Meaning is digestible — All concepts can be consumed
  • Emptiness seeks filling — The void must be satisfied
  • All things return to nothing — Everything dissolves eventually
  • Hunger is the only truthful emotion — All other feelings are illusions
  • Understanding is consumption — To know is to devour

Her priests speak in metaphors because literal truth dissolves in the Courts.

Geography

The climate is humid and uncomfortable—the air feels thick with dissolution. Colors are muted; sounds are dampened; everything feels slightly less real than it should.

Major Regions

The Stomach Basins — Vast depressions where the Digestive Engine's hunger is concentrated. Staying too long causes existential erosion—first you forget why you came, then who you are, then that you are. Used for executions and processing. The Intestinal Passages — Winding canyons where meaning has already been partially digested. Travel here is safer but unsettling. Objects lose their names. Caravans speak in simple terms to avoid losing concepts mid-sentence. The Hunger Fields — Plains where the ground itself consumes. Plants don't photosynthesize—they consume. Animals don't graze—they hunt. Even the soil slowly dissolves organic matter. The Bile Marshes — Where the Digestive Engine's waste collects. Acidic pools, dissolving ground, remnants of things that used to mean something. Avoided by everyone sane. The Teeth Ridges — Border mountains that move. Slowly, imperceptibly grinding. Invading armies are pulverized. Mining communities extract processed materials—things ground so fine they've lost all original identity.

Consumption — The Hollow Capital

Population: ~260,000 (fluctuates as meaning erodes)

"We don't build to last. We build to be consumed. Everything ends in the Empress's mouth."

The capital is built around the Mouth of the World—a massive aperture leading to the Digestive Engine's core. The city radiates outward from this hungry center, architecture designed to be temporary, buildings replaced constantly as hunger erodes them.

Life focuses on the present. Planning for the future is difficult when "tomorrow" feels slippery. Citizens live in cycles of creation and dissolution.

Districts

District Character
The Mouth Quarter Edge of the aperture; most dangerous
The Offering Rings Where sacrifices are prepared
The Temporary Markets Commerce; goods only last so long
The Remembering District Where meaning is preserved (at great cost)
The Dissolution Slums Where those losing identity gather
The Feeding Pits Industrial consumption; processing

Notable Locations

Location Description
The Mouth of the World Portal to the Digestive Engine; consumes all
The Hollow Throne Vor'Kael's seat; empty yet full of hunger
The Meaning Vaults Where concepts are preserved (temporarily)
The Feast Halls Endless banquets; never satisfying
The Identity Registry Helps citizens remember who they are

Other Key Locations

The Meaning Vaults

Population: ~18,000

Fortified repositories where meaning is preserved against ambient hunger. Archivists decide what concepts are worth saving. The responsibility slowly erodes their own sense of self; most eventually forget their own names.

The Feeding Pits

Population: ~70,000

Industrial facilities processing objects and concepts for their meaning. Meaning extraction is the primary currency of the Courts. The husks left behind—objects without significance, people without identity—are given to the Empress.

The Identity Registry

A vital public service—regular visits reinforce who you are, what you want, why you exist. Citizens who skip appointments dissolve into nameless husks within months. If someone dissolves but their records survive, they can be "rebuilt"—given back their identity.

Society & Culture

The Hunger Hierarchy

Class Role
The Hollow Empress Vor'Kael; perfect hunger incarnate
The Satisfied Inner court; learned to live with hunger
The Archivists Preserve meaning against dissolution
The Processors Extract and refine meaning
Citizens Struggling to remain coherent
The Fading Losing identity; desperate
The Husks Dissolved; still moving

The Economy of Meaning

Currency is extracted meaning:

  • Distilled Purpose — Standard currency
  • Concentrated Memory — Premium currency
  • Pure Significance — Ultimate currency; rare

Objects have value based on meaning, not material. A mother's wedding ring is worth more than a gold bar.

Identity Maintenance

Remaining yourself requires constant effort:

  • Regular Registry visits
  • Keeping meaningful objects close
  • Maintaining relationships (shared meaning reinforces identity)
  • Repeating your name, your purpose, your history
  • Avoiding the Basins and Marshes

Inhabitants

Vor'Kael's Servants

  • Gastric Spirits — Vapors that suck emotions from mortals
  • Stomach-Priests — Monks whose bellies whisper secrets
  • Digestors — Creatures that eat memories and excrete questions
  • Regurgitants — Beings pulled from Vor'Kael's vomit, half-real
  • The Hollow Choir — Singers with stomachs full of swallowed voices

Creatures

Creature CR Description
Hunger Elemental 6 Living void; consumes matter and meaning
The Dissolved 8 What remains of consumed people
Purpose Wraith 11 Ghost of a lost goal; possesses seekers
Identity Predator 14 Steals selves; wears them briefly
Concept Devourer 17 Erases ideas from reality
The Hollow One 20 Vor'Kael's direct servant; perfect emptiness

Connection to Kael

Kael was born from this realm—or rather, vomited from it.

Long ago, Vor'Kael consumed a concept (perhaps destiny, perhaps identity itself). Something went wrong. The concept refused dissolution. Unable to process the fragment, unable to keep it, Vor'Kael expelled it.

That fragment took form and became Kael.

Implications:
  • Kael is Vor'Kael's unfinished meal
  • He represents meaning that cannot be digested
  • His existence proves the Empress's power is not absolute
  • She instinctively hunts for him, though she may not consciously remember
And Kael killed her ancient Skin-Walker by being indigestible. When Savaros consumed him, the monster sealed his own fate—poisoned by consuming something that refused to be consumed.

— The Party's Passage

Entry Through Lastwell

The party entered through Lastwell, a border settlement where meaning begins to fade. There, Fursen betrayed Jonas by giving his name to the husks, and Jonas acquired the Closed Locket containing Vor'Kael's true name.

Consumption (Capital)

The party walked through the grey streets of Consumption:

  • Colors faded to grey
  • Words came harder
  • Meaning itself grew thin
  • The constant chest-hunger for meaning

The Mouth of the World

At the vast depression where Vor'Kael waits:

  • Fursen's 10,000 names screamed in recognition (WIS save SUCCESS)
  • Sol's Codex tried to throw itself in—Kael's Echo panicking (WIS save FAILED)
  • Jonas caught the Codex one inch from the edge

Vor'Kael spoke directly to the party:

"...visitors... you carry interesting flavors... names that should be forgotten, an echo that escaped, and a secret my brother keeps from me..."

Jonas's Demands

Using the true name Azerach revealed, Jonas demanded:

  1. Safe passage for the party
  2. The Throat of Forgotten Things opened
  3. He keeps the name

All granted. Vor'Kael had no choice—her true name is a leash.

The Throat of Forgotten Things

The party spent 5 days traveling through The Throat of Forgotten Things:

  • Day 1: The Gullet (Sol found the Remembrance Seal)
  • Day 2: The Lodged Kingdom (Jonas refused to help The Undigested)
  • Day 3: The Concept Graveyard (Sol infected with Possibility)
  • Day 4: The Satiated One (Jonas spoke the true name aloud)
  • Day 5: Exit to Veinspire border

Consequences

  • Vor'Kael will hunt Jonas forever — he spoke her true name twice in her domain
  • Sol is infected with Possibility — unlived lives whisper in his mind
  • Safe passage ended — when they left the Throat, Vor'Kael's promise ended

Travel Times

Journey Distance Time (foot)
Consumption → Meaning Vaults ~200 miles 10 days
Consumption → Teeth Ridges ~350 miles 17 days
Border to border ~700 miles 35 days
Note: Travel in the Courts erodes memory. Bring written records of your destination and purpose.
items.raw: The Devoured Courts Sovereign: Vor'Kael the Hollow Empress Location: Vor'Khalem region, southwestern Stolen Aspect: Hunger and Meaning Concept: Hunger, Consumption, Dissolution of Meaning Size: ~470,000 square miles Overview The Devoured Courts is where meaning goes to die. This region has been warped by Vor'Kael's stolen power over hunger and meaning—the divine aspect of consumption she ripped from Aedwynn. The territory exists in perpetual consumption. Here, everything is eaten: food, objects, ideas, identities, purpose itself. It is a realm where meaning itself is digestible, where purpose dissolves, and where hunger is the only truthful emotion. Law of Hunger Vor'Kael enforces the Law of Hunger throughout her realm: Meaning is digestible — All concepts can be consumed Emptiness seeks filling — The void must be satisfied All things return to nothing — Everything dissolves eventually Hunger is the only truthful emotion — All other feelings are illusions Understanding is consumption — To know is to devour Her priests speak in metaphors because literal truth dissolves in the Courts. Geography The climate is humid and uncomfortable—the air feels thick with dissolution. Colors are muted; sounds are dampened; everything feels slightly less real than it should. Major Regions The Stomach Basins — Vast depressions where the Digestive Engine's hunger is concentrated. Staying too long causes existential erosion—first you forget why you came, then who you are, then that you are. Used for executions and processing. The Intestinal Passages — Winding canyons where meaning has already been partially digested. Travel here is safer but unsettling. Objects lose their names. Caravans speak in simple terms to avoid losing concepts mid-sentence. The Hunger Fields — Plains where the ground itself consumes. Plants don't photosynthesize—they consume. Animals don't graze—they hunt. Even the soil slowly dissolves organic matter. The Bile Marshes — Where the Digestive Engine's waste collect

The Dregs

type: location

region: Veinspire

district: The Dregs

status: active

tags:

The Dregs

Veinspire's Forgotten District Where the faithful who can't afford proximity to Mareatha's heart scrape by in buildings that don't pulse, don't breathe, don't remind you with every step that you're living inside a god. Region: Veinspire Type: Slum District

Description

The Dregs is Veinspire's poorest district — the one place in the city where buildings don't share Mareatha's organic architecture. Here, structures are made of mundane stone, rotted wood, and desperate hope.

Key Features

Architecture:
  • Ramshackle structures leaning against each other
  • Roofs that sag, walls that bow
  • Buildings patched with canvas and prayer
  • No pulse, no heartbeat, no divine tissue
The Market:
  • Empty stalls crowd the center square
  • Tarps pulled over meager wares at night
  • Guttering torches in iron brackets
  • The only commerce in poverty
The Canal:
  • Dark water sluggish with refuse
  • Small boats tied to rotting posts
  • Cuts through the eastern edge
  • Not Mareatha's blood — just filth
The People:
  • Those who can't afford proximity to the divine
  • Beggars, thieves, the desperate
  • They don't see things — seeing gets you involved
  • Getting involved gets you dead

Social Dynamics

Don't Ask Questions: No one wants to know. No one wants to be a witness. Don't Flash Wealth: Ten gold is a fortune here. Fifteen gold will get you robbed — or worse. Don't Trust Anyone: The child who smiles at you will mark you for thieves. The old woman who helps you will sell you out for copper. Don't Stay: The Dregs is where you pass through. Not where you stop.

Notable Locations

Old Marten's Shack (Northeast)

A barely-standing hovel where the party sheltered.

  • Single room, dirt floor
  • Straw mattress (previous owner died on it)
  • Crooked table, one stool
  • Fireplace with rusted pot
  • No windows facing the street
Current Status: Party shelter

The Collapsed Building

Across from the market square. Used by local thieves as a watching post. The child thief was spotted here during Fursen's fourth watch.

The Forgotten Ground (West)

A patch of bare earth behind a collapsed fence. No one's backyard. Just forgotten.

events

The party emerged from the Catacomb Reliquary's service tunnels into the Dregs late at night.

Transactions:
  • Fursen bought a barrel for 5 gold (to carry Mira's remains)
  • Jonas paid 10 gold to Gretta for shelter
Note: The party sheltered here before moving on. Kael was buried elsewhere (behind the Church of the Merciful Vein). Theft:
  • During Jonas's third watch (Perception 3), someone pried a board loose and stole Sol's coin pouch
  • Fursen discovered the theft on fourth watch (Perception 21)
  • The child thief is still watching from the collapsed building

The Child Thief

A barefoot child who marked the party when Jonas flashed gold. Led watchers to their shack. Stole Sol's pouch during Jonas's failed watch.

Still watching. Still out there with 300 gold that doesn't belong to them.

Atmosphere

Sights:
  • Torchlight that doesn't reach far
  • Shadows pooling between hovels
  • Stars visible through gaps in roofs
  • A market square that's more mud than stone
Sounds:
  • Dogs barking once and falling silent
  • Arguments in languages you don't speak
  • Someone coughing deep and wet
  • The lap of dark water against rotting posts
Smells:
  • Mud and sewage
  • Woodsmoke and cooking meat (rat? worse?)
  • And underneath — always — the faint copper tang of Mareatha's circulation from elsewhere in the city

items.title: The Pallid Crossroads
items.content:
The Pallid Crossroads

Overview

A Place That Shouldn't Be The Pallid Crossroads exists because people remember it exists. If they ever forgot, it would simply... stop. Type: Settlement Region: The Pallid Waste (Unclaimed territory) Population: Small (exact number unknown — people come and go)

Description

A settlement in the gaps between Sovereign territories. Wooden buildings with smoke rising from chimneys. The distant sound of voices. It emerges from the white landscape like a mirage refusing to dissolve, gaining solidity with each step until suddenly it's there.

A makeshift wooden wall surrounds roughly seventy percent of the town, gaps filled with nothing but intention. Guard towers stand at irregular intervals, manned by people who watch the pale horizon with the practiced vigilance of those who know what comes out of it.

The Nature of the Place

The Pallid Crossroads exists in Unclaimed territory — the gaps between Sovereign domains where reality was never shaped by divine theft. The Pallid Waste is a land of nothing: featureless white dunes, ivory sky indistinguishable from the horizon, silence so complete it feels like weight.

Navigation: You cannot navigate the Waste traditionally. Direction doesn't work here. Instead:
  • Know where you want to go
  • Walk with certainty
  • The Waste listens — if you're certain enough, it takes you there
Existence: The Crossroads persists because its inhabitants refuse to let it be forgotten. Every conversation, every meal shared, every story told is an act of defiance against the nothing. The settlement exists because people insist on it.

If the population drops too low, if too many people forget, the Crossroads will simply vanish.

Key Locations

Mira's Clinic

A converted house near the center of town. Wooden sign above the door: MIRA HEMM — HEALER.

Inside, it smells of herbs and something older. The healer who runs it — Mira Hemm — is a woman who appears to be in her fifties with grey-streaked dark hair and sharp eyes. She moves with the efficiency of someone who has healed more wounds than she can count.

Services:
  • Healing (mundane and magical)
  • Curse removal (some types)
  • Herb supplies
Notable Herbs:
  • Pallid Mint — pale leaves with faint blue tinge; one leaf silences for 24 hours, three leaves cause unconsciousness

The Ivory Inn

A building of pale wood and bleached stone. Interior lit by candles that burn with steady, colorless flames. The innkeeper is a tired woman with kind eyes who asks no questions.

Services:
  • Lodging: 3 silver/night (breakfast included)
  • Food and drink
  • Common room with fireplace
Warning from the Innkeeper:

"Don't go outside after dark unless you have to. Things move in the Waste when the light fades."

The Forge

Blacksmith's workshop. Usually manned, though the smith travels often. When the party visited, the door was unlocked, the building cold, the smith nowhere to be found.

Status: Unavailable (smith traveling)

The Market

If "market" means three stalls selling whatever people have found. Supplies are scarce in the Unclaimed — traders sell salvage from abandoned outposts and whatever can be scavenged from the old world's remnants.

Inhabitants

The people of the Pallid Crossroads came here to hide from the world. Most are not fighters. They're refugees, hermits, outcasts — people who found their way to the gaps between territories and decided to stay.

Known Residents:
Name Role Notes
Mira Hemm Healer Actually Mira Alethain in hiding
Innkeeper Ivory Inn proprietor Tired, kind, asks no questions
Hunter Woman Resident Lost friends to the White Marcher
Young Man Resident Nervous energy; helped with caravan quest
Middle-Aged Man Resident Seen too much to be surprised

Threats

The White Marcher

A creature of absence that hunted in the Waste east of the Crossroads. It erased things from existence rather than destroying them — wounds it inflicted were literally missing pieces of reality.

Status: Killed by the party

The Marcher destroyed a caravan of six people, partially erasing their bodies and supplies. The party tracked it, fought it, and killed it — but not before suffering wounds that couldn't heal and losses that were permanent.

The Waste Itself

The Pallid Waste wants to forget everything. Blood fades. Footprints vanish. Stay too long, and it might forget you too.

The Caravan Incident

A caravan of six people went missing while scavenging from abandoned outposts east of town. Signs found:

  • Blood on the eastern path
  • Boxes half-vanished — not broken, just absent
  • Clean edges where reality had been edited

The party investigated, encountered the White Marcher, killed it, and found the caravan's remains:

  • Three wagons (one half-vanished)
  • Four corpses, each partially erased
  • No survivors
  • Recovered: 47 gold, 3 days rations, half-erased letter

The Crossroads lost six irreplaceable people. In a settlement that exists through memory, every loss is existentially dangerous.

Visitors

The Father and Son

An old man with a walking stick and a young man carrying firewood. Travelers who guided the party to the Crossroads and explained how navigation works in the Waste.

The young man gave Fursen his rope freely when asked — no payment, no questions. Just one traveler helping another.

Old Man: "The Waste takes everything eventually. Might as well give things away while you still can."

Atmosphere

The Pallid Crossroads feels like a place that shouldn't exist. Step outside the wall and the white nothing stretches in every direction. The sky is indistinguishable from the ground. Sound dies. Color fades.

But inside the wall, there's smoke and voices and the stubborn insistence of people who refuse to be forgotten.

"The Waste doesn't hate you. The Waste doesn't feel anything. It just forgets — and if you stay too long, it forgets you too. The Crossroads survives because we refuse to be forgotten. Every conversation, every meal shared, every story told — it's all an act of defiance. We exist because we insist on it. And so far, that's been enough."

— Ivory Inn keeper

items.title: The Throat of Forgotten Things
items.content:
The Throat of Forgotten Things

Overview

The Throat of Forgotten Things is Vor'Kael's esophagus — a 5-day passage through living meat that descends from the Devoured Courts into the deeper regions of the Maker's corpse. It was sealed since the Usurpation until Jonas used Vor'Kael's true name to demand it opened. Contains the Lodged Kingdom, the Concept Graveyard, and the Satiated One

Overview

The Throat of Forgotten Things is Vor'Kael's esophagus — a passage of living meat that descends from the Devoured Courts into the deeper regions of the Maker's corpse. It was sealed since the Usurpation until Jonas used Vor'Kael's true name to demand it opened.

What It Contains:
  • Civilizations Vor'Kael swallowed but couldn't fully digest
  • Concepts too complex or contradictory to dissolve
  • Ancient beings immune to her hunger
  • The remnants of everything she tried to consume and failed

Geography (5-Day Journey)

Day 1 — The Gullet

The entry passage. A tunnel of wet meat, 20 feet wide, 15 feet high, sloping down.

Features:
  • Constant peristalsis (throat-muscle contractions)
  • Bile pools — grey-green, acidic, deepening as you descend
  • No natural light — only bioluminescent growths
  • Skeletons of previous travelers
  • The Remembrance Seal was found here (Sol acquired it)
The Woman's Skeleton: A skeleton in a bile pool, centuries old, arm reaching forward. She wore a Remembrance Seal and almost escaped — dissolved inches from the exit.

Day 2 — The Lodged Kingdom

The Throat widens dramatically to contain an entire civilization stuck in Vor'Kael's esophagus for 800 years.

The City:
  • White stone architecture (arches, columns, domes)
  • Elegant but scarred by centuries of digestive exposure
  • Too large to go down, too solid to dissolve
  • Population: 12 survivors (The Undigested)
The Undigested: Survivors adapted to life in a god's throat. Changed over 800 years:
  • Pale grey-white translucent skin (bones/blood visible through it)
  • Milky faded eyes
  • Clothing patched with tissue
  • Each wears a Remembrance Seal

They cannot leave — the Seals that protect them in the Throat fail in the outside world. They're trapped forever.

Party Interaction:
  • The elder offered knowledge in exchange for freedom (using Vor'Kael's name)
  • Jonas refused to help
  • The Undigested watched them leave without offering guidance

Day 3 — The Concept Graveyard

A vast cavern filled with half-digested concepts — ideas given physical form.

What's There:
  • Faceless woman statue (shimmers between solid/liquid) — Longing
  • Black liquid pool (perfectly still, no reflection) — Regret
  • Skeleton sitting upright with wrong bones, endless smile — Madness/Joy
  • Glass tree with tinkling leaves — Nostalgia
  • Door standing alone, closed, something on other side — Possibility
  • Cracked mirror showing nothing — Emptiness
  • Hundreds more, some dormant, some reaching
Dangers:
  • Some concepts are hungry — they want to be thought about
  • Touching the wrong idea causes infection — the concept lodges in your mind
  • No clear path through — requires intuition or guidance
Sol's Infection:

Day 4 — The Obstruction (The Satiated One)

The passage narrows to single-file width, then opens to an enormous chamber containing The Satiated One.

The Satiated One: An ancient serpentine being older than the Sovereigns. Perfectly content. Vor'Kael cannot digest it because it has no meaning to consume — no hunger, no desire, no purpose. Just existence.

It has been blocking this passage for 800 years. It let the party pass because Jonas speaking Vor'Kael's name aloud was "interesting."

Day 5 — The Exit

The passage rises, steepens. Flesh-walls thin to translucent. Daylight ahead.

Emergence Point: A ridge of exposed tissue at the outer edge of Vor'Kael's domain — where her stolen organs meet unaffiliated flesh. View:
  • Behind: The Devoured Courts
  • Ahead: Empty road across the Maker's corpse
  • Distance: 2 days to Veinspire

Environmental Hazards

Hazard Effect
Bile Pools 1d6 acid damage on contact; deeper pools = more damage
Peristalsis DEX saves to avoid being knocked prone or pushed
Meaning Drain Long rests in the Throat risk losing memories or emotions
Concept Infection Touching hungry concepts requires WIS save or become infected
Identity Erosion Extended time causes people to forget who they are

Items Found

Item Found By Location
Remembrance Seal Sol Raven Day 1 — skeleton in bile pool

Conditions Acquired

Condition Character Source
Infected — Possibility Sol Raven Day 3 — Door of Possibility

NPCs Encountered

NPC Location Status
The Undigested Day 2 — Lodged Kingdom Denied help by Jonas
The Satiated One Day 4 — The Obstruction Let party pass

Why It Was Sealed

Vor'Kael sealed the Throat after the Usurpation. According to her:

"What lies beyond should not be visited."

The passage leads through her digestive system into deeper regions of the Maker's corpse — places even a Sovereign finds uncomfortable. The Satiated One blocks the deepest point, a reminder that even gods have things they cannot consume.

items.title: Veinspire
items.content:
Veinspire

Domain: The Sangreal Dominion (Mareatha) | Type: Major City

Overview

Veinspire is the beating heart of Mareatha's domain — a city built where the Vein-Mother's stolen divine heart pumps loudest. The city follows a ring-district design, with multiple walled districts surrounding a central cathedral. Arterial canals flow through every district. Buildings are stained red with centuries of blood-mist. The walls literally breathe.

The Tribunal operates throughout the city, handling many matters beyond just religious enforcement. The Church of the Merciful Vein is one of many churches in the city, though the Grand Cathedral dominates the skyline.

Districts

The Lesser Sacral District

A quieter district with lower divine presence and moderate Inquisition activity. Key locations include:

  • The Frayed Codex — A narrow bookshop run by Thessaly, an impossibly old bookseller. Officially sells hymnals and devotional texts. Actually deals in restricted texts, pre-Usurpation fragments, and forbidden knowledge.
  • The Whetstone and Anvil — A smithy run by Garrett, a discreet craftsman who doesn't ask questions and doesn't talk to the Church.
  • Church of the Merciful Vein — A small congregation church, station of High Inquisitor Seraphine Vale.
  • The Catacomb Reliquary — West side of the district, main Tribunal checkpoint. Where prisoners go to the deep cells. Was operated by Savaros the High Keeper.

The Dregs

Veinspire's poorest district. Ramshackle buildings, market stalls, sluggish canals. No one looks at you directly here — seeing things gets you involved. Unlike the rest of the city, the buildings don't pulse or breathe. No divine presence reaches this far.

The Grand Cathedral

The central religious structure where citizens receive communion (filtered blood-water).

The Catacombs

Beneath the city lies an extensive catacomb network that connects to older tunnels and eventually leads to the Catacomb Reliquary.

Party History

The party arrived in Veinspire as escorts for a merchant caravan. They explored the city and descended into the catacombs.

They descended into the catacombs, witnessed Sister Marwen's corruption by divine tendrils, and were interrogated by the clergy. High Inquisitor Seraphine Vale declared them "potential heretics" and forbade them from leaving. The party met Kael, a young scholar with resistance connections, and discovered the Resonance Theorists — a hidden cell studying divine memory.

They infiltrated the church archives and stole the Resonant Codex. Kael joined the party. They eventually escaped through the southern mines and fled to the Pallid Crossroads as fugitives.

The party returned via the Arterial Tunnels beneath the city, emerging in the Lesser Sacral District. They visited:

  • The Frayed Codex — Thessaly recognized Mira from 30 years ago. Sol read The Doctrine of Still Air and a book on Vor'Kael that has a mind of its own, but returned them — too expensive. Fursen begged for The Ledger of Moments and Thessaly gave it to him for free, with a promise to return and tell her how his quest concludes.
  • The Whetstone and Anvil — Garrett assessed Jonas's Custodian Armplate and shared legends about lost artifacts.
  • Church of the Merciful Vein — Confronted Seraphine Vale. Mira revealed she had delivered Seraphine at birth 34 years ago. The party showed Seraphine evidence of Kaleth Vorn's crimes. Seraphine's faith cracked and she cooperated, providing intelligence on Savaros, the Cardinal, and the Confluence.
  • The Catacomb Reliquary — Descended to confront Savaros the High Keeper. Both Mira and Kael died in the battle. Savaros was destroyed when Kael's paradox nature proved indigestible.

The party escaped through the Dregs with Savaros's Ledger — 15 centuries of Tribunal intelligence.

Current Status

The Confluence has occurred. While the party was in the Blooming Rot laying Mira to rest, the Tribunal completed their ritual. The party doesn't know what happened or what changed. Seraphine's status is unknown.
items.raw: Veinspire Domain: The Sangreal Dominion (Mareatha) | Type: Major City Overview Veinspire is the beating heart of Mareatha's domain — a city built where the Vein-Mother's stolen divine heart pumps loudest. The city follows a ring-district design, with multiple walled districts surrounding a central cathedral. Arterial canals flow through every district. Buildings are stained red with centuries of blood-mist. The walls literally breathe. The Tribunal operates throughout the city, handling many matters beyond just religious enforcement. The Church of the Merciful Vein is one of many churches in the city, though the Grand Cathedral dominates the skyline. Districts The Lesser Sacral District A quieter district with lower divine presence and moderate Inquisition activity. Key locations include: The Frayed Codex — A narrow bookshop run by Thessaly, an impossibly old bookseller. Officially sells hymnals and devotional texts. Actually deals in restricted texts, pre-Usurpation fragments, and forbidden knowledge. The Whetstone and Anvil — A smithy run by Garrett, a discreet craftsman who doesn't ask questions and doesn't talk to the Church. Church of the Merciful Vein — A small congregation church, station of High Inquisitor Seraphine Vale. The Catacomb Reliquary — West side of the district, main Tribunal checkpoint. Where prisoners go to the deep cells. Was operated by Savaros the High Keeper. The Dregs Veinspire's poorest district. Ramshackle buildings, market stalls, sluggish canals. No one looks at you directly here — seeing things gets you involved. Unlike the rest of the city, the buildings don't pulse or breathe. No divine presence reaches this far. The Grand Cathedral The central religious structure where citizens receive communion (filtered blood-water). The Catacombs Beneath the city lies an extensive catacomb network that connects to older tunnels and eventually leads to the Catacomb Reliquary. items.title: Verdant Pass
items.content:
Verdant Pass — The Wound

Overview

The Place Where Nothing Rots Type: Geographic Anomaly / Sacred Site Location: Southeastern edge of the Blooming Rot Sovereign: None — Talaris cannot reach here Significance: ✅ Final resting place of Mira and Elias Alethain

Description

The Threshold

A line in the earth marks where the Blooming Rot ends. On one side: moss, fungi, roots, life consuming death — the full expression of Talaris's power. On the other: nothing.

Grey stone. Bare rock. A narrow ravine where the forest refuses to grow.

The transition is absolute. One step you're in the eternal garden. The next, you're in sterile silence.

Inside the Wound

The ravine extends for roughly a mile — a scar in the landscape where Talaris's influence cannot reach.

Environmental Features:
  • Cold, dry air
  • Absolute silence — no insects, no birdsong, no wind
  • Stone that has never known decay
  • Darkness that lanterns cannot fully dispel
  • Footsteps that echo strangely
The Bleeding Blade's Reaction: When Jonas entered Verdant Pass, the cursed sword went cold and quiet. There was no life to drink, no blood to sense. The blade was useless here — a tool designed for the living, powerless in a place that has forgotten what living means. Sol's Reaction: The shard of Aedwynn within Sol pulsed with recognition. This was a place the Maker knew — or rather, a place that remembered the Maker.

The Cave of Waiting

Description

At the center of the ravine, a natural cave mouth opens in the cliff face. Low entrance, perhaps twenty feet across. Inside: bare stone, absolute stillness, and perfect preservation.

Properties

Property Effect
No Decay Nothing rots; organic matter is preserved indefinitely
No Growth Plants cannot grow; fungal spores die
Temporal Stasis Time has diminished meaning; the dead remain as they were
Divine Immunity Talaris's power cannot reach; possibly immune to all Sovereign influence

Current Occupants

The Aletheins — Together at Last Elias Alethain — Skeleton, pristine white, hands folded across chest. Died 22 years ago. Has been waiting ever since. Mira Alethain — Skeleton, placed beside Elias by Fursen. Wedding ring on finger. Hand positioned to hold Elias's.

Two skeletons hold hands in the darkness. Husband and wife. Healer and saint. Twenty-two years of separation, finally ended.

Origin — The Wound

What Happened Here

When Talaris Bloomrend claimed the Blooming Rot as his domain after the Usurpation, his power spread through every inch of organic matter. The cycle claimed everything.

Almost everything.

Something in this ravine resisted. The nature of the resistance is unknown:

  • A fragment of Aedwynn's will?
  • A pre-Usurpation ward?
  • A natural phenomenon that predates the Sovereigns?
  • The stubborn refusal of the stone itself?

Whatever it was, Talaris's power flowed around it like water around a rock. The wound healed, but the scar remained.

Talaris's Perspective

The Choir Blooms call this place "The Wound" — not with anger, but with a kind of respect. When asked about it, they acknowledge:

"The healer who died there chose where to end. The King respects that choice. It is... discourteous, perhaps. But there is courage in choosing where you die, even if the place is beyond the cycle."

Talaris tolerates the anomaly. He could not claim it even if he wanted to — and perhaps he doesn't want to. Even the Verdant King, who believes all things must join the cycle, recognizes that some choices are sacred.

— The Reunion

The Party's Arrival

The party arrived at Verdant Pass on the morning of Day 3, having passed through:

  • Sweetwater Marsh (Sol's compulsion and rescue)
  • Pilgrim's Spine (Bloom Hound burning, lie detected)
  • Hunger Garden (Thornback Behemoth killed, Talaris spoke)
  • Congregation Grove (The Questioning, Sol's offering accepted)

The Grove Wardens — thirty-foot humanoids of wood and bark — bowed their heads as the party passed toward the Wound. A mark of respect for what they carried and what they had given.

Finding Elias

Inside the Cave of Waiting, they found Elias Alethain exactly as he'd been for twenty-two years:

  • Skeleton on bare stone
  • Hands folded across chest
  • No rot, no fungal growth
  • Clean white bones, pristine

He'd been waiting.

The Reunion

Fursen lowered the barrel containing Mira's remains. He lifted out her bones — skull, ribcage, spine, arms, hands — and laid them beside Elias. Parallel. Close enough to touch. Sol placed Mira's wedding ring on her finger. The ring had been cold since he retrieved it from the gore in the Catacomb Reliquary. When he slid it onto her finger, it warmed — not magical warmth, just the warmth of remembering.

Sol positioned Mira's hand until her fingers rested against Elias's. The wedding ring gleamed between them.

Fursen spoke:

🦁 "I am sorry we could not reunite you in life. But at least in death, we have brought you together."

The party left them there. Two skeletons holding hands in a place where nothing rots.

Travel Information

Getting There

From To Time Difficulty
Congregation Grove Verdant Pass Half-day Easy (if permitted)
Note: Passage requires permission from the Congregation Grove. The party earned passage through Sol's offering of Aedwynn's memory.

Inside the Pass

The ravine is approximately one mile long. The Cave of Waiting is roughly at the center.

Hazards: None — this is one of the only truly safe places in the Blooming Rot.

Exiting

Beyond the ravine, the Blooming Rot ends entirely. The party emerged into:

  • Rolling hills
  • Brown grass
  • Normal trees (oak, ash)
  • A dirt road toward distant mountains
  • Warm sunrise

Normal world. No eternal garden. No cycle. Just... ordinary land.

Significance

To Talaris

The Wound is a reminder that even a Sovereign's power has limits. Talaris tolerates it — perhaps even respects it — but he cannot claim it.

To the Party

This is where they completed Mira's quest. The culmination of the journey. The place where a two-thousand-year-old saint finally rests beside her husband.

To the Campaign

Verdant Pass represents hope — proof that some things exist beyond Sovereign control. In a world where the Thirteen claim dominion over all aspects of existence, this barren ravine stands as evidence that exceptions exist.

If a place can resist Talaris, perhaps other things can resist other Sovereigns.
