Crownfall.title: Crownfall
Crownfall.content:
Crownfall

Type: Independent City-State Location: The Unclaimed — at the junction of three Sovereign territories Population: ~75,000 permanent residents, 15,000+ transients Government: Council of Coinholders (Ten Founding Houses)

Overview

Crownfall exists because it shouldn't.

A city of nearly a hundred thousand souls thriving in the gaps between Sovereign territories, where no divine authority holds sway, where the laws of three different god-tyrants collide and cancel each other out. It's not a trading post — it's a metropolis. Not a smuggler's haven — it's a civilization. The largest concentration of free people in the known world, and proof that mortals can build something without kneeling to gods.

The name comes from its founding — when King Aldren IV of the Vaelith Dynasty fled the expansion of Mareatha's domain with his court, his treasury, and his crown. He made it this far before his heart gave out. His crown rolled from his dead hand into the dirt of the crossroads. His followers, rather than continue running, decided to stay. They melted the crown for seed money and built a settlement on the corpse of monarchy itself.

That was three hundred years ago. The crown is long gone, but the name remains — a reminder that even kings fall, and that something greater can grow from the wreckage.

Geography

Crownfall sits at a three-way junction:

North: Leads toward Veinspire and Mareatha's Circulatory Dominion Southeast: Leads toward the Blooming Rot and Talaris Bloomrend's territory Southwest: Leads toward Ossathar and Vortegas the Bone-Warden's domain East: The deep Unclaimed — uncharted, dangerous, full of opportunity

The city is built on flat plains, spreading in a roughly circular pattern from the central Coinhall Plaza. Three major avenues radiate outward like spokes of a wheel toward the three Sovereign territories, with ring roads connecting districts at intervals.

The city is surrounded by massive outer walls — ancient stone fortifications expanded over three centuries. More unusually, inner walls separate each district, a legacy of the early days when the Houses didn't trust each other enough to share open streets. Now the district walls serve as territory markers, chokepoints for House guards, and reminders that Crownfall is ten small cities pretending to be one.

The Walls

The Outer Walls: Massive stone fortifications encircling the entire city, 40 feet high and 20 feet thick, with towers every hundred yards. Three major gates (North, Southeast, Southwest) control access to the Sovereign roads, plus the smaller Eastern Gate toward the Unclaimed. House Valdris controls the gates; House Varn mans the walls. The District Walls: Lower but still formidable — 20 feet high, running from the outer walls to the central Coin district like spokes. Each district is essentially a walled compound. Gates between districts are controlled by whichever House claims that territory. In times of crisis, districts can seal themselves off from each other. Why District Walls? Three centuries ago, the founding Houses didn't trust each other. They built walls between their territories before they built walls around the city. The Compact eventually brought peace, but the walls remained — useful for controlling movement, collecting tolls, and reminding everyone that House law changes at every gate. The Deterrent: The walls help, but Crownfall's true defense is its people:
  • Ten powerful Houses, each with private armies and high-level retainers
  • House Varn's mercenary forces — thousands of professional soldiers
  • Countless refugees who fled Sovereign control, many of them powerful adventurers, mages, and warriors
  • The Docent — whose true capabilities are unknown but rumored to be considerable
  • Independent powers who have made Crownfall their home specifically because it's free

A Sovereign army would face walls, yes. But behind those walls? A city of people with nothing to lose and everything to fight for.

Districts

The city is divided into districts separated by ring roads, with noble House territories cutting across district lines.

The Coin (Central District) The heart of the city. The Coinhall Plaza, the Exchange markets, major guild headquarters, banking houses. Where power concentrates and deals are made. The most valuable real estate in the free world. The Rings (Middle Districts) Dense urban construction radiating outward from the Coin. Divided into quarters — the Northring, Eastring, Southring, Westring — each with distinct character. Residential, commercial, industrial, all mixed together. Where most of the city's population lives and works. The Edges (Outer Districts) The newest construction at the city's periphery. Less dense, more varied. Includes:
  • The Kennels — Eastern edge. Expedition staging, relic markets, fortune-seekers. Rough but vital.
  • The Threshold — Northern edge. Thane territory. Cemetery grounds, crematoriums, death rites.
  • The Sprawl — Southern edge. Cheapest housing, newest arrivals, temporary camps.
House Territories The ten Houses each control territory that cuts across district lines — their compounds, their businesses, their people. Walking from Valdris territory to Keth territory means changing which laws apply, even if you're still in the Northring.

The Compact

Crownfall has no formal laws — it has The Compact, an agreement between the Ten Houses that has evolved over three centuries. The Compact isn't written in any single document; it's a living tradition of precedents, deals, and understandings.

Core Principles:
  1. No House Makes War on Another — Assassination, sabotage, and economic warfare are tolerated. Open violence is not. The last inter-house war nearly destroyed the city.
  1. The Tribute Must Flow — Every house contributes to the payments that keep surrounding Sovereigns disinterested. Failure to contribute is grounds for expulsion from the Council.
  1. Neutral Ground is Sacred — Certain locations (Council chambers, the Docent's library, Thane death-grounds) are inviolable. Violence there is punished by all houses collectively.
  1. Outsiders Follow House Law — Visitors must obey the laws of whichever house's territory they're in. Ignorance is no excuse.
  1. The Council's Word is Final — A six-vote majority on the Council of Coinholders settles any dispute. A unanimous ten-vote decision cannot be appealed or revisited for a decade.

The Council of Coinholders

The ten founding houses each hold one seat. The Council meets weekly in the Coinhall (neutral ground at city center) to settle disputes, set trade policy, and manage the tribute.

Current Heads:
House Head Role
House Valdris Sera Valdris Gatekeepers — Access control
House Morrow Aldric Morrow Tithelords — External diplomacy
House Keth Yenra Keth Fleshmongers — Grey market
House Drennan Ogden Drennan Hearthkeepers — Hospitality
House Carran Iselda Carran Coinbinders — Banking
House Varn Torek Varn Blade-Lenders — Security
House Selvik Naya Selvik Veilwalkers — Expeditions
House Orvenne Gavril Orvenne Binding Word — Contracts
House Thane Maren Thane Ashkeepers — Death rites
House Quellan Isen Quellan Tonguesingers — Information
Voting Dynamics:
  • Six votes needed for majority
  • Ten votes (unanimous) overrides any previous ruling
  • Ties are resolved by coin flip (literally — a traditional Crownfall silver)
Current Alliances (Informal):
  • Valdris + Varn — Security bloc
  • Morrow + Carran — Financial axis
  • Keth + Quellan — Shadow alliance
  • Thane — Perpetual neutral
  • Selvik, Orvenne, Drennan — Swing votes, courted by all

With ten houses, alliances shift constantly. A stable bloc of four can block any majority. Getting to six requires coalition-building across philosophical lines.

The Tribute

Crownfall survives because it pays everyone a little and threatens no one enough to matter.

Tribute Recipients:
  • Veinspire (Mareatha) — Paid in rare alchemical components and "blood tithes" (preserved samples)
  • The Blooming Rot (Talaris) — Paid in organic matter and corpses for composting
  • Ossathar (Vortegas) — Paid in bone artifacts and historical records

House Morrow manages all tribute negotiations. The amounts are carefully calibrated — enough to seem respectful, not enough to seem prosperous enough to conquer.

The Secret: The tribute amounts don't actually match what Morrow tells the Council. Aldric has been skimming for decades. If any Sovereign compared notes with the Council's records, the discrepancy would be obvious.

Economy

Crownfall's economy runs on three pillars:

1. Trade Arbitrage Goods illegal in one Sovereign territory are legal in another. Crownfall sits at the junction where everything can be exchanged. A merchant can buy Church-banned texts from Ossathar, sell them to a collector from Veinspire, and neither transaction violates local law — because Crownfall has no law against it. 2. Services Banking (Carran), mercenary contracts (Varn), expedition outfitting (Selvik), information (Quellan), and a dozen other services that require neutral ground. People come to Crownfall to do business that can't happen elsewhere. 3. Unclaimed Salvage The deep Unclaimed contains relics, resources, and secrets. Expeditions launch from Crownfall, and the salvage flows back through Crownfall markets. House Selvik and House Keth both profit enormously. Currency: Crownfall accepts all currencies but has its own: Crownfall Silvers (called "Crowns" or "Falls" depending on the speaker). House Carran mints them. They're trusted specifically because they're not tied to any Sovereign — neutral money for neutral ground.

Notable Locations

The Coinhall Council chambers at city center. Neutral ground. A circular building with ten doors (one for each house) and no windows. What happens inside stays inside. The Docent's Archive The city's greatest library, maintained by a figure known only as The Docent. Neutral ground by ancient tradition. Contains records of every major deal, dispute, and decision in Crownfall's history — and much older things besides. The Three Roads The major avenues leading to the three Sovereign territories. Valdris controls checkpoints on each, monitoring (but not restricting) traffic. The Exchange Crownfall's central market complex, sprawling across multiple blocks near the Coinhall. Operates on house-neutral ground by Council agreement. Anything can be sold here. Anything. The Threshold Thane-controlled cemetery and crematorium district in the northern Edges. Where the dead are processed to ensure they stay dead. The Velvet Thorn Most prestigious inn/tavern in Crownfall. Drennan-owned. Where serious people conduct serious business. The upper floors host services not discussed in polite company. The Silken Refuge Brothel and safehouse in the Sprawl, near the southern Edges. Run by Madame Veshra Coil. Known for buying slaves and freeing them. The workers stay by choice. The Kennels The entire eastern Edge district. Where expeditions outfit, where relic hunters drink, where the desperate and the ambitious mix. Selvik territory, loosely.

Threats & Tensions

External:
  • Sovereign Interest — Any of the three nearby Sovereigns could decide Crownfall is worth the cost. The tribute keeps them disinterested, but that could change.
  • Church of Radiant Blood — Mareatha's church has agents in the city, watching for heresy and opportunity.
  • The Deep Unclaimed — Something is stirring in the eastern zones. Expeditions have been reporting wrongness. Selvik knows more than she's saying.
Internal:
  • Sera Valdris is dying — The Gatekeeper's slow decline will trigger a succession crisis. Her nephew Cael is competent but perceived as weak.
  • Morrow's skimming — If discovered, it could collapse the tribute arrangement and invite Sovereign intervention.
  • Keth's project — Yenra is building something in her basement. No one knows what.
  • Forbidden love — Brix Drennan and Cael Valdris are secretly involved. If their families find out, it could mean alliance or war.
  • Thane's secret — The cemetery district is built over something that requires constant containment. If the death rites ever stop...

Story Hooks

  • The party needs something that can only be obtained through Crownfall's grey market
  • Someone important is hiding in Crownfall under a false identity
  • A house hires the party for a job against another house — deniable, dangerous, lucrative
  • An expedition into the Unclaimed needs capable guards
  • The tribute payment is threatened and someone needs to fix it quietly
  • One of the house heads wants the party to investigate a rival
  • Seraphine Vale and Vela Thorne arrive seeking refuge

— Party Visit

Arrival: Day 14 (evening), entered through northern gate Entry Fee: 2 silver each (6 silver total) Lodging: The Velvet Thorn (Coin District, Westring)

Party Activities (Days 15-16)

Jonas:
  • Visited Broma's Forge (Forge Ward) — commissioned shield from Custodian armplate (100gp deposit)
  • Broma reacted with terror to the pulsehammer ("a wound in the shape of a weapon")
  • Visited Garrik Holdt (Westring) — nothing suitable
  • Visited The Green Door (Kennels) — purchased Oathbreaker's End folio (200gp)
Fursen:
  • Visited Thresh's Workshop (Kennels) — received diamond teeth in exchange for reciting the Names
  • Visited The Silken Refuge (Sprawl) — night with Scarlet and Cinder; received Cinder's Scale and open invitation
Sol Raven:
  • Visited The Green Door (Kennels) — purchased Cloak of Protection (280gp)
  • Communed with Velara Ashyn about the passion-seed
  • Gathered intelligence about Seraphine Vale from Velvet Thorn

Intelligence Gathered

Seraphine Vale:
  • Arrived 12 days before party (with Vela Thorne)
  • Stayed 2 nights at the Velvet Thorn
  • Spent a day at the Docent's Archive
  • Left "looking like she'd seen a ghost"
  • Departed through southern gate 10 days before party arrived
  • If she kept moving: dead, in the Bastion, or somewhere between

Locations Established

Location District Contact Purpose
The Velvet Thorn Coin (Westring) Velvet Thorn Lodging, information
Broma's Forge Forge Ward Broma Shield commission
The Green Door Kennels The Dealer Magic items, information
Thresh's Workshop Kennels Thresh Body modification
The Silken Refuge Sprawl Madame Veshra Coil Companionship
The Docent's Archive Coin The Docent Next destination

Pending Business

Item Status
Custodian Shield In progress (2 weeks - 2 months)
Visit Docent's Archive Next session objective

Crownfall.title: The Silken Refuge
Crownfall.content:
The Silken Refuge

Type: Brothel / Safehouse Location: The Sprawl, Crownfall (near the border with The Spillway) Owner: Madame Veshra Coil Affiliation: Independent — deliberately unaligned with any House

Overview

The Silken Refuge is exactly what its name suggests — a place of comfort for those seeking it, and sanctuary for those who work there. From the outside, it's a well-maintained three-story building of dark timber and amber-lit windows, unremarkable among the Sprawl's many establishments. Inside, it's one of the few truly safe places in a city built on deals and compromises.

What makes the Refuge different isn't the quality of its services — though those are excellent — but its staff. Every worker is a former slave purchased and freed by Madame Veshra. They stay because they want to, leave when they choose, and are protected with a ferocity that has earned the Refuge a reputation even House Varn's mercenaries respect.

The Refuge caters to all tastes and all species. In a city where refugees from every Sovereign domain mix with native Unclaimed folk, exiled nobles, and desperate fortune-seekers, the Refuge reflects that diversity. Its workers are elves and half-orcs, tieflings and halflings, humans from a dozen different origins, and stranger things besides.

Madame Veshra Coil

Race: Human | Age: 52 | Role: Owner, Protector, Mother Figure

A human woman in her fifties who has aged into iron rather than frailty. Rose from a cheap brothel in the Kennels to owning the most respected establishment in The Sprawl through sheer will and cunning. Now she buys slaves just to free them, and protects everyone under her roof with a ferocity that even House Varn respects.

See Veshra Coil for full details.

The Staff

Old Nara (Dwarf)

Description Dwarven woman in her eighties — middle-aged by dwarven standards, ancient by human reckoning. Broad, weathered, fiery red hair streaked with iron grey, bright blue eyes that have seen everything, intricate braids with copper beads from her lost clan. Was enslaved when her hold fell to Vortegas's expansion. Has been with Veshra for twenty-five years. Runs the kitchen now but still has "regulars" who've been coming for decades. Personality: Sharp-tongued, warm-hearted, makes the best stew in the Sprawl. Grandmother to the whole house. Will hit you with a ladle if you disrespect anyone under this roof.

The Workers

Tessa (Human)

Human woman in her late twenties, fair skin dusted with freckles, warm auburn hair in loose waves, bright green eyes full of genuine warmth, soft features with an easy smile. Former pleasure slave to a Veinspire merchant — escaped during a trade dispute. The Madam found her starving at the North Gate. Now she's the first face newcomers see, and she makes sure it's a kind one.

Warm, playful, genuinely enjoys her work now that it's her choice. The "welcome" for nervous first-timers. Has a gift for making people feel at ease.

Scarlet (Tiefling)

Tiefling woman in her late twenties, dusky skin with a warm undertone, small curved horns half-hidden in a wild mane of dark curly hair, striking amber-gold eyes that glow faintly in dim light, sharp canines visible when she grins — which is often. Confident, sensual, knows exactly the effect she has on people and enjoys it. Was a "pet" to a wealthy collector who liked exotic things. When Veshra bought her contract, Scarlet asked if she could stay and work. She likes the work. She likes choosing.

Bold, playful, teasing. The one who makes clients blush before they even reach a room. Wears red exclusively. Has never met a boundary she couldn't push — but respects "no" absolutely.

Roslyn (Human)

Human woman in her early thirties, fair skin, dark curly hair pinned up in artful disarray, warm hazel eyes, soft knowing smile. Curves poured into a burgundy corset she clearly enjoys wearing. Former house slave to a minor Crownfall family — not one of the Ten, but wealthy enough to be cruel. Veshra bought out her contract when the family fell into debt. She's been here five years and has no intention of leaving.

Warm, experienced, maternal in an unexpected way. The one nervous clients end up confiding in. Makes everyone feel like they're her favorite. Probably because, in that moment, they are.

Runa (Goliath)

Goliath woman in her early thirties, pale grey skin with darker grey markings like natural tattoos across her shoulders and arms, powerfully muscular build that towers over most clients, dark hair pulled back in a practical braid, intense pale eyes that assess every threat. Jaw-droppingly strong — her abs alone have inspired poetry. Former pit fighter in the Ossuary Kingdom — bought by Veshra after she killed her owner in the ring. Still learning that strength can protect instead of just destroy.

Fierce, protective, speaks little. Handles security more than clients, but has regulars who appreciate her particular intensity. Wears leather and not much else — she earned this body, she'll show it.

Whisper (Changeling)

Changeling of uncertain age, currently presenting as a beautiful pale-skinned woman with silver-white hair, but their features shift subtly — eye color drifting, bone structure adjusting to client preference. Was kept by a Blackfold noble as a "mirror" — forced to wear faces of the noble's dead lovers. Doesn't have a fixed appearance anymore, but is learning to choose forms for themselves.

Quiet, observant, still figuring out who they are when not reflecting someone else's desires. Veshra is helping them discover preferences.

Ember (Tiefling)

Young tiefling woman in her early twenties, pale lavender skin, small delicate horns she used to file down, thin tail she's learning not to hide, eyes of soft pink. Born into slavery, sold to a Bastion of Fireblood cult for "purification rituals." Veshra killed the buyer personally to get her out. Still flinches at flames but is getting better.

Sweet, shy, the little sister everyone protects. Only takes clients she chooses, mostly companionship rather than anything physical. Learning that she's allowed to have boundaries.

Silhouette (Shadar-kai / Shadow Elf)

Shadar-kai woman of indeterminate age, ash-grey skin, eyes of pure black that reflect nothing, stark white hair cropped short, ritual scars in geometric patterns across her visible skin. From somewhere in the Blackfold before it was Ultharion's — she doesn't speak of it. Arrived at the Refuge bleeding and hasn't left. Draws clients who want something darker, stranger.

Quiet, intense, melancholy. Finds something like peace here. Her room is always cold.

Juniper (Halfling)

Halfling woman in her thirties, barely four feet tall, round friendly face with dimples, curly chestnut hair always escaping its pins, large warm brown eyes. Was a house slave in Crownfall itself — House Keth, specifically. Veshra bought her freedom as a pointed message to Yenra Keth. Sunny disposition hides a surprising ruthlessness regarding her former owners.

Cheerful, chatty, everyone's friend. Hears everything, remembers everything, tells Veshra everything. Far more dangerous than she looks.

Sorrow (Grief-Born)

Not born but manifested — crystallized from a mother's grief when her children were sold away. Appears as a woman whose skin is pale blue-grey crystal with visible depth, tears permanently frozen on her cheeks like gems, hair of fine glass threads that chime when she moves. Veshra found her wandering, not understanding what she was. Gave her a name, a room, a purpose.

Speaks little, feels much. Clients who visit her often leave having cried for the first time in years. She absorbs sorrow and gives back peace. It's not conventional work, but it's needed.

Veyla (Aasimar)

Aasimar woman in her twenties, luminous pale skin that glows faintly, silver-gold hair that moves slightly without wind, eyes of liquid gold. Divine-touched in a world where the divine is dead or corrupted. Was kept as a "holy relic" by a Mareathan cult, displayed and worshipped and never allowed to be a person. Veshra got her out through channels she doesn't discuss.

Still learning that she's allowed to want things. Her beauty makes people uncomfortable — it feels like looking at something holy in a very unholy establishment. She's slowly embracing the contradiction.

Lirael (Elf)

Elven woman who appears to be in her late twenties but is closer to three hundred, pale ivory skin, angular features that would be cold if not for the warmth in her faded violet eyes, long silver-white hair worn loose, pointed ears adorned with simple silver cuffs. Was a court musician in a minor noble house before the family sold her to cover debts. Three centuries of life and she ended up property. Veshra bought her at auction and asked what she wanted to do with her freedom. She chose to stay.

Melancholy grace, speaks softly, plays the harp in the common room some evenings. Clients who want conversation more than anything else seek her out. Has seen too much to be shocked by anything.

Vex (Drow / Dark Elf)

Drow woman in her apparent thirties, obsidian-dark skin, stark white hair cropped short and practical, eyes of pale lavender that glow faintly in darkness, sharp angular features. Fled the underdark politics of her people, was captured by surface slavers who thought an exotic dark elf would fetch a premium. She did. Veshra outbid everyone. Now she handles clients who want something dangerous, and she enjoys reminding surface-dwellers that she's not as tame as they assume.

Sharp, sardonic, takes no shit. Enjoys making clients nervous. Fiercely loyal to Veshra for treating her like a person instead of a curiosity.

Cinder (Dragonborn)

Dragonborn woman with scales of deep burnished copper that catch firelight beautifully, amber eyes with slit pupils, small horns swept back from her skull, a powerful but feminine build. Was bred for pit fighting — dragonborn fetch high prices in the arena circuit. Won thirty-two matches before Veshra bought her contract. Chose to stay because she'd never had a soft bed or a choice before. Takes clients who want strength, and those who just want to touch her scales.

Quiet dignity, moves with controlled power, surprisingly gentle. Still not used to being treated well. Cries sometimes when clients are kind to her, which embarrasses her.

Marrow (Dhampir)

Dhampir woman in her apparent late twenties though likely much older, deathly pale skin that never sees sun, dark hair with a sharp widow's peak, eyes of pale red like diluted blood, elongated canines visible when she smiles, gaunt sharp features of predatory beauty. Half-vampire, never fully accepted by either world. Was kept by a Veinspire blood cult as a "sacred vessel" — they fed from her, believing her mixed blood had holy properties. Veshra got her out. She doesn't talk about how.

Darkly sensual, gallows humor, surprisingly kind beneath the predator aesthetic. Some clients want the danger. She gives them just enough to thrill without harm. Feeds only on willing donors now — the Refuge has arrangements.

Shale (Lizardfolk)

Lizardfolk woman with scales of mottled green and brown, large amber eyes with horizontal pupils, a crest of softer scales along her head in lieu of hair, long tail she uses expressively, clawed hands she's learned to use gently. Was captured from her swamp tribe and sold as an exotic curiosity. Doesn't fully understand mammalian concepts of affection but is learning. Some clients find her alienness fascinating. She finds mammals equally strange but has grown fond of them.

Blunt, practical, doesn't understand euphemisms. Surprisingly warm once you understand her. Tilts her head like a curious bird when confused. Has learned to enjoy physical warmth — her room is always heated.

Ssyllia (Yuan-Ti Pureblood)

Yuan-ti pureblood woman, almost human-looking at first glance — pale skin with a faint greenish undertone, beautiful features with something subtly wrong about the proportions, eyes of solid amber with slit pupils, forked tongue she's learned to hide. Patches of fine scales visible at her temples and along her spine. Was an assassin for her people before she failed a mission and was sold rather than executed. Veshra bought her knowing exactly what she was. Ssyllia has never been trusted before. It's... strange.

Cold, calculating, slowly thawing. Speaks in a slight hiss she can't fully suppress. Genuinely confused by the concept of loyalty earned rather than demanded. Watches Veshra like she's solving a puzzle.

Raven (Drow / Dark Elf)

Drow man in his apparent forties, obsidian-dark skin, long white hair worn loose past his shoulders, eyes of deep crimson that smolder in low light, sharp aristocratic features, lean muscular build. Was a minor noble in the underdark before a house war left him the sole survivor — and a valuable commodity. Sold to the surface as a curiosity, passed between owners who wanted to own something beautiful and dangerous. Veshra was the first to ask his name. He gave her a false one. She knew and didn't press. He's been here three years and still hasn't told anyone his real name.

Cultured, guarded, watches everything. Speaks softly with impeccable manners that feel like armor. Takes clients who want refinement — conversation, wine, the illusion of courtship. Lets very few past his walls. Those who do find someone desperately lonely.

Callum (Human)

Human man in his late twenties, fair skin with a scattering of freckles, tousled copper-brown hair, warm green eyes, easy smile that comes readily. Handsome in a boyish, approachable way rather than intimidatingly beautiful. Was a debt-slave — his father's gambling debts passed to him when the old man died. Worked as a laborer until a wealthy merchant bought his contract for "personal service." When the merchant tried to sell him on, Veshra intervened. He's genuinely happy here — good pay, good company, and work he doesn't mind.

Charming, easygoing, good listener. The "safe" choice for clients who are nervous or new. Makes everyone feel comfortable. Flirts shamelessly but kindly. Has become something of a little brother to the other workers despite being grown.

House Rules

Posted near the entrance, enforced without exception:

  1. No means no. Always. Immediately. Without question.
  2. What happens here stays here. We don't know your name if you don't want us to.
  3. Weapons stay at the door. The staff are protection enough.
  4. Payment before service. House Carran notes accepted.
  5. Harm a worker, lose a hand. This is not metaphorical.
  6. Species is not a curiosity. Everyone here is a person first.
  7. The Madam's word is final. Appeal to the Council if you dare.

Services & Prices

Companionship (conversation, drinks, company): 5 silvers/hour Standard Services: 20-50 silvers depending on worker and request Specialty Services: Negotiated individually Overnight: 100+ silvers "Just talk to Sorrow": Pay what you feel it was worth Workers keep 70% of their earnings. The house takes 30% for room, board, and protection.

Reputation

Common Knowledge:
  • The Silken Refuge is one of the safer establishments in the Sprawl
  • The Madam rose from courtesan to owner through sheer will and cunning
  • Don't cause trouble there unless you want trouble back
  • They cater to all species and most tastes
  • The workers seem... happy? Genuinely?
Known to Those Who Ask:
  • Madame Veshra has killed at least three people who hurt her workers
  • House Varn tried to muscle her once. They don't talk about what happened.
  • She buys slaves just to free them — House Keth hates her for it
  • She trades information with House Quellan
  • Some workers are things that aren't quite mortal

— Fursen's Visit

Day 15-16, Night

Fursen came seeking companionship after the loss of his wisdom teeth to the Hollow Crawler and the weight of being the last Leonin. Tessa greeted him at the door.

His Choices: Scarlet (tiefling, bold, playful) and Cinder (dragonborn, copper scales, intense). Cost: 150 silver for the full night with both.

The Night

Fire meeting fire.

Scarlet — dusky skin, dark curls, amber eyes, horns curved back — teased him, made him work for every touch. Her tail traced patterns on his thigh. She pinned his wrists and showed him what tiefling boldness meant.

Cinder — copper scales like burnished metal, amber slit-pupil eyes, quiet power — was the counterpoint. Slow. Deliberate. Her scales ran furnace-hot against his fur. She held him from behind while Scarlet worked, stronger than she looked, pressing heat into his spine.

Between them, Fursen forgot.

Forgot the names burning in his skull. Forgot the teeth the Crawler took. Forgot that he's the last of his kind. For one night, he was just a body — fur and muscle and breath — held between two people who knew exactly what they were doing.

The Morning

Fursen stayed for breakfast. Unusual — most clients leave before dawn.

Scarlet stole food from his plate, grinning around a mouthful of bread.

Cinder's foot pressed against his thigh under the table — steady warmth.

They talked. Actually talked. About grief. About presence. About why Fursen was "actually here" unlike most clients who pretend it means nothing.

"You carry something. I don't know what. But you're not hiding from it — you're just... taking a breath."

— Scarlet

Afternoon

Fursen paid for an extended stay. The second session was slower. Exploratory.

Scarlet mapped every inch of him. Pinned him again, used teeth and mouth with deliberate care. Cinder held him from behind, scales furnace-hot, worked with Scarlet in practiced rhythm.

By evening, they were tangled on the floor by dying embers — Scarlet draped across his chest tracing patterns in his fur, Cinder's foot pressed against his thigh.

The Parting

Scarlet: "Diamond teeth and claws. I'm keeping you."

"If you survive whatever you're doing out there... come back. I mean it. Most clients, I forget their faces by morning. I won't forget yours."

Cinder gave Fursen one of her scales — copper, palm-sized, shed naturally. Still warm.

"For luck. And for remembering."

Madame Veshra Coil spoke to Fursen at the bar as he left:

"You treated my girls well. They speak highly of you — and they don't say that about most."

"You're welcome back. Anytime. No payment required — just company and stories."

"A Leonin. I thought your people were gone... I'm glad to see I was wrong."
Crownfall.raw: The Silken Refuge Type: Brothel / Safehouse Location: The Sprawl, Crownfall (near the border with The Spillway) Owner: Madame Veshra Coil Affiliation: Independent — deliberately unaligned with any House Overview The Silken Refuge is exactly what its name suggests — a place of comfort for those seeking it, and sanctuary for those who work there. From the outside, it's a well-maintained three-story building of dark timber and amber-lit windows, unremarkable among the Sprawl's many establishments. Inside, it's one of the few truly safe places in a city built on deals and compromises. What makes the Refuge different isn't the quality of its services — though those are excellent — but its staff. Every worker is a former slave purchased and freed by Madame Veshra. They stay because they want to, leave when they choose, and are protected with a ferocity that has earned the Refuge a reputation even House Varn's mercenaries respect. The Refuge caters to all tastes and all species. In a city where refugees from every Sovereign domain mix with native Unclaimed folk, exiled nobles, and desperate fortune-seekers, the Refuge reflects that diversity. Its workers are elves and half-orcs, tieflings and halflings, humans from a dozen different origins, and stranger things besides. Madame Veshra Coil Race: Human | Age: 52 | Role: Owner, Protector, Mother Figure A human woman in her fifties who has aged into iron rather than frailty. Rose from a cheap brothel in the Kennels to owning the most respected establishment in The Sprawl through sheer will and cunning. Now she buys slaves just to free them, and protects everyone under her roof with a ferocity that even House Varn respects. See Veshra Coil for full details. The Staff Old Nara (Dwarf) Description Dwarven woman in her eighties — middle-aged by dwarven standards, ancient by human reckoning. items.title: Azerach Pact Materials
items.content:
Azerach Pact Materials

Type: Ritual Components | Bearer: Jonas

What They Are

Materials for initiating a warlock pact with Azerach the Whispered King, given to Jonas by Thessaly at the Frayed Codex.

Contents

  • A Book on Azerach Pact Theory — Explains how pacts with the Whispered King work
  • A Scroll with Ritual Instructions — Recorded by one of Azerach's warlocks before he "faded"

The Ritual

According to Thessaly:

The Cost

Warlocks of the Whispered King gain power over silence — the ability to steal words from throats, to move without sound, to hear what was never meant to be heard.

But they fade. Not physically — but socially. People forget they're in the room. Conversations move past them. They become background. Unnoticed. Unremembered.

Thessaly's Warning

items.title: Diamond Teeth
items.content:
Diamond Teeth

Type: Permanent Modification | Bearer: Fursen

What They Are

Two wisdom teeth (lower left) made of diamond, cut to perfect Leonin dentition and anchored directly to the jawbone. Permanent, functional, and capable of biting through leather — maybe thin wood.

Origin

The Hollow Crawler's Consume Feature dissolved two of Fursen's wisdom teeth during the ambush on Day 8. Fursen discovered the loss at dawn and wept — grief for the teeth, for everything taken, for being the last Leonin.

In Crownfall, Fursen visited Thresh — a body modifier in the Kennels District. Thresh asked for payment in story, not gold. Fursen recited names from the 10,000 Names in his blood.

Thresh was moved: "I have never met someone who touched a god and lived."

The service was free in exchange for being remembered. Fursen promised: "I will remember you."

items.title: Oathkeeper
items.content:
Oathkeeper

Oathkeeper

Legendary Weapon — Conviction Made Steel "Forged from two thousand years of conviction, Oathkeeper is less a weapon and more a philosophy given edge." Weapon (greatsword), legendary (requires attunement by a Paladin or similar) Original Wielder: Mira Alethain Current Holder: Seraphine Vale Acquired by Seraphine: — Church of the Merciful Vein

Description

Oathkeeper does not look forged. It looks decided.

The blade is pale steel that seems to glow from within — not brightly, but with a warmth that suggests conviction rather than magic. No runes adorn its surface. No gems decorate its crossguard. The weapon is austere, purposeful, beautiful in its refusal to be anything other than what it is.

The grip is wrapped in leather that has molded itself to hands that held it with certainty. The pommel bears no symbol — only smooth, warm metal that fits perfectly in the palm.

It first manifested the day Mira Alethain chose truth over obedience. The sword did not exist before that moment. Then it did.

History

Origin

Oathkeeper was not forged in a smithy. It was forged in a moment.

Two thousand years of accumulated conviction — the faith of paladins, the certainty of martyrs, the unwavering belief of those who chose truth over survival — crystallized into steel the instant Mira Alethain defied the Church of Mareatha.

She had been an Inquisitor. A hunter of heretics. A perfect instrument of doctrine.

Then she learned the truth about what the Church had done to her husband.

The moment she chose Elias over obedience, the moment she turned her back on everything she had believed, Oathkeeper appeared in her hands. Not given. Not found. Manifested.

The sword recognized something in her choice — a conviction pure enough to deserve an edge.

Mira's Wielder

For thirty years, Mira carried Oathkeeper through exile and pursuit. The blade served her faithfully, burning bright against the servants of the Church that had betrayed her., Mira Alethain was consumed by Savaros the High Keeper. Her flesh was stripped. Her bones were left behind.

Oathkeeper fell beside her skeleton, its glow flickering and dying.

Transition

Sol Raven recovered the blade after Mira's death. When his skeletal fingers touched the grip, Oathkeeper responded — warming, glowing, acknowledging him despite his nature.

But Sol was a sorcerer. A skeleton. He could not wield a greatsword, no matter how much the weapon seemed willing.

He brought Oathkeeper to Seraphine Vale — the broken High Inquisitor whose faith had been shattered by revelations about the Church she served.

Sol offered the blade to her: "I think she would've wanted you to have this."

Seraphine's Wielder

When Seraphine took Oathkeeper, it felt cold in her grasp.

Not the warmth Sol had experienced. Not the acknowledgment. The sword was waiting. Judging. Deciding whether this woman — who had spent her life hunting people like Mira — could ever become worthy of a heretic's conviction.

Seraphine made a promise: "I'll try to be someone worthy of this blade."

Whether she can keep that promise remains to be seen.

The Sword's Judgment

Oathkeeper is not sentient in the traditional sense. It does not speak. It does not scheme. It does not demand.

But it knows.

It knows when a wielder acts from conviction versus convenience. It knows when truth is spoken and when lies are told. It knows when someone is worthy of its edge and when they are simply holding steel.

For Mira: The blade burned bright. Every strike carried thirty years of righteous fury. The sword and the woman were one purpose, one conviction, one truth. For Sol: The blade acknowledged him — perhaps recognizing something in his nature as a fragment-bearer, perhaps simply grateful to be recovered from beside its wielder's bones. For Seraphine: The blade is cold. Waiting. Testing. The inquisitor must prove herself before Oathkeeper will truly serve her.

Mechanical Notes

Damage Breakdown

Source Damage
Base greatsword 2d6 slashing
Enhancement bonus +3
Conviction's Edge 1d8 radiant
Total per hit 2d6 + 3 slashing + 1d8 radiant
Against liars (Truth-Seeker) +2d6 radiant

Attunement Requirements

Oathkeeper requires attunement by a Paladin or similar class — defined as someone whose power derives from conviction, oath, or unwavering belief. This includes:

  • Paladins (any oath)
  • Devotion-based Clerics (DM discretion)
  • Characters with similar narrative conviction (DM discretion)

Seraphine qualifies despite her crisis of faith — the sword is testing whether she can rebuild conviction, not whether she currently possesses it.

Current Status

Holder: Seraphine Vale Location: Church of the Merciful Vein, Veinspire Condition: Cold to Seraphine's touch; waiting to judge her worthiness Attunement: Pending (Seraphine has not yet attuned)

items.title: Seraphine's Letter
items.content:
Seraphine's Letter

Type: Warning Letter | Author: Seraphine Vale

What It Is

A letter left by Seraphine Vale in her quarters at the Church of the Merciful Vein, addressed to the party. She fled Veinspire before they arrived.

Contents

Seraphine witnessed the Confluence — the ritual that "resurrected" Ardian Bloodveil. But Oathkeeper warned her. The sword grew cold like ice when Ardian opened his eyes.

She saw the Cardinal and Ardian share a knowing look that no one else noticed. They know each other.

Seraphine has renounced her faith and fled to "a place where blood does not flow." Her current whereabouts are unknown.

Hidden Evidence

Jonas found additional items hidden in Seraphine's room:

  • A sketch of Ardian on the steps, the Cardinal's shadow behind him — faceless, tall, wrong
  • A requisition order with the Cardinal's seal: specimens R-7, R-13, R-22 taken from Reliquary vaults, dated 2 weeks before the Confluence
  • A scratched message on the wardrobe floor: "If I die, know that I tried. —S.V."

items.title: Soul Anchor Amulet
items.content:
Soul Anchor Amulet

Type: Pre-Usurpation Artifact | Bearer: Sol Raven (Velara's soul within)

What It Is

A dull metal amulet, tarnished green, pulsing with a steady heartbeat rhythm. When Jonas lifted it from the mummified corpse in the Bone Field wagon, the corpse's hand grabbed his wrist with iron grip and whispered: "...don't... take it... to... her..."

The amulet is a soul anchor — pre-Usurpation containment magic. It doesn't preserve flesh — it preserves self. The pulse is a prison rhythm.

Velara Ashyn

The soul trapped within is Velara Ashyn — former consort of Kaedris the Crimson Matron. 500 years ago, she stole the passion-seed and fled. The caravan she hired was killed by something Kaedris sent — a burning woman who walked with feet that left glass in the dirt.

Velara's soul was trapped in the amulet for centuries, aware, watching the caravan rot around her. She has asked the party to take her to the Docent's Archive in Crownfall.

Properties

When Jonas tried to examine the amulet (Arcana 1), it flared cold, whited out his vision, gave him a nosebleed, and knocked him to one knee. The amulet rejected examination.

Sol's communion revealed Velara recognizes that Sol isn't alive but isn't empty — "...there's something inside you too..."

items.title: The Bleeding Blade
items.content:
The Bleeding Blade

Weapon (longsword), legendary (requires attunement) Current Holder: Jonas Location Found: Catacomb Reliquary, Veinspire

Description

A longsword of dark iron — not black, but the deep red-brown of dried blood. Veins run through the metal itself, hairline fractures that pulse faintly with crimson light. Like arteries. Like the sword is alive.

The crossguard is shaped like two hands pressed together in prayer, wrists opened, blood flowing down to form the grip. The pommel is a clot — a hardened sphere of something that might be ruby, might be crystallized blood.

It's beautiful. It's obscene.

Curse — The Vein-Mother's Thirst

Daily Hunger: If you finish a long rest without having dealt damage to a living creature with the Bleeding Blade since your last long rest, you take 2d10 necrotic damage that cannot be healed until you feed the blade. Death's Pull: While attuned, you have disadvantage on death saving throws. Your blood wants to leave your body. Bound: The blade cannot be unequipped willingly. Breaking attunement requires Remove Curse cast at 7th level or higher, or Mareatha's direct intervention.

Dormant Sentience

The Bleeding Blade contains an echo of something — not quite sentient, but aware.

  • It pulses when near large amounts of blood
  • It grows warm in battle
  • It grows cold when sheathed for too long
It remembers Mira. It felt her die.

The blade was in the Catacomb Reliquary when Savaros consumed Mira Alethain. It experienced her death. Whether this has changed the blade in some way remains to be seen.

History

The Bleeding Blade is one of Mareatha's oldest relics — created in the early days after the Usurpation when the Vein-Mother's faithful were still learning what divine blood could do.

It was kept in the Catacomb Reliquary for centuries, displayed at the altar as a symbol of sacrifice and devotion. Savaros the High Keeper guarded it — though he served Ultharion, not Mareatha.

Jonas took the blade from the altar after Savaros's defeat. It bit him for 5 necrotic damage as introduction — a small tithe to establish the bond.

Connection to Mareatha

The blade is infused with the Vein-Mother's essence. While attuned:

  • Servants of Mareatha may recognize the blade's signature
  • The blade may react in proximity to Mareathan holy sites
  • Mareatha herself could theoretically sense the blade if she chose to pay attention

Whether Mareatha would approve of an enemy of her Church wielding her relic... is another question.

Veins run through the metal itself, hairline fractures that pulse faintly with crimson light. Like arteries. Like the sword is alive. The crossguard is shaped like two hands pressed together in prayer, wrists opened, blood flowing down to form the grip. The pommel is a clot — a hardened sphere of something that might be ruby, might be crystallized blood. It's beautiful. It's obscene. Breaking attunement requires Remove Curse cast at 7th level or higher, or Mareatha's direct intervention. items.title: The Passion-Seed
items.content:
The Passion-Seed

Type: Divine Fragment | Bearer: Jonas

What It Is

A black stone darker than obsidian, warm to the touch, that seems to deny light around it. It pulses with heat that resonates with intense emotion.

This is the original passion-seed — a fragment of concentrated passion crystallized from Aedwynn's heart. Kaedris cut this from the Maker's heart with her own hands.

Danger

According to Velara Ashyn:

  • Kaedris found a way to grow more passion-seeds
  • One seed can ignite a city
  • A hundred could burn the world
  • Without the original, the others are just echoes
  • With it, Kaedris could finish what she started

Properties

The passion-seed resonated with the Bleeding Blade when Jonas found both in the Bone Field wagon.

Warning from Velara: "Don't feel strongly near it. It responds to emotion, amplifies it."

Velara's Attempts

Velara tried to destroy it once. Fire, blade, magic — nothing works. It's a piece of a god's heart. It cannot be unmade by conventional means. She considered throwing it into the Void zones but feared Kaedris might still find it.

The Docent might know how to unmake something that can't be unmade.

items.title: The Remembrance Seal
items.content:
The Remembrance Seal

Type: Protective Artifact | Bearer: Sol Raven

What It Is

A pendant of black iron, cold to the touch. It grants its bearer advantage on saving throws against memory alteration effects. Inside the seal is a preserved memory — the final memory of its previous owner.

How It Was Found

In the bile pools of Vor'Kael's Throat, Sol found a skeleton — a woman who had almost escaped the Hollow Empress's domain 800 years ago. She was dissolving inches from freedom when she died. Around her neck was the Remembrance Seal.

Sol retrieved it from her remains and now carries her memory forward.

The Final Memory

The seal contains the woman's last moments — her desperate crawl through the bile, the burning as her flesh dissolved, the sight of freedom just out of reach. She wore the seal to remember who she was as Vor'Kael tried to consume her meaning. She almost made it.

The Resonant Codex (Transformed)

The Resonant Codex

Transformed by Loss "The book likes you. I can feel it. Something about what you carry — the Witness thing. It resonates." — Kael's final entry Wondrous Item, rare (requires attunement) Current Holder: Sol Raven Original Holder: Kael (deceased) Transformed: — Catacomb Reliquary

Description

A leather-bound tome of unusual weight. The cover is embossed with symbols that shift when not observed directly. The pages reorganize themselves based on the reader's needs, bringing relevant information forward.

The pages are blood-stained — Kael's blood, from when Savaros consumed him.

History

Original Acquisition

The party stole the Resonant Codex from the Veinspire church archives at the request of the Resonance Theorists. Kael became its primary user, studying its contents about pre-Sovereign resonance theory.

Kael's Use

Throughout Sessions 3-18, Kael consulted the Codex regularly. It responded to his nature as an ontological anomaly — a concept that refused dissolution. The book and Kael developed a connection.

Transformation

When Savaros consumed Kael in the Catacomb Reliquary, his blood soaked the Codex's pages. Sol Raven retrieved the book from beside Kael's skeleton.

When Sol touched it, he experienced a vision of Kael's journey — consumption by Vor'Kael, resistance, expulsion. The pressure of a god trying to digest him.

The Codex transformed. It now responds to Sol's nature as the Maker's Witness.

Properties

Base Properties (Unchanged)

  • Contains resonance theory and pre-Sovereign knowledge
  • Pages reorganize based on reader's needs
  • Detects ontological anomalies (proximity sensing)
  • Can identify beings that "shouldn't exist"

New Properties (Post-Transformation)

Witness Resonance: Sol's Witness visions are automatically recorded in the Codex. When he accesses the Maker's memory or experiences divine revelation, the book writes it down — preserving the knowledge even if Sol forgets. Kael's Echo (1/Long Rest): Sol can ask a question about identity, existence, or self. The book answers in Kael's voice.

Kael's Echo

This is not Kael's soul or consciousness. It is an echo — an impression left in the Codex by a concept that refused to dissolve.

When Sol asks a question:
  • The answer comes in Kael's voice
  • Always honest
  • Often uncertain
  • Occasionally profound
  • Sometimes asks questions back
Limitations:
  • Can only answer questions about identity, existence, or self
  • Does not know current events (stuck in a permanent present)
  • Does not know Kael is dead
  • Cannot take actions or provide tactical information
  • Is not aware of conversations it isn't directly asked into
Sample Interactions:

Sol: "Kael, what does it mean to be real?"

Echo: "I think... it means someone remembers you. It means you left a mark. It means something changed because you existed. Does that count? I hope that counts."

Sol: "Do you remember dying?"

Echo: "Dying? I don't... no. Why would I remember that? Sol, is something wrong?"

Kael's Final Entry

Found when Sol first opened the transformed Codex:

"If you're reading this, I'm probably dead. The codex knows things I don't. Sol — if it's you — I'm sorry I couldn't be more useful. I'm sorry I didn't understand what I was in time to matter. But you called me real. You said I was making choices NOW. That it mattered. I hope you were right.

— Kael

P.S. — The book likes you. I can feel it. Something about what you carry — the Witness thing. It resonates. Take care of it. Take care of them."

Connection to the Witness

The Codex and Sol's Witness abilities have formed a symbiotic relationship:

  • Sol's visions are recorded automatically
  • The Codex organizes divine knowledge for easier access
  • Kael's echo may have insights about Sol's nature as a "wrong thought"
  • Both Sol and the Codex carry pieces of beings that shouldn't exist

items.title: Aedwynn the Maker
items.content:
Aedwynn the Maker

Status: Deceased (Murdered during the Usurpation)

Who She Was

Aedwynn the Maker was the god who created the world. She shaped reality, breathed life into existence, and maintained the balance of all things. She was not distant or unknowable — she walked among her creations, crafting and caring for the world she made.

Thirteen of her trusted servants betrayed her. They killed her and divided her body among themselves, becoming the Sovereigns who rule the world today.

Her Legacy

Aedwynn is not entirely gone. Fragments of her divine essence survived:

  • Her preserved body lies in the Chamber of the Final Breath, discovered by the party in
  • Divine shards embedded themselves in certain mortals (the Aedwynn-Born)
  • Sol Raven carries one such shard, animating his skeletal form
  • Ancient facilities built by the Maker still respond to those who carry her essence

The Witness

In the Chamber of the Final Breath, the party found a white-barked tree with veins of gold rising from the stone. At its base sat Aedwynn's preserved body — a shell containing an echo of her consciousness, uploaded onto this puppet made from the tree. When the party touched her, she awakened. She recognized Sol as carrying a piece of herself, and gave him the role of Witness — her heir, carrying her memory forward into an age ruled by her murderers.

Sol can now access complete memories of the world before the Usurpation. He showed one such memory to Talaris Bloomrend — the first time the Verdant King had seen his creator since helping to kill her.

items.title: The Usurpation
items.content:
The Usurpation

Type: Historical Event — The Murder of Aedwynn the Maker

What Happened

Before the current age, there was one god: Aedwynn the Maker. She created the world, shaped life, and maintained reality. Thirteen of her most trusted servants conspired to kill her.

They murdered Aedwynn and divided her body among themselves. Each claimed an organ, a piece of divine power. They became the Thirteen Sovereigns — gods built from the corpse of their creator.

  • Mareatha took the Heart
  • Azerach took the Ears
  • Imhuran took the Eyes
  • Talaris took the Liver
  • Vor'Kael took the Stomach
  • Eredain took the Voice
  • Karthayne took the Heart of Creation
  • Ultharion took the Skin
  • ...and five others claimed the remaining organs

The World Now

The Sovereigns rule their domains absolutely. Each has reshaped their territory according to their nature. Their cults enforce worship. Their agents hunt those who remember what came before.

But fragments of Aedwynn survived. Divine shards embedded in mortals. Echoes of the Maker's power hiding in ancient places. And now Sol Raven — the Maker's Witness — carries her memory forward.

items.title: Vor'Kael's True Name
items.content:
Vor'Kael's True Name

Type: Ultimate Leverage | Bearer: Jonas

What It Is

Vor'Kael's true name — the name she had before the Usurpation, before she became the Hollow Empress, before she claimed the Maker's Stomach. A secret that Azerach the Whispered King kept hidden for 800 years.

How It Was Found

In Lastwell, Jonas purchased a Closed Locket from a smith who didn't know what he had. The locket was sealed with strong magic. When Jonas touched it, his brand flared cold and Azerach opened it, revealing Vor'Kael's name etched inside.

Azerach had kept this secret for eight centuries — leverage against a fellow Sovereign. Now Jonas holds it.

The Cost

At the Mouth of the World, Vor'Kael sensed Jonas held the name but he did not speak it. Later, Jonas spoke the name aloud once — to command passage from the Satiated One. The Hollow Empress felt her true name spoken. She cannot unhear it.

Vor'Kael will hunt Jonas forever.

The Power

Vor'Kael's true name grants power over her. The exact nature of this power is unclear, but it is enough that Azerach kept it secret for 800 years, and enough that the Satiated One — an entity older than the Sovereigns — recognized its significance.

items.title: Blood Drinkers
items.content:
Blood Drinkers

Overview

Aberrations of the Arterial Tunnels Type: Aberration Domain Association: Mareatha the Vein-Mother Habitat: Arterial Tunnels beneath Veinspire Challenge Rating: 1/2 (100 XP)

Blood drinkers are creatures that feed on Mareatha's seepage in the Arterial Tunnels. They resemble dog-sized leeches—eyeless, mouthless, their skin glistening wet. They don't bite; they absorb. Skin contact means feeding.

Appearance

Physical Description Dog-sized leech-like creatures with eyeless, mouthless bodies. Their skin glistens wet, constantly pulsing with hunger. They hunt by sensing warmth and absorb blood through skin contact rather than biting.
  • Size of large dogs
  • Leech-like body shape
  • Eyeless—hunt by sensing warmth
  • Mouthless—absorb through skin contact
  • Glistening, wet skin
  • Pulsing with hunger

Behavior

Hunting Tactics:
  • Hunt in swarms (11+ typical)
  • Emerge from organic walls of Arterial Tunnels
  • Ambush predators—hide within walls until prey passes
  • Attack from multiple directions (walls, ceiling, floor)
  • Target isolated or wounded individuals first
Instincts:
  • Avoid fire—vulnerable to flames
  • Will flee if swarm takes heavy casualties
  • Cannot survive outside Arterial Tunnels for long—need Mareatha's seepage

Combat

STR DEX CON INT WIS CHA
8 (-1) 14 (+2) 14 (+2) 2 (-4) 10 (+0) 2 (-4)
Skills Stealth +4 Damage Vulnerabilities Fire Condition Immunities Blinded, Charmed, Deafened Senses Blindsight 60 ft., passive Perception 10 Languages — Challenge 1/2 (100 XP) Blood Sense. Can detect warm-blooded creatures within 60 feet. Wall Crawler. Can climb difficult surfaces, including ceilings, without ability checks.

Actions

Absorbing Touch. Melee Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 7 (2d4 + 2) necrotic damage. Target's maximum HP reduced by damage taken until long rest. Blood drinker regains HP equal to damage dealt. Latch On (Recharge 5-6). If Absorbing Touch hits, blood drinker attaches to target. While attached, target takes 7 (2d4 + 2) necrotic damage at start of each of its turns. Blood drinker moves with target. Detaching requires action and DC 12 Strength check.

Ecology

Blood drinkers are spawned from Mareatha's influence in the Arterial Tunnels. They feed on the residual divine blood that seeps through the walls, but prefer warm-blooded prey when available.

Weaknesses:
  • Vulnerable to fire (take double damage)
  • Flee from large flames
  • Cannot survive outside Arterial Tunnels for long—need Mareatha's seepage

Key Moments

Party Encounter — Arterial Tunnels

  • 11 blood drinkers ambushed party in Arterial Tunnels
  • Emerged from walls, ceiling
  • Party killed all 11
  • Casualties: Jonas (32 damage), Fursen (11 damage), Sol (9 damage)
  • Mira healed Jonas and Fursen; Sol regenerated naturally

items.title: Bloom Hound
items.content:
Bloom Hound

Type: Beast Domain Association: The Blooming Rot (Talaris Bloomrend the Verdant King) Habitat: Throughout the Blooming Rot, particularly along the Pilgrim's Path Challenge Rating: 3 (700 XP)

Description

Wolves adapted to the Rot. Fur patchy and matted, skin visible beneath in mottled green-grey. Flowering vines grow from their shoulders and spine, bright blossoms that attract insects — which the hounds eat. Hunt in packs of 3-6. Loyal to territory, not malicious.

Appearance

Physical Description Medium-sized canines with patchy, matted fur in shades of grey-green. Their skin shows through in mottled patches, having taken on the colors of moss and lichen. Flowering vines grow directly from their shoulders and spine, producing bright blossoms in colors ranging from deep crimson to pale violet. A constant cloud of insects hovers around them, attracted to the flowers — the hounds snap these up as supplemental food. Their eyes glow faintly green in low light, reflecting the bioluminescence of their environment.

Behavior

Bloom Hounds are territorial but not inherently aggressive. They patrol established hunting grounds within the Blooming Rot, marking territory with scent and waiting for prey to stumble into their domain.

Pack Dynamics: Hunt in packs of 3-6, with a dominant alpha leading coordinated attacks. They communicate through low growls and body language, flanking prey efficiently. Feeding Habits: Primarily carnivorous, hunting rot hares, smaller creatures, and occasionally unwary pilgrims. The insects attracted by their flower growths provide supplemental nutrition. Territorial Nature: A pack might follow travelers at a distance, curious rather than hostile. Feeding them (a rot hare, for instance) earns safe passage through their territory. Threatening one brings the entire pack. Connection to Talaris: As with all life in the Blooming Rot, Bloom Hounds are connected to Talaris Bloomrend through the fungal network. The Verdant King sees through their eyes when he chooses to look.

Combat

D&D 5e Stat Block

Bloom Hound

Medium beast, unaligned Armor Class 14 (natural armor) Hit Points 39 (6d8 + 12) Speed 50 ft.
STR DEX CON INT WIS CHA
14 (+2) 16 (+3) 14 (+2) 4 (-3) 14 (+2) 6 (-2)
Skills Perception +4, Stealth +5, Survival +4 Senses darkvision 60 ft., passive Perception 14 Languages — Challenge 3 (700 XP) Keen Senses. The bloom hound has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing or smell. Pack Tactics. The bloom hound has advantage on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of the hound's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't incapacitated. Pollen Lure. Insects swarm around the bloom hound's flowering growths. Any creature that starts its turn within 5 feet of the bloom hound must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or be distracted by the swarming insects, having disadvantage on Perception checks until the start of its next turn.

Actions

Bite. Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 10 (2d6 + 3) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a DC 13 Strength saving throw or be knocked prone.

Variants

Bloom Pup (CR 1/2): Young hounds with only budding flower growths. 13 HP, no Pollen Lure ability. Often stay back during hunts, learning from the pack. Elder Bloom Hound (CR 5): An old pack leader whose flower growths have become extensive, covering most of its body. 65 HP, AC 15. Its Pollen Lure extends to 10 feet and the DC increases to 14. Can release a burst of spores once per day that causes creatures within 15 feet to make a DC 14 Constitution save or be poisoned for 1 minute. Fungal Alpha (CR 7): A Bloom Hound that has been blessed by Talaris directly. 85 HP, AC 16. It can communicate telepathically with Talaris and other creatures of the Rot within 60 feet. Once per day, it can summon 1d4 additional Bloom Hounds from the forest.

Ecology

Formation: Bloom Hounds evolved from ordinary wolves that entered the Blooming Rot generations ago. The fungal network slowly integrated with their biology, and now the flower growths are as natural to them as fur. Lifecycle: They reproduce normally, though pups are born with small vine buds that grow as they mature. The pack raises young communally. Relationship to the Verdant King: Talaris views them as useful servants — they patrol his domain and alert him to intruders. In return, they have abundant hunting grounds and protection from larger predators. Symbiosis: The flowers growing from Bloom Hounds are connected to the Rot's greater fungal network. When a Bloom Hound dies, its body is quickly reclaimed by the forest, flowers blooming from the corpse within hours.

Encounter Ideas

  • A pack of Bloom Hounds blocks the Pilgrim's Path. They're not attacking — they're waiting. Something has frightened them from their usual territory.
  • A lone Bloom Hound follows the party, keeping its distance. It seems to be watching them on behalf of something else.
  • The party finds a wounded Bloom Hound caught in a hunter's trap. Freeing it might earn favor with the pack — or with Talaris himself.
  • A pack has cornered a merchant who wandered off the path. The party must decide whether to intervene.

Lore

From a Pilgrim's Account "The hounds watched us for three days. Never attacked, never threatened — just watched. When we reached the Congregation Grove, the Spore-Touched told us the hounds had been reporting our progress. The forest knew exactly where we were the entire time." From a Hunter's Warning "Feed them if you have food to spare. A rot hare buys you safe passage through their territory. But never, ever run from them. They're wolves at heart, and wolves chase prey that runs."
items.raw: Bloom Hound Type: Beast Domain Association: The Blooming Rot (Talaris Bloomrend the Verdant King) Habitat: Throughout the Blooming Rot, particularly along the Pilgrim's Path Challenge Rating: 3 (700 XP) Description Wolves adapted to the Rot. Fur patchy and matted, skin visible beneath in mottled green-grey. Flowering vines grow from their shoulders and spine, bright blossoms that attract insects — which the hounds eat. Hunt in packs of 3-6. Loyal to territory, not malicious. Appearance Physical Description Medium-sized canines with patchy, matted fur in shades of grey-green. Their skin shows through in mottled patches, having taken on the colors of moss and lichen. Flowering vines grow directly from their shoulders and spine, producing bright blossoms in colors ranging from deep crimson to pale violet. A constant cloud of insects hovers around them, attracted to the flowers — the hounds snap these up as supplemental food. Their eyes glow faintly green in low light, reflecting the bioluminescence of their environment. Behavior Bloom Hounds are territorial but not inherently aggressive. They patrol established hunting grounds within the Blooming Rot, marking territory with scent and waiting for prey to stumble into their domain. Pack Dynamics: Hunt in packs of 3-6, with a dominant alpha leading coordinated attacks. They communicate through low growls and body language, flanking prey efficiently. Feeding Habits: Primarily carnivorous, hunting rot hares, smaller creatures, and occasionally unwary pilgrims. The insects attracted by their flower growths provide supplemental nutrition. Territorial Nature: A pack might follow travelers at a distance, curious rather than hostile. Feeding them (a rot hare, for instance) earns safe passage through their territory. Threatening one brings the entire pack. Connection to Talaris: As with all life in the Blooming Rot, Bloom Hounds are connected to Talaris Bloomrend through the fungal network. The Verdant King sees through their eye

items.title: Coagulated Guardians
items.content:
Coagulated Guardians

Description

Coagulated Guardians are living security systems formed from Mareatha's divine blood. They have no permanent form — they exist as part of the arterial walls until intruders are detected, then congeal into humanoid shapes to investigate or contain.

Physical Appearance:
  • Roughly humanoid shape
  • Made entirely of thickened, clotted blood
  • Faceless — smooth ovoid where head should be
  • Too-long limbs that bend without bones
  • Surface ripples with tiny currents
  • Six or seven fingers per hand
Behavior:
  • Patrol through vessel walls (blood is their medium)
  • Respond to Tribunal sigils
  • Query unrecognized bearers for authorization
  • Can split from one large form into multiple smaller forms
  • Communicate through skull-vibration (telepathic speech)

Communication Protocol

When encountering intruders, guardians follow a verification sequence:

  1. Manifest — Congeal from wall to investigate
  2. Scan — Sense blood, divine presence, sigils
  3. Query — Request authorization if sigil recognized but bearer unknown
  4. Respond — Accept authorization or initiate containment
Query Format:

⟨ SIGIL: [STATUS] ⟩

⟨ BEARER: [STATUS] ⟩

⟨ SPECIES: [STATUS/ERROR] ⟩

⟨ QUERY: AUTHORIZATION SOURCE? ⟩

Note: Leonin register as [ERROR] — likely due to Imhuran's erasure of their species from official records.

D&D 5e Statistics

Coagulated Guardian Stat Block

Coagulated Guardian

Medium aberration, neutral evil Armor Class 13 (natural armor) Hit Points 45 (6d8 + 18) Speed 30 ft., climb 30 ft.
STR DEX CON INT WIS CHA
14 (+2) 14 (+2) 16 (+3) 6 (-2) 12 (+1) 5 (-3)
Damage Resistances Bludgeoning, piercing Damage Vulnerabilities Fire, cold Damage Immunities Poison, psychic Condition Immunities Charmed, exhaustion, frightened, poisoned, prone Senses Blindsight 60 ft. (blind beyond this radius), passive Perception 11 Languages Understands Mareathan commands, communicates via telepathic vibration Challenge 2 (450 XP)

Traits

Amorphous. The guardian can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing. Blood Sense. The guardian knows the exact location of any creature with blood within 60 feet of it. Wall Merger. The guardian can enter and move through Mareathan arterial walls as difficult terrain. While merged with a wall, the guardian has total cover and cannot be targeted by attacks or spells. Sigil Recognition. The guardian can identify Tribunal sigils on sight and will not attack bearers unless authorization fails. Divisible Form. When reduced to 0 hit points, the guardian can choose to split into two smaller guardians (22 HP each) instead of dying. Each split guardian has disadvantage on attack rolls. This ability can only be used once per guardian.

Actions

Multiattack. The guardian makes two Coagulating Touch attacks. Coagulating Touch. Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 7 (2d4 + 2) bludgeoning damage plus 3 (1d6) necrotic damage. On a hit, the target must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or have their blood begin to thicken, reducing their speed by 10 feet until the end of their next turn. Engulf (Recharge 5-6). The guardian attempts to engulf a Medium or smaller creature within 5 feet. The target must succeed on a DC 13 Strength saving throw or be grappled (escape DC 13). While grappled, the creature is restrained and takes 10 (3d6) necrotic damage at the start of each of its turns. The guardian can only engulf one creature at a time.

Reactions

Fluid Escape. When the guardian takes damage from a melee attack, it can use its reaction to flow away, moving up to 15 feet without provoking opportunity attacks.

Encounter History

— Arterial Passage

Situation: Party used dead handler's Tribunal sigil to attempt passage. Result: Sigil recognized, but bearer (Fursen/Leonin) flagged as ERROR. Fursen failed Deception check (8) when asked for authorization source. Guardian initiated containment — split into three forms. Combat: Party destroyed all three guardians in one round:
  • Mira bisected Guardian A
  • Sol's Firebolt exploited fire vulnerability on Guardian B
  • Fursen finished Guardian B with Flurry of Blows
  • Jonas destroyed Guardian C with Booming Blade hammer throw
Aftermath: Party sprinted to Reliquary, pursued by reinforcements until arterial valve sealed.

items.title: Corpse Scavenger
items.content:
Corpse Scavenger

Description

Corpse Scavengers are evolution's answer to an impossible food source — the exposed flesh of a dead god. They've adapted over centuries to feed on Aedwynn's divine tissue in the borderlands between Sovereign domains, places where nothing else grows and only carrion remains. They are nature's most efficient cleanup crew, stripping divine flesh with jaws that unhinge like snakes.

They are not undead. They are not touched by corruption. They are simply hungry.

Appearance

Pallid, hairless humanoid-shaped creatures with grey-white skin stretched tight over lean muscle. Their bodies are gaunt, emaciated-looking, but deceptively strong. They have no eyes — just smooth skin where eyes should be. Their ears are enormous, bat-like, constantly twitching. Their mouths are their most disturbing feature — normal-looking when closed, but the jaw can unhinge like a snake's, revealing rows of needle-sharp teeth designed to grip and tear. Their fingers end in black, hardened claws caked with dried divine flesh.

Stats

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
16 (+3)14 (+2)14 (+2)2 (-4)12 (+1)5 (-3)

AC 13 (natural armor) | HP 39 (6d8 + 12) |




Traits

Blind Hunters. The scavenger can't use its blindsight while deafened. It relies entirely on tremorsense and smell to locate prey.

Carrion Sense. The scavenger can smell blood within 120 feet. It has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks to locate wounded creatures.

Pack Tactics. The scavenger has advantage on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of the scavenger's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't incapacitated.

Divine Flesh Diet. The scavenger has adapted to consume the Maker's tissue. It is immune to any corruption or mutation effects from consuming divine flesh.

Actions

Multiattack. The scavenger makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its claws.

Bite. Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 8 (1d10 + 3) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a or take 3 (1d6) necrotic damage as the scavenger's saliva begins breaking down flesh.

Claws. Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d6 + 3) slashing damage.

Unhinged Jaw (Recharge 5-6). The scavenger unhinges its jaw and attempts to tear a chunk from a creature. Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 14 (2d10 + 3) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a or be knocked prone as the scavenger wrenches them off balance.

Encounter Notes

Corpse Scavengers hunt in packs of 4-8, working cooperatively to strip flesh from the Maker's corpse. They are blind but extraordinarily perceptive through tremorsense and smell. One scavenger will draw attention while others flank. The party encountered four of them — Jonas fed the Bleeding Blade.

items.title: Hollow Crawler
items.content:
Hollow Crawler

Medium aberration, unaligned (serves Vor'Kael)

Description

A Hollow Crawler is one of Vor'Kael's scouts — sent to find, track, and mark targets for later consumption. Humanoid shape, but wrong. Too-long fingers. Slides rather than walks. Leaves handprints with impossible proportions. Smells like "absence" or "nothing."

Stats

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
14 (+2)18 (+4)16 (+3)6 (-2)16 (+3)4 (-3)

AC 16 (natural armor) | HP 90 (12d8 + 36) |





Traits

Spider Climb. The crawler can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

Aura of Nothing. Creatures within 10 feet have disadvantage on Perception checks to notice anything other than the crawler.

Vor'Kael's Eyes. When the crawler dies, Vor'Kael immediately becomes aware of its location and the circumstances of its death.

Patient Hunter. Advantage on Stealth checks while tracking prey it has followed for at least 1 hour.

Actions

Multiattack. The crawler makes two claw attacks.

Claw. Melee Weapon Attack: +7 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 11 (2d6 + 4) slashing damage plus 7 (2d6) necrotic damage.

Consume Feature. The crawler targets one creature within 5 feet. or lose a small physical feature (tooth, fingernail, hair). The loss is painless and may go unnoticed. Vor'Kael gains a permanent connection to the creature through the stolen piece.

Encounter Notes

A Hollow Crawler tracked the party for 8 nights after they entered the Unclaimed territories. It circled camps, left handprints, and placed a human tooth with Vor'Kael's mark on Jonas's pack. On Day 8, the party ambushed and killed it — triggering Vor'Kael's Eyes. The Hollow Empress now knows Jonas's exact location.

During the fight, the Crawler's Consume Feature destroyed two of Fursen's wisdom teeth.
