items.title: Misremembered
items.content:
Misremembered

Classification: Conceptual Predator / Ontological Correction Domain Association: Karthayne the Hollow Crown (creation, destruction, authority) First Encounter: — The Northern Ascent (Pallid Crossroads stables) Major Battle: — The Wrong Thought Status: Driven off, will return

ORIGIN

The Misremembered is a function of Karthayne the Hollow Crown—the Sovereign who holds the Maker's Heart of Creation.

When Karthayne claimed the Heart of Creation, he lost his memories—his identity scoured away by an organ meant for a god. To compensate, he began compiling The Cosmic Census: a complete record of every existing thing in the world. If he cannot remember himself, he will remember everything else.

But records reveal gaps. Anomalies. Things that exist but aren't documented. Things that shouldn't exist.

The Misremembered was created to hunt these anomalies. It is Karthayne's correction tool—sent to find things that don't fit the records and erase them from existence. Not kill them. Erase them. As if they never were.

The Misremembered hunts "errors in reality"—beings and concepts that don't fit the pattern of creation Karthayne inherited from Aedwynn. They are corrections. Functions. Tools of a creative authority that cannot tolerate flaws.

CONNECTION TO THE THRONE VOID

The Misremembered retreated to The Throne Void—Karthayne's hidden domain, located off the known map of the Ashen Realms. This is where:

  • Karthayne maintains his Cosmic Census
  • The archives of all existence are kept
  • Anomalies are processed and erased
  • The Misremembered returns to report and regenerate

The Throne Void is where broken and impossible things go—either to be catalogued or unmade.

APPEARANCE

Primary Form:
  • Tall, too tall for normal humanoid proportions
  • Can perfectly mimic living beings (with subtle flaws)
  • Head tilts at predatory angles—suggests broken neck
  • Hollow black spaces where eyes should be
  • Shadows behave incorrectly (turn opposite way, move independently)
  • Can fold like paper and slip through impossible spaces
Voice:
  • Layered whispers
  • Like pages sliding over each other
  • Sound of thought without a mouth
  • Breath escaping a closed book
  • When mimicking, uses stolen voices with underlying discordant whispers

ABILITIES

Form Mimicry:
  • Can create perfect duplicates of living beings
  • Small flaws always present (wrong shadow direction, too-sharp outlines, hollow eyes)
  • Duplicates are conceptual rather than physical
Reality Manipulation:
  • Can freeze objects mid-motion
  • Moves by "jumping" closer without physically crossing space
  • Exists partially outside normal physics
  • Leaves messages carved/written in materials without tools
Conceptual Form:
  • Made of stolen memories and wrong thoughts
  • Resistant to physical damage
  • Can fold along angles that don't exist in three-dimensional space
  • Regenerates unless disrupted by significant force
Correction Touch:
  • Can attempt to unmake beings from existence
  • Victims don't die—they are erased, as if they never existed
  • Those nearby forget the victim existed
Tracking:
  • Hunts conceptual anomalies and ontological errors
  • Can sense "wrong thoughts"—beings that shouldn't exist
  • Patient and methodical, not aggressive
  • Tests boundaries before striking

TARGET: SOL RAVEN

Why Sol?
  • Sol is connected to Aedwynn the Maker—the god who died before Karthayne claimed the Heart
  • Karthayne cannot fully process Aedwynn's legacy—it predates his authority
  • Sol registers as a "wrong thought"—a concept that exists outside proper creation
  • To the Heart of Creation, Sol is a flaw that must be corrected
The Memory Coin Trigger: During the 13-Hour Trial in Imhuran's domain, the party acquired a memory coin—an item that records and triggers remembrance. When the Misremembered encountered the party at the Pallid Crossroads boundary, Fursen offered the coin to the creature. Sol Raven and Kael were present.

The coin made the Misremembered remember Sol. And remembering meant recognizing him as an anomaly. Recognizing meant targeting for erasure.

Without the coin, Sol might have remained unnoticed—just another mortal beneath the attention of cosmic correction. The coin changed everything.

What It Wants: The Misremembered doesn't want to kill Sol. It wants to correct him—unmake him from existence so that he never was. This is worse than death. Current Status: Sol is flagged in Karthayne's records as an anomaly, but he is considered insignificant. A mortal. A speck. The Misremembered was deemed sufficient to handle him—and it failed.

Karthayne has not escalated. Sol is too unimportant for the Sovereign's personal attention.

Sol's best protection is being beneath notice. The moment he becomes important—does something significant, gains real power, threatens the cosmic order—Karthayne might actually look his way.

ENCOUNTER HISTORY

— The Northern Ascent (Pallid Crossroads)

  1. Fursen slept in the stable with the span-runner
  2. Sensed something wrong in the night — span-runner stopped breathing, shadows displaced, clicking sounds
  3. Found carved message "TURN AROUND" on smooth wood where something had stood
  4. Turned around — saw duplicate of himself in stall doorway (hollow black eyes, shadow turning opposite way)
  5. Duplicate said "Not you" and folded/dissolved under the stall door
  6. Fursen woke Sol Raven and Kael (Jonas barricaded his room and refused to come)
  7. Followed conceptual trail — lanterns flickered/recoiled along its path
  8. Found the creature waiting at settlement perimeter — too tall, arms too long, head tilted at Fursen's angle but facing Sol
  9. Creature tapped its head (tap tap tap) and reached for the coin
  10. Fursen asked what it was — it answered: "Not name... Not meant for names... Old thought... Forgotten shape... I look for the one who thinks wrong"
  11. Fursen gave it the memory coin (acquired during the 13-Hour Trial)
  12. Time froze — only Fursen remained aware
  13. Coin crumbled to silver dust, poured into creature's form — it became more defined, more real
  14. Entity said: "Memory returns... One of you bends the frame."
  15. Turned to Sol Raven: "You. You are the wrong thought. The Hollow Crown remembers everything... But he doesn't remember you. You're a thought that thinks itself without permission."
  16. Vanished (like a page turning)
  17. Left behind paper strip with "FOUND YOU" written in Sol's handwriting (but he never wrote it)
Note: The memory coin was the catalyst. Without it, the Misremembered might never have recognized Sol as an anomaly. The party inadvertently painted a target on Sol's back.

— The Wrong Thought

  1. Manifested at Pallid Crossroads during party's rest
  2. Settlement went wrong—mist surrounded area, people vanished
  3. Appeared wearing Sol's shape (with flaws)
  4. Explained its nature and purpose to Sol
  5. Jonas intervened—threw hammer at its hand (rolled 24, hit)
  6. Hand crumpled "like wet paper," dripped black ink
  7. Full combat ensued
  8. Party defeated it through combined assault
  9. Entity folded inward along impossible angles and vanished
  10. Left note: "NOT CORRECTED. NOTED. WILL RETURN."

BEHAVIOR

Hunting Pattern:
  • Observes before acting
  • Tests prey's reactions and defenses
  • Makes its presence known deliberately
  • Uses psychological pressure over physical force
  • Communicates through cryptic statements
  • Patient—will wait weeks or months between attempts
Known Statements:
  • "Not you." (to Fursen)
  • "...I look... for the one... who thinks... wrong." (seeking Sol)
  • "...Memory... returns..." (after consuming memory coin)
  • "You. You are the wrong thought." (to Sol)
  • "The Hollow Crown remembers everything... But he doesn't remember you."
  • "You're a thought that thinks itself without permission."
  • "NOT CORRECTED. NOTED. WILL RETURN."

CURRENT STATUS

Condition: Disrupted, reforming Location: Unknown—folded out of physical space Timeline: Will return in weeks or months Threat Level: EXTREME

The party hurt it. This is rare. This means they can hurt it again.

But it cannot be killed by conventional means. It was disrupted, not destroyed. It will reconstitute and return.

PARTY KNOWLEDGE

The party now knows:

  • Its name (The Misremembered)
  • Its origin (Karthayne the Hollow Crown)
  • Its purpose (correcting errors in creation)
  • Why it hunts Sol (connection to Aedwynn)
  • It can be hurt (Jonas's hammer worked)
  • It will return (the note confirms this)
  • Radiant damage is effective against it

items.title: Skin-Walkers
items.content:
Skin-Walkers

Type: Aberration (Shapechanger) Domain Association: Ultharion the Obsidian Shepherd Habitat: The Blackfold, mirrors, shadowed places, anywhere identity can be stolen Challenge Rating: 8 (3,900 XP)

Description

Skin-Walkers are servants of Ultharion who have transcended their original forms entirely. They no longer possess a true appearance—only the stolen identities of their victims. They exist as living voids that wear other people's skin, faces, and memories like clothing.

Appearance

Physical Description In their "true" form (rarely seen), a Skin-Walker is a void in the shape of a person—absolute darkness given humanoid outline, with no features except a faint shimmer where a face should be. When wearing a stolen skin, they appear perfectly identical to their victim, down to scars, mannerisms, and voice. The only tell: their reflection is always delayed by a fraction of a second, as if the mirror needs time to process what it's seeing.

Behavior

Skin-Walkers don't simply shapeshift—they steal. When they take a form, they remove it from the original owner, leaving behind a featureless, identity-less husk.

Identity Theft: The process requires physical contact and takes about one minute. The victim must be helpless or willing. The Skin-Walker gains their appearance, voice, some surface memories, and personality traits. The victim loses all of these—becoming a blank, faceless creature that eventually dies of existential dissolution. Impersonation: A Skin-Walker wearing stolen identity is nearly impossible to detect through normal means. They have the victim's mannerisms, knowledge of common facts, and even emotional responses. Only prolonged interaction, specific questions about obscure memories, or magical detection reveals them. Collection: Most Skin-Walkers maintain multiple stolen identities, switching between them as needed. Some collect skins obsessively, building vast wardrobes of stolen selves.

Combat

items.title: Thornback Behemoth

Thornback Behemoth

Type: Beast Domain Association: The Blooming Rot (Talaris Bloomrend the Verdant King) Habitat: The Hunger Garden, deep forest regions of the Blooming Rot Challenge Rating: 11 (7,200 XP)

Description

A bear — or it was, once. Now it's a mountain of matted fur, bark-like hide, and massive thorns growing from its spine and shoulders. Vines trail from its limbs. Mushrooms sprout from its haunches. It moves slowly, ponderously, eating everything in its path — plants, animals, Planted, pilgrims.

Not aggressive unless hungry or threatened. Unfortunately, it's always hungry.

Appearance

Physical Description A massive creature standing 15 feet tall at the shoulder, originally bear-like but now transformed by the Rot. Its hide has become bark-like, rough and ridged like ancient tree bark. Massive thorns — some as long as a man's arm — grow from its spine and shoulders in dense clusters. Matted fur hangs in patches where the bark hasn't completely taken over. Vines trail from its limbs, dragging along the ground as it walks. Mushrooms of various sizes sprout from its haunches and flanks. Its eyes are small and dark, almost lost in the mass of organic growth. When it opens its mouth, rows of flat grinding teeth are visible alongside newer, sharper growths.

Behavior

Thornback Behemoths are solitary apex predators of the Blooming Rot. They wander continuously, eating everything in their path — vegetation, animals, and any creature unfortunate enough to be caught.

Feeding Habits: Omnivorous in the extreme. A Behemoth will consume entire groves of trees, packs of smaller creatures, and any pilgrims who don't get out of its way. Its digestive system can process nearly anything organic. Movement Patterns: They move slowly but inexorably, following no set path. The forest parts before them — smaller creatures flee at the sound of their approach. Trees cracking and ground shaking announce their presence long before they're visible. Territorial Nature: They don't defend territory in the traditional sense — they simply consume whatever they encounter. Two Behemoths meeting will usually ignore each other, as neither is worth the effort to fight. Connection to Talaris: Like all major creatures of the Rot, Behemoths are connected to the fungal network. Talaris considers them useful — they clear deadfall, spread spores, and keep the forest's cycle of death and rebirth in constant motion.

Combat

D&D 5e Stat Block

Thornback Behemoth

Huge beast, unaligned Armor Class 16 (natural armor) Hit Points 175 (14d12 + 84) Speed 40 ft.
STR DEX CON INT WIS CHA
24 (+7) 8 (-1) 22 (+6) 3 (-4) 12 (+1) 6 (-2)
Saving Throws Str +11, Con +10 Skills Perception +5 Damage Resistances poison; bludgeoning from nonmagical attacks Condition Immunities frightened, poisoned Senses darkvision 60 ft., passive Perception 15 Languages — Challenge 11 (7,200 XP) Thorn Aura. Any creature that starts its turn within 10 feet of the behemoth or hits it with a melee attack while within 10 feet takes 7 (2d6) piercing damage from the behemoth's thorns. Siege Monster. The behemoth deals double damage to objects and structures. Regeneration. The behemoth regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 hit point. If the behemoth takes fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the behemoth's next turn.

Actions

Multiattack. The behemoth makes two slam attacks. Slam. Melee Weapon Attack: +11 to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: 23 (3d10 + 7) bludgeoning damage. Thorn Volley (Recharge 5-6). The behemoth shakes violently, launching thorns in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in the area must make a DC 18 Dexterity saving throw, taking 28 (8d6) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Creatures that fail the save are also restrained by thorns embedded in their flesh until they use an action to pull them out, taking 7 (2d6) piercing damage when doing so. Consume. The behemoth attempts to swallow a Large or smaller creature it has grappled. The target must succeed on a DC 18 Strength saving throw or be swallowed. A swallowed creature is blinded and restrained, has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the behemoth, and takes 21 (6d6) acid damage at the start of each of the behemoth's turns. If the behemoth takes 30 or more damage in a single turn from a creature inside it, the behemoth must succeed on a DC 20 Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall prone in a space within 10 feet of the behemoth.

Variants

Young Thornback (CR 6): A smaller specimen, only 10 feet tall. 95 HP, AC 14. No Consume ability, and Thorn Volley only affects a 15-foot cone. Still dangerous, but can be driven off by determined resistance. Ancient Thornback (CR 15): A behemoth that has lived for centuries, now more plant than animal. 230 HP, AC 18. Its Thorn Aura extends to 15 feet and deals 10 (3d6) damage. It can use Thorn Volley twice before needing to recharge. When reduced to 0 HP, it explodes in a burst of spores — all creatures within 30 feet must succeed on a DC 18 Constitution save or be poisoned for 1 hour. Rot-Blessed Behemoth (CR 17): A behemoth that Talaris has personally blessed. 260 HP, legendary resistance (2/day). Can cast entangle at will and wall of thorns once per day. Talaris can see and speak through this creature directly.

Ecology

Formation: Thornback Behemoths are descendants of bears that entered the Blooming Rot long ago. Over generations, the forest's influence transformed them into the massive, thorn-covered creatures they are today. Lifecycle: They live for centuries, growing larger and more overgrown with each passing decade. They reproduce rarely — perhaps once per century — and the mother abandons the cub within weeks of birth. Relationship to the Verdant King: Talaris values them as instruments of the cycle. Their constant consumption and movement spreads spores, clears deadfall, and keeps the forest in constant renewal. He occasionally directs them toward intruders he wants removed. Role in Ecosystem: They are the forest's apex predators and primary recyclers. Everything they consume is eventually returned to the Rot through their waste, feeding new growth.

Encounter Ideas

  • The party hears a Behemoth approaching — trees cracking, ground shaking. They have minutes to hide, flee, or prepare for a fight they probably can't win.
  • A Behemoth has swallowed something important — a key, an artifact, a person. The party must retrieve it without killing themselves.
  • Two Behemoths are approaching the same area from different directions. The party is caught in the middle.
  • A dying Behemoth blocks the only path forward. Its death throes will be violent, and the spore burst when it dies will be dangerous.

Lore

From a Pilgrim's Warning "When the ground shakes and the trees start falling, you run. You don't fight. You don't hide. You run, and you pray it's not following you. I've seen a Behemoth walk through a camp of twenty armed men. It didn't even slow down. The men who didn't run... the forest grew flowers where they fell." From the Spore-Touched of Sporehaven "The Behemoths are the King's gardeners. They prune. They clear. They spread the seeds of new growth. When one passes through an area, the forest grows back stronger, more vital. We do not mourn those they consume — we celebrate their return to the cycle."

items.title: Vein-Crawlers
items.content:
Vein-Crawlers

Overview

Parasites of the Arterial Deepways Type: Aberration (Vermin) Domain Association: Mareatha the Vein-Mother Habitat: Arterial Deepways, Veinspire territories, anywhere blood has been spilled in devotion Challenge Rating: 1/2 (100 XP)

Vein-Crawlers are parasitic creatures that infest the Arterial Deepways—the fossilized blood vessels of Aedwynn that crisscross beneath the world. They resemble centipedes the size of a human forearm, but their bodies are translucent, revealing thick dark fluid sloshing within segmented chambers.

Appearance

Physical Description A segmented creature roughly 18 inches long with dozens of needle-thin legs ending in hooked barbs. Its body is semi-transparent, showing chambers of stolen blood inside. The head features a circular lamprey-mouth ringed with backward-curving teeth designed to latch and drain. Two vestigial eye-spots glow faintly red when blood is nearby.

Behavior

Vein-Crawlers are ambush predators that cling to tunnel ceilings in the Arterial Deepways, dropping onto warm-blooded creatures passing below. They're drawn to heartbeats and can sense pulse from up to 60 feet away.

Feeding: Once latched, they drain blood at an alarming rate. A single crawler can exsanguinate a human in under an hour if not removed. Swarm Behavior: Vein-Crawlers are solitary hunters but will congregate around large prey. Finding one usually means more are nearby. Religious Significance: Mareathan cultists consider Vein-Crawlers sacred—living vessels that carry the Mother's essence. Some intentionally allow themselves to be fed upon as devotion.

Combat

D&D 5e Stat Block

Vein-Crawler

Small aberration, unaligned Armor Class 13 (natural armor) Hit Points 14 (4d6) Speed 30 ft., climb 30 ft.
STR DEX CON INT WIS CHA
6 (-2) 16 (+3) 10 (+0) 1 (-5) 12 (+1) 2 (-4)
Skills Stealth +5, Perception +3 Senses blindsight 60 ft. (blind beyond), passive Perception 13 Languages — Challenge 1/2 (100 XP) Blood Sense. The vein-crawler can detect the location of any creature with blood within 60 feet. Spider Climb. The vein-crawler can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

Actions

Latch. Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 5 (1d4 + 3) piercing damage, and the vein-crawler attaches to the target. While attached, the vein-crawler doesn't attack. Instead, at the start of each of its turns, the target loses 5 (1d4 + 3) hit points due to blood loss.

The vein-crawler can detach itself by spending 5 feet of movement. A creature, including the target, can use its action to detach the vein-crawler with a successful DC 12 Strength check.

Variants

Bloated Crawler (CR 1): A vein-crawler gorged on blood. Larger, slower, but explodes in a spray of acidic blood when killed (5 ft. radius, DC 11 Dex save, 2d6 acid damage). Blessed Crawler (CR 1): Mareathan priests cultivate these specimens. They can transmit a compulsion to seek Veinspire when they bite (DC 12 Wisdom save or feel drawn to the Cathedral for 24 hours).

Ecology

Diet: Blood exclusively. Can survive months between feedings by entering torpor. Reproduction: Lays eggs in corpses. Larvae gestate inside dead flesh before emerging as hand-sized juveniles. Predators: Gallery Hounds hunt them. Pulse-Wardens ignore them as "beneath notice." Territory: Arterial Deepways primarily, but can spread through any blood-soaked environment.

Encounter Ideas

  • Party discovers a corpse in the Deepways, completely drained, with dozens of shed crawler shells nearby
  • A Mareathan pilgrim begs the party to help retrieve "sacred crawlers" from a collapsed tunnel
  • An infestation has spread to a village well that connects to the Deepways

items.title: Session 01: The Church Below
items.content:
Session 01: The Church Below

Prelude — The Caravan Job

Sol Raven and Jonas met as hired guards for a merchant caravan. The job was straightforward: escort goods to Veinspire, deliver them to a church in one of the lesser districts, collect payment. Neither knew the other before this job. Neither had reason to trust the other beyond professional obligation.

The journey to Veinspire was uneventful. The land changed as they approached — the soil took on a reddish hue, the air grew warm and humid, and a faint copper smell hung in everything. Rivers ran red, not with pollution but with something older. The architecture of distant Veinspire rose on the horizon like a cathedral grown rather than built, its spires twisted into organic shapes that defied conventional masonry.

They delivered the goods without incident. Payment received. Job complete.

They should have left.

Part One — The River Wakes

Taking Lodging

With coin in their pockets and no immediate obligations, Sol and Jonas took rooms at The Scarlet Hearth — a tavern in the Lesser Sacral District named for the great stone fireplace that dominated its common room. The establishment was modest — working-class patrons, simple food, beds that were clean enough. The kind of place where people minded their own business.

The district sat along one of Veinspire's arterial rivers — canals that ran through the city like veins through flesh. The water was thick and red, viscous in ways water shouldn't be. Locals paid it no mind. This was simply how things were in Mareatha's domain. The rivers carried the Vein-Mother's essence. The rivers were holy.

That first night, the rivers were restless.

The Heartbeat Intensifies

It started as a vibration felt more than heard — a deep, rhythmic pulse that made the floorboards tremble. The tavern's patrons paused mid-conversation. Drinks rippled in their cups. The pulse came again. And again. Each beat stronger than the last.

The heartbeat of something vast beneath the city.

Outside, the river began to bubble. Steam rose from its surface despite the cool night air. The red water churned, thick clots rising and sinking in the current.

Then the screaming started.

The Miner

Sol and Jonas rushed outside to find chaos in the streets. Civilians fled in all directions. Among them, a miner — still covered in the dust of his labor — sprinted toward them, wild-eyed with terror.

A shard of coagulated blood had pierced his leg.

The wound was strange — the blood-shard had embedded itself in his calf like a thrown dagger, but it pulsed with its own rhythm, independent of the miner's heartbeat. Dark veins spread from the impact site, crawling up his thigh.

Sol Raven moved to help him. The skeleton's nature remained hidden beneath hood and robe — to the miner, Sol was simply a stranger offering aid. Sol knelt to examine the wound, reaching for the shard.

The moment Sol touched him, the miner's eyes went white.

He screamed — not in pain, but in rage. Whatever the blood-shard carried had reached his brain. His hands found Sol's throat with strength that shouldn't have belonged to a wounded man. The miner had lost his mind, lost himself, become something else wearing his body.

Sol fought him off as Jonas turned toward the river.

The Blood Beast

Jonas peered over the edge of the canal, trying to see what had caused the chaos. The red water churned below, thick and opaque. He saw nothing.

Then the river exploded upward.

A Blood Beast erupted from the canal — a coagulated predator formed from Mareatha's circulatory essence. It was roughly humanoid in shape but wrong in every proportion: too-long limbs, a torso that bulged and contracted with its own heartbeat, a head that was more wound than face. It glistened wetly in the lamplight, held together by divine will rather than anatomy.

It landed on the street with a wet slap and lunged for Jonas.

Combat — The River Attack

Enemies:
  • Blood Beast (CR appropriate for level 1)
  • Corrupted Miner (commoner statistics, maddened)
Battlefield: The street outside the tavern, along the canal's edge. Wet cobblestones. Panicking civilians fleeing in all directions. Red water still churning below.

Sol Raven fought the corrupted miner while Jonas engaged the Blood Beast. The miner attacked with desperate, mindless fury — clawing, biting, screaming incoherently. The blood-shard in his leg pulsed faster with each passing moment, the dark veins spreading higher.

Jonas tanked the Blood Beast's assault. The creature fought like a thing that didn't understand its own mortality — throwing itself forward without regard for defense, trying to engulf rather than strike. Each wound Jonas inflicted wept rather than bled, the creature's mass redistributing around the damage.

Sol's fire magic proved effective against the Beast. Heat caused its coagulated mass to cook and solidify, disrupting its ability to reform. Sol superheated sections of its body while Jonas carved away at the weakened areas.

The miner died still fighting — Sol put him down as mercifully as circumstances allowed. There was nothing left of the man inside. Only the corruption.

The Blood Beast fell when Jonas finally struck something vital — if such a creature had vital organs. It collapsed into a pool of steaming blood that slowly drained back into the canal.

Victory. The river calmed. The heartbeat faded.

For now.

Aftermath of the Attack

The street was a charnel scene. The miner's body lay still, dark veins frozen beneath his skin. The Blood Beast had left nothing but a wet stain that would trouble the cobblestones for days. Civilians emerged from hiding, some injured, all terrified.

City watch arrived within minutes. They asked questions — who were these strangers, what had happened, why were they here? Sol and Jonas answered honestly. They were caravan guards. They heard screaming. They helped.

The watch seemed satisfied, or at least too overwhelmed to press further. Blood Beast attacks were rare but not unheard of in Veinspire. The rivers sometimes... expressed themselves. It was the nature of living in a god's circulatory system.

Sol and Jonas returned to The Scarlet Hearth. Sleep came poorly that night.

Part Two — Sister Marwen's Request

The Parish in Distress

The next morning, a small group from a nearby parish approached Sol and Jonas at the tavern. Word had spread of the strangers who had fought the Blood Beast. Word had spread that they were capable.

The parish was in distress.

Sister Marwen led the delegation. Sister Marwen Role: Parish Cleric, Lesser Sacral District Age: Late twenties Status: ☠️ Deceased (this session) Appearance: A young woman in her late twenties with blonde hair pulled back in a simple, practical style. Kind blue eyes already showing worry lines from the stress of recent weeks. Fair skin. Work-worn hands that had tended the sick, blessed the dying, and held the grieving. She wore the white robes of the Mareathan clergy — red trim along the hems and collar, a red sash at her waist, marking her devotion to the Vein-Mother. No gold thread, no ornate embroidery — the modest attire of a lesser sister who served the common folk rather than the cathedral elite. Personality: Gentle, devoted, humble. Sister Marwen was the kind of cleric who knew every parishioner by name, who visited the sick without being asked, who gave her own food to those with less. She had dedicated her life to Mareatha's mercy — the compassionate face of the Vein-Mother that the Church preached to the faithful. Young as she was, she had already earned the trust of her entire parish. Final Words: "Kill me. Please. Kill me before I—"

She was terrified.

The Disappearances

Marwen explained the situation:

Parishioners had been vanishing. Not all at once — one every few days for the past two weeks. They would attend evening services, return to their homes, and simply... not be there in the morning. No signs of struggle. No witnesses. No bodies.

The tremors had been growing worse. The church floor shook during services now. Cracks had appeared in the basement walls — cracks that wept a thick, dark fluid.

The Bishop had been informed. The Bishop had done nothing. The Bishop had said it was "the Mother's will" and that the faithful should not question.

Sister Marwen questioned.

She believed something was wrong beneath the church. Something had taken root in the old foundations. Something was taking her people.

She asked Sol and Jonas to accompany her into the church's basement. To investigate. To help.

They agreed.

Entering the Church

The church was modest by Veinspire standards — a stone building perhaps a century old, built in the early expansion of the district. It served a working-class congregation: miners, laborers, craftsmen, their families. The pews were worn smooth by generations of worship. The altar was simple carved stone, stained dark with centuries of ritual blood-offerings.

In Veinspire, worship meant blood. Small offerings — a pricked finger, a shallow cut, a few drops into the collection basin. The Vein-Mother asked for devotion made manifest. The Vein-Mother was always hungry.

Sister Marwen led them to a door behind the altar. Stone steps descended into darkness. The air rising from below was warm and humid, carrying a smell like copper and meat.

Marwen lit a lantern. Her hands trembled.

They descended.

Part Three — The Descent

The Basement

The church's basement had served many purposes over its century of existence. Storage. A shelter during times of trouble. A place for private prayer. The walls were old stone, the floor packed earth, the ceiling low enough that Jonas had to duck.

At first, it seemed normal. Dusty. Forgotten. The kinds of crates and barrels that accumulate in any building's unused spaces.

Then they found the crack in the far wall.

The Crack

The crack was new — Sister Marwen confirmed she had never seen it before the tremors began. It split the foundation stones like something had pressed against them from the other side. The edges were wet with a thick, dark fluid that moved too slowly to be water.

The crack was wide enough for a person to squeeze through.

Beyond it, the architecture changed.

The Tunnels

What lay beyond the crack was not stone.

The walls were congealed divine tissue — organic matter that had solidified into something like flesh-colored limestone. It was warm to the touch. It gave slightly under pressure. When Sol held the lantern close, they could see organic growths pulsing faintly beneath the surface — dark shapes that might have been veins, might have been something else.

The chambers beyond were warped inward like collapsed veins — cylindrical passages that branched and rejoined in patterns that followed no human logic. The tunnels throbbed with slow, unnatural heat. The air was thick and wet and tasted of copper.

This was not a catacomb.

This was the interior of a living body.

Mareatha's Architecture

They had found a fragment of Mareatha's circulatory architecture — the divine tissue that the Vein-Mother had ripped from Aedwynn the Maker during the Usurpation, the living infrastructure that spread beneath all of Veinspire like roots beneath a tree.

The Heart Below.

Or rather, a tiny fragment of it. A capillary of the divine. A piece of something vastly, incomprehensibly larger that extended throughout the city's foundations.

This fragment was not supposed to be accessible. The crack in the basement wall was new. Something had changed. Something had shifted. The divine tissue was growing, pressing against the boundaries of the human city above.

The missing parishioners had found this crack. Or the crack had found them.

Sister Marwen's fear grew with each step deeper into the tunnels. She had served the Vein-Mother her entire life. She had never seen this. She had never been inside her goddess.

She whispered prayers that seemed to echo strangely off the organic walls.

Deeper

They pressed deeper into the tunnels, following the largest passage. The growths became more pronounced — pulsing shapes beneath the tissue walls, dark fluid pooling in depressions in the floor, formations that looked disturbingly like organs.

The heat intensified. The heartbeat returned — felt through the floor, through the walls, through the air itself. A rhythm that was almost soothing if you didn't think about what was producing it.

They found traces of the missing parishioners: a shoe, half-absorbed into the wall; a prayer bead necklace, beads scattered across the floor; a dark stain that might once have been a person.

The fragment had consumed them.

Part Four — Marwen's Corruption

The Deepest Point

At the deepest point of their exploration, the tunnel opened into a chamber.

The chamber was roughly spherical, perhaps thirty feet across. The walls pulsed visibly — great slow contractions that made the entire space feel like the inside of a breathing lung. In the center of the chamber stood a formation of tissue that rose from the floor like a pillar, its surface covered in what looked almost like faces pressed against skin from the inside, mouths open in silent screams.

The missing parishioners. Absorbed but not entirely gone. Trapped in the divine tissue, aware, suffering.

Sister Marwen saw them. She recognized them. She whispered their names.

The chamber's heartbeat quickened.

The Fragment Awakens

The fragment was spiraling out of control.

Something about the party's presence — their living warmth, their blood, their fear — had agitated it. The tissue walls contracted faster. The faces in the pillar moved, mouths opening and closing in unison. The dark fluid on the floor began to rise.

An organ-like wall on the far side of the chamber split open violently.

Tendrils burst forth — arterial ropes of living tissue, red and glistening, moving with terrible purpose. They whipped across the chamber, fast as striking snakes.

They seized Sister Marwen.

She had time to scream — one short, shocked cry — before the tendrils pulled her into the fleshy aperture. The wall closed behind her.

Silence.

The Transformation

For a long moment, nothing happened. Sol and Jonas stood frozen, weapons raised, staring at the wall that had swallowed their guide. The chamber's heartbeat had slowed to something almost peaceful.

Then the wall opened again.

Sister Marwen emerged.

She was distorted. Corrupted. Suffering.

Her body had been reshaped in the seconds she had been inside the fragment. Her skin had taken on a greyish-red hue, stretched tight over bones that had shifted into wrong configurations. Her arms had lengthened, her fingers fused into blade-like appendages. Her face was still recognizably hers — that was the horror of it — but her jaw had unhinged, revealing rows of teeth that had not been there before.

Dark veins pulsed visibly beneath her skin. The same corruption that had taken the miner, amplified a thousandfold.

But her eyes were still hers.

Marwen's Plea

She collapsed to the floor, her transformed body convulsing. The corruption was still taking hold, still reshaping her, and she was fighting it with everything she had.

Her voice emerged broken, wet, inhuman — but the words were her own:

"Kill me."

She dragged herself toward them, not to attack, but to beg.

"Please. Kill me before I—"

Her voice cut off. Her body seized. Her eyes, which had been filled with desperate pleading, went blank.

Whatever Sister Marwen had been was gone.

What remained rose to its feet, flexed its blade-fingers, and attacked.

Combat — The Corrupted Sister

Enemy:
  • Corrupted Sister Marwen (statistics appropriate for a challenging level 1 encounter)
Battlefield: The spherical chamber at the heart of the fragment. Organic walls pulsing around them. Dark fluid underfoot. The pillar of absorbed parishioners watching with trapped, silent faces.

The thing that had been Marwen fought with terrible efficiency. Her transformed body was faster than it should have been, stronger than it should have been. The blade-fingers slashed with surgical precision. She made no sound as she attacked — no battle cries, no screams, just the wet whisper of tissue moving through air.

Sol and Jonas fought back. They had to.

The corruption controlling Marwen was not intelligent in any conventional sense — it was reflexive, predatory, consuming. It did not strategize. It did not speak. It simply attacked, over and over, until it was destroyed or its prey was consumed.

The battle was brutal. The chamber's heartbeat quickened with each wound inflicted, each drop of blood spilled. The tissue walls contracted closer, as if the fragment itself was trying to join the fight.

But Sol and Jonas were capable. They were professional. They had survived the Blood Beast hours before.

They killed her.

Victory. A mercy.

The Aftermath in the Chamber

Marwen's corrupted body did not die cleanly.

It bloated — the corruption responding to the cessation of life by trying to consume the shell that remained. Her body swelled, dark fluid pressing against skin that could no longer contain it.

Then it exploded.

The detonation painted the chamber walls with gore. Dark tissue splattered across Sol and Jonas, across the pillar of trapped faces, across everything. The smell was indescribable — copper and rot and something sweetly chemical.

When the echoes faded, nothing remained of Sister Marwen but a wet stain on the organic floor.

The chamber's heartbeat slowed.

The fragment had fed.

Escape

Sol and Jonas fled.

They did not stop to investigate further. They did not attempt to free the absorbed parishioners — if such a thing was even possible. They simply ran, back through the tunnels of living tissue, back through the crack in the basement wall, back up the stone steps into the church above.

They emerged into daylight, covered in blood and worse, gasping for air that didn't taste of copper.

The church was empty. The parishioners who had seen them descend were gone — fled, perhaps, when the screaming started. When the tremors intensified. When the walls began to weep.

They had to report what had happened.

Part Five — The Bishop's Welcome

Reporting to the Authorities

Sol and Jonas made their way to the district's ecclesiastical authority — a minor administrative building where the church hierarchy managed the lesser parishes. They were blood-soaked, traumatized, and carrying news that no one would want to hear.

A Bishop received them.

He was a middle-aged man with the soft hands and well-fed face of someone who had never worked a day of manual labor. His robes were finer than anything Sister Marwen had ever worn. His office was comfortable, decorated with religious iconography that seemed almost obscene after what Sol and Jonas had witnessed below.

They told him everything.

The crack in the basement. The tunnels of living tissue. The absorbed parishioners. Sister Marwen's corruption and death. The chamber with its pillar of screaming faces.

The Bishop listened. He nodded. He made appropriate sounds of concern.

Then he offered them a cleansing ceremony.

The Cleansing

The Bishop explained that exposure to raw divine tissue could leave... residue. Corruption that might not manifest for days or weeks. A cleansing ceremony — ritual immersion in holy water — would purify them, ensure that whatever they had touched in those tunnels would not touch them back.

It was a reasonable precaution. It was a generous offer.

Sol Raven rejected it.

The hooded figure simply shook their head and moved toward the door. No explanation. No excuse. Just refusal.

The Bishop's eyes followed Sol out. His expression did not change, but something behind it did. A hooded stranger who had descended into divine tissue and emerged alive. A hooded stranger who refused purification. A hooded stranger who might be hiding something beneath those robes.

Jonas accepted.

He followed the Bishop to a side chamber where a pool of holy water waited — a basin carved into the floor, filled with liquid that glowed faintly red. Blood-water. Sacred. This was Veinspire, after all. Even holy water carried the Vein-Mother's essence.

Jonas entered the pool. The water was warm, almost hot. It tingled against his skin, a sensation that might have been cleansing or might have been something else entirely.

When he emerged, the Bishop declared him purified.

Pushing His Luck

Jonas, perhaps emboldened by surviving two near-death experiences in as many days, decided to push his luck.

He asked the Bishop for a reward.

They had, after all, risked their lives to investigate the disappearances. They had destroyed a corruption that might have spread further. They had done the church's work when the church itself had done nothing.

The Bishop considered this.

Then he smiled — a warm, pastoral smile that did not reach his eyes — and agreed. Jonas had performed a heroic deed. Jonas deserved recognition.

The Bishop gave him gold.

Jonas thanked him and left, satisfied that he had made the best of a terrible situation.

He did not see the Bishop's expression change the moment the door closed.

He did not see the Bishop summon a junior priest and speak quietly about "the hooded stranger" and "potential heresy" and "matters for the Inquisition."

He did not know that the Bishop had already made his decision about the hooded figure who refused purification.

Word was already being sent to High Inquisitor Seraphine Vale.

Session Conclusion

The Night After

Sol and Jonas reunited at The Scarlet Hearth that evening. Neither spoke much about what had happened. What was there to say? They had descended into a god's flesh. They had killed an innocent woman transformed into a monster. They had seen the faces of the damned pressed against walls of living tissue.

This was Veinspire. This was the Ashen Realms. This was the world the Sovereigns had made from the Maker's corpse.

They drank. They rested. They tried not to dream.

In the morning, the Inquisition would come.

items.title: Session 02: The Inquisition & The Theorists
items.content:
Session 02: The Inquisition & The Theorists

Part One — The Inquisition Arrives

Morning at The Scarlet Hearth

Sol and Jonas woke in their rooms at The Scarlet Hearth — the modest tavern that had become their temporary home in the Lesser Sacral District. The establishment took its name from the great stone fireplace that dominated its common room, its flames casting a warm reddish glow that locals found comforting in a city where red was the color of the sacred.

Sleep had not come easily. The memory of Sister Marwen's pleading eyes, her transformed body, her explosion into gore — these images lingered. But morning had come regardless, and with it, the need to move forward.

They descended to the common room for breakfast. The other patrons gave them a wide berth. Word had spread. The strangers who had gone into the church basement. The strangers who had come out covered in blood. The strangers who had killed Sister Marwen.

The whispers followed them out the door.

Suspicion in the Streets

The Lesser Sacral District felt different that morning. Gazes lingered too long. Conversations paused as they passed. A mother pulled her child closer when Sol's hooded figure walked by.

The district had decided what to think of them. Two strangers arrive. A Blood Beast attacks. They descend into a church with a beloved sister. Only they return. The sister's body is never found.

It didn't matter that they had tried to help. It didn't matter that Marwen had begged them to kill her. The district saw only the facts: strangers, violence, death.

They had barely made it a block from the tavern when the Inquisition found them.

High Inquisitor Seraphine Vale

She was waiting for them at the intersection of two arterial streets, flanked by four armed soldiers in the standard armor of the Inquisition's enforcers. The morning crowd had already parted around her, civilians pressing themselves against walls and doorways to avoid her attention.

High Inquisitor Seraphine Vale stood perfectly still, watching them approach. High Inquisitor Seraphine Vale Role: High Inquisitor, Mareathan Inquisition Age: 34 Status: Active (this session) Appearance: A striking woman in her mid-thirties with sharp, aristocratic features and eyes the color of dried blood — a mark of Mareatha's favor granted to her most devoted servants. Her dark hair was worn in a severe braid that fell past her shoulders. She carried herself with the absolute certainty of someone who had never questioned their purpose. Her Inquisitor's vestments were immaculate — white robes trimmed with arterial red, cut for both ceremony and combat. The holy symbol of Mareatha hung openly at her throat: a heart wrapped in veins. There was no cruelty in her face. That was what made her dangerous. She genuinely believed she was saving souls. Personality: Patient. Methodical. Certain. Seraphine Vale did not raise her voice. She did not make threats. She simply asked questions and waited for the truth to emerge. She had never failed to extract a confession from a genuine heretic — because she believed, truly believed, that the guilty always revealed themselves. The Vein-Mother's light exposed all falsehood. First Words to the Party: "You are the ones who descended into the Church of the Merciful Vein. You are the ones who emerged without Sister Marwen. I have questions."

She did not introduce herself. She did not need to. Everyone in Veinspire knew the blood-eyed woman who hunted heretics.

"You are the ones who descended into the Church of the Merciful Vein," she said. Her voice was calm, almost gentle. "You are the ones who emerged without Sister Marwen. I have questions."

It was not a request.

The soldiers moved to flank Sol and Jonas — not aggressively, but with the casual certainty of predators who knew their prey could not escape. The message was clear: they would answer the High Inquisitor's questions, one way or another.

Part Two — The Trial by Ash

The Red Priory

Seraphine did not take them to a dungeon. She did not chain them or threaten them with torture. Instead, she led them to The Red Priory — a chapel in the Lesser Sacral District that served as a secondary seat for the Inquisition's work among the common folk.

The sun never truly shone in Veinspire — it just faded. By the time they arrived, the air was thick with candle smoke and incense. The once-holy halls glowed a dull crimson, as though the walls themselves were bleeding.

A pair of Inquisitors in mirrored masks escorted Sol and Jonas inside. Their boots echoed through the marble corridors, lined with icons defaced in soot. Every eye in the murals had been carved out.

At the center of the chapel sat a great brazier filled with smoldering ash. Seraphine stood behind it, flanked by two aides — Confessor Halvyr (a whispering priest with a scarred throat) and Scribe Malis (a masked scribe recording everything in ash ink).

The brazier's light painted Seraphine's face gold and red, like a saint sculpted from fresh blood.

"Step forward," she said. "And kneel."

Refusal Before the Flame

Sol and Jonas stepped forward.

They did not kneel.

Jonas — armored, battle-worn, scarred from his encounter with the Blood Beast. Sol Raven — still, silent, draped in cloth, eyes like coals under his hood.

A long, cold pause. The Inquisitors shifted; the sound of their armor was a whisper of threat.

"You misunderstand," Seraphine said, her voice patient. "Kneeling isn't submission. It's recognition — that something greater than flesh hears your truth."

No movement. She lowered her voice.

"Refusal before the flame... is still confession."

She took one step forward, the red light of the brazier reflecting off her blood-colored eyes.

"Very well. Stand, then. But the flame stands with you."

She gestured sharply. Two masked attendants pulled open narrow vents in the brazier — the fire grew brighter, higher, breathing like a living thing.

"Let your words prove stronger than your knees."

The Structure of the Trial

The interrogation happened in three stages, each testing something different:

  1. Faith — words and conviction
  2. Blood — the body's truth
  3. Will — the soul's resistance

Their defiance had consequences. All checks would be harder now. The Inquisitors were watching for any misstep.

Stage One: Faith

Seraphine gestured toward the brazier.

"Speak what you saw below the Church of the Merciful Vein. Speak as though the Vein-Mother listens — because She does."

Sol and Jonas told the truth — or most of it. The crack in the basement. The tunnels of living tissue. The absorbed parishioners. Marwen's corruption. Her plea to be killed. The combat. The explosion.

Seraphine's expression did not change. When they finished, she asked clarifying questions. Small details. The color of the fluid. The temperature of the walls. The exact words Marwen had spoken.

She was testing their story against itself.

Jonas invoked duty, spoke of the Priory, of responding to a sister's plea for help. Sol spoke as a scholar — clinical, observational, careful not to claim more understanding than warranted.

Seraphine nodded slowly throughout. When they finished, she said nothing for a long moment.

"A liar who hides behind faith is still a believer," she murmured. "But you speak with the cadence of truth. The flame accepts your account — for now."

Stage One: Partial success.

Stage Two: Blood

Confessor Halvyr stepped forward with a silver censer and a long needle. He motioned for their hands.

"The body does not lie," Seraphine said. "Your veins will tell us whom you serve."

The test was ritual and invasive. When the needle pierced the skin, a drop of blood would fall into the ash brazier. If it glowed red, the Heart's corruption was near. If it burned clean, the subject was untainted.

Jonas went first.

The needle pierced his palm. Blood welled — red, ordinary, human. It dripped into the brazier.

The ash glowed faintly, then subsided. Clean. But Seraphine's eyes lingered on Jonas's arm, where faint red veins pulsed once beneath the skin — visible only to her trained gaze. A trace of something. Not corruption, but... contact. Proximity to the divine tissue.

She said nothing. But she noticed.

Sol Raven's turn.

Halvyr approached with the needle. Sol extended a wrapped hand — the bandages that concealed bone rather than flesh.

The needle pressed against Sol's palm.

Nothing.

Halvyr pressed harder. The needle should have pierced skin, drawn blood, revealed truth.

Sol's hand was dry. Empty. The needle drew nothing at all.

A long silence. Halvyr looked to Seraphine, uncertainty in his posture.

Seraphine stared at the empty needle for a long moment. Her blood-colored eyes found Sol's hidden face.

"Curious," she said quietly.

She did not press further. But the suspicion was planted — a seed that would grow in the days to come.

Stage Two: Failed. Sol's nature remained hidden, but Seraphine knew something was wrong.

Stage Three: Will

Seraphine dismissed her aides. Only the brazier's light remained.

"Now we see the truth that cannot be cut or burned."

She held up her halberd — the blade dripping faint red light from rituals performed long ago.

"Look into the flame. Speak what you fear. If you lie, the flame will grow cold."

Jonas looked into the fire.

The flames reflected in his eyes. He held his stare, jaw set, soldier's discipline keeping his expression neutral. The flame flickered — tested — then steadied.

Seraphine nodded once.

"A soldier's will. Steel forged in duty. The kind we need."

Sol looked into the fire.

The light bent strangely around the hooded figure. For a moment, the flame seemed to hum — a resonance that had no source, a vibration that touched something deep in Seraphine's training.

Her pupils dilated. She felt something answer from within Sol. Something that should not have been there.

"You are... touched," she whispered. "But by what?"

The flame guttered. Cold crept into the brazier's heart.

Stage Three: Failed. Sol's nature remained secret, but the wrongness of his existence had registered.

The Verdict

Seraphine raised her halberd and drove its butt into the marble floor. The sound echoed through the Red Priory like a judge's gavel.

"Two faults. One strength."

She circled them slowly, her weapon tracing a faint hum in the air.

"You stood before the flame, yet it did not consume you. That means the Heart still knows your names. It has not decided whether to kill you... or use you."

She stopped before Jonas.

"You believe in order, soldier. But your faith is forged of fear. You'll obey — not because you worship, but because you dread chaos."

Then she turned to Sol.

"And you." The brazier's light flickered, casting strange shadows across Sol's wrapped form. "You've touched something you shouldn't have. You carry a wrongness the flame cannot name."

She stepped back, addressing them both.

"You are not proven heretics. But you are not proven faithful either. You exist in the space between — potential heretics, watched but not condemned."

Forbidden to Leave

"You will remain in Veinspire," Seraphine said. It was not a request. "You will not attempt to leave the city. You will report to the Chapel of Inquiry every three days to confirm your presence. You will not interfere with Church business unless directed."

She paused at the chapel door.

"I will be watching you. The Vein-Mother's eyes are everywhere in her city. Do not forget that."

Then she was gone, her soldiers falling into step behind her.

Sol and Jonas were left alone in the Red Priory, the weight of their situation settling over them like a shroud. They were trapped. Suspected. Surveilled. And they had no idea how to escape.

Part Three — The Cursed Breastplate

Seeking Armor

After the Inquisition's departure, Sol and Jonas took stock of their situation. They were trapped in Veinspire, yes — but that didn't mean they had to be helpless. The fights in the church basement had shown them the dangers of this city. They needed better equipment.

They spent the afternoon searching the Lesser Sacral District for a blacksmith. Most of the forges in the district served the mining community — picks, shovels, cart wheels, the tools of labor. But eventually they found a smith who dealt in arms and armor.

The Blacksmith's Offer

The smith was a broad-shouldered man with burn-scarred forearms and the permanently squinting eyes of someone who had spent decades staring into forge-fire. His shop was cramped and cluttered, weapons and armor pieces hanging from every available surface.

He looked Sol and Jonas up and down with the calculating gaze of a merchant assessing customers.

"Looking for protection, are you?" He gestured vaguely at his wares. "Got chainmail. Got leather. Got a few pieces of plate if you've got the coin."

Jonas browsed the selection. Most of it was serviceable but unremarkable — the kind of armor that would stop a blade but wouldn't turn heads.

Then he noticed the breastplate in the corner.

It was steel, well-crafted, with a subtle curve that would deflect blows effectively. It looked expensive — far too expensive for a smith in the Lesser Sacral District. But it sat apart from the other pieces, almost hidden, as if the smith didn't want anyone to notice it.

"What about that one?"

The smith's expression changed. Something flickered across his face — discomfort, perhaps. Or fear.

"That one's... different," he said carefully. "Found it in a shipment from the cathedral district years ago. Don't know where it came from originally. Don't want to know."

"What's wrong with it?"

The smith hesitated. Then he picked up the breastplate and held it close to Jonas.

"Listen."

Jonas leaned in. At first he heard nothing. Then — faint, almost imperceptible — a rhythm. A pulse. A heartbeat.

The breastplate had its own heartbeat.

"It's cursed," the smith said flatly. "Or blessed. Or something in between. I've had priests look at it. They can't explain it. All I know is, it's been sitting in my shop for eight years and I want it gone."

He thrust it toward Jonas.

"Fifty gold. That's a fraction of what it's worth as armor, and I don't care. Take it. Get it out of my shop. I'm tired of hearing that damn heartbeat when I'm trying to sleep."

Jonas's Choice

Jonas examined the breastplate more closely. The craftsmanship was excellent — better than anything else in the shop. The steel was high quality, the joints well-fitted, the straps solid leather. And there was something else: the metal radiated a faint red hue, as if warmth lived within the steel itself. As armor, it would serve admirably.

The heartbeat continued. Slow. Steady. Alive.

In any other city, Jonas might have walked away. But this was Veinspire. This was Mareatha's domain. Here, blood flowed upward in fountains. Here, the rivers pulsed with divine essence. Here, the boundary between the living and the inanimate was... flexible.

A breastplate with a heartbeat was strange. But was it dangerous?

Jonas made his decision. He paid the fifty gold and strapped the breastplate on.

The heartbeat synchronized with his own within minutes.

Part Four — The Alleyway

Evening Falls

As evening descended over the Lesser Sacral District, Sol and Jonas found themselves wandering the streets with no particular destination. The Inquisition's surveillance weighed on them. Every passing face might be a spy. Every shadow might hide watching eyes.

They needed allies. They needed information. They needed a way out of this trap.

They had none of these things.

The arterial canals glowed faintly in the dusk, their red waters catching the last light of day. Lanterns were being lit along the major thoroughfares. The district was transitioning from the bustle of day to the quieter rhythms of night.

They were passing the mouth of an alleyway when a hand reached out and grabbed Jonas's arm.

"In here. Quickly. Before they see you."

Kael

The young man who pulled them into the shadows was barely out of his teens — thin, nervous, with the ink-stained fingers of a scholar and the darting eyes of someone who expected to be caught at any moment.

He pressed himself against the alley wall, peering past them toward the street.

"Were you followed? Did anyone see you come this way?"

Sol and Jonas exchanged glances. They had no idea who this person was or why he was accosting them in an alleyway.

"Who are you?" Sol asked.

The young man seemed to remember himself. He straightened slightly, though his eyes kept flicking toward the alley's entrance.

"My name is Kael. I'm... I'm with people who want to help you. People who understand what it's like to be trapped in this city. People who know what the Church really is."

Kael Role: Resonant Theorist, Scholar Age: Early twenties Status: Alive (joins party this session) Appearance: A young man who looked barely out of his teens — thin and angular, with the pale complexion of someone who spent more time with books than sunlight. His dark hair was perpetually disheveled, and his fingers were stained with ink from constant writing. He wore simple scholar's robes, threadbare at the elbows, and carried a satchel that bulged with papers and journals. His eyes were sharp despite their nervous darting — the eyes of someone who noticed details others missed. Personality: Anxious, brilliant, driven. Kael vibrated with nervous energy, always looking over his shoulder, always expecting the Inquisition to appear. But beneath the anxiety was a fierce intelligence and a burning need to understand the truth of the world. He had risked everything to study forbidden knowledge. He would risk everything again to share it. First Words to the Party: "I know who you are. I know the Inquisition has marked you. And I know you need help — the kind of help the Church will never give you."

"I know who you are," Kael continued, speaking quickly. "You're the ones who went into the Church of the Merciful Vein. You're the ones Seraphine Vale questioned today. The whole district is talking about it."

He stepped closer, lowering his voice.

"I also know you need help. The kind of help the Church will never give you. The Inquisition has marked you as potential heretics — that means they're watching you, waiting for you to slip up. Sooner or later, they'll find an excuse to arrest you properly. And then..."

He drew a finger across his throat.

"But there are others in this city who oppose the Church. Others who see what it really is. And we might be able to help you — if you're willing to help us first."

An Offer

Sol and Jonas listened as Kael explained. He was part of a group called the Resonance Theorists — scholars and researchers who studied the true nature of the world. They believed that the Sovereigns were not gods in any meaningful sense, that the world itself was built on the corpse of something older, and that the divine "truth" preached by the Church was a carefully maintained lie.

This was heresy of the highest order. The kind of heresy that got people publicly executed.

"We operate in secret," Kael said. "We have to. If the Inquisition found us..." He shuddered. "But we have resources. Knowledge. Connections outside the city. We can help you escape Veinspire — eventually. But first, we need to know we can trust you."

"How do we prove that?"

Kael's nervous energy intensified. "There's something we need. Something important to our research. We can discuss the details later, with the others. But if you're willing to work with us — if you're willing to help us — we can help you in return."

He glanced toward the alley's entrance again.

"Think about it. Come to The Scarlet Hearth tonight, after midnight. I'll find you there and take you to meet the others."

Then he slipped away into the shadows, leaving Sol and Jonas alone with a choice to make.

Part Five — The Mines

Return to The Scarlet Hearth

Sol and Jonas returned to the tavern as evening deepened into night. The common room was busier now — miners off their shifts, laborers seeking drink after a hard day, a few travelers passing through. The fire in the great stone hearth crackled warmly, casting dancing shadows across the walls.

They found a table in the corner and ordered food, their minds occupied with Kael's offer. Alliance with heretics. The risk was enormous. But so was the alternative — waiting for Seraphine Vale to find an excuse to condemn them.

They were debating their options when they noticed the miner.

The Drunk Miner

He sat alone at a table near the fire, hunched over a mug of ale that he wasn't drinking. His clothes were dust-covered, his face haggard, his eyes unfocused. He looked like a man who had seen something that had broken him.

What drew their attention was his hand.

A shard of crystallized blood was embedded in his palm — a jagged red crystal that pulsed faintly with its own light. The same kind of shard that had corrupted the miner they'd fought on their first night in Veinspire.

The man was staring at it with the glazed expression of someone in shock.

The Miner's Plea

Sol and Jonas approached carefully. The miner looked up at them with hollow eyes.

"You're them, aren't you?" His voice was slurred — from drink or trauma, it was hard to say. "The ones who killed the beast in the canal. The ones who went into the church."

They didn't deny it.

The miner lifted his hand, showing them the crystal embedded in his flesh. "Found this in the mines. The northern tunnels. Something's wrong up there. Men have been... changing. Acting strange. Some of them don't come back at all."

He swallowed hard.

"I pulled this out of a wall. Didn't think nothing of it at first — crystals in the mines aren't unusual. But then it... it started growing into me. I can feel it. Spreading. Like roots under my skin."

His voice cracked.

"Please. I don't want to end up like the others. I don't want to become... something else."

Cauterization

Jonas examined the shard. It had embedded itself deep into the miner's palm, crystalline tendrils spreading beneath the skin toward the wrist. The same corruption they had seen before — Mareatha's influence, uncontrolled and consuming.

But this was early. The corruption hadn't reached the miner's brain yet. There might still be time.

Jonas made a decision. He crossed to the tavern's great hearth and thrust his blade into the coals, heating the metal until it glowed orange. Then he returned to the miner.

"This is going to hurt."

The miner nodded, understanding.

Jonas gripped the shard with one hand and pulled. The crystal came free with a wet tearing sound, trailing thin tendrils of corrupted tissue. Before the wound could bleed — before the corruption could spread — Jonas pressed the heated blade against the miner's palm.

The miner screamed. The smell of burning flesh filled the air. Nearby patrons looked up in alarm, then quickly looked away. In Veinspire, people learned not to ask questions.

When Jonas removed the blade, the wound was cauterized. Ugly, scarred, but clean. The corruption had been stopped.

The miner slumped in his chair, unconscious from pain and shock.

The Northern Mines

Sol and Jonas looked at the crystal in Jonas's hand. It pulsed weakly, its light fading now that it was separated from living flesh.

The miner had mentioned the northern tunnels. Something wrong. Men changing. Some not coming back.

They exchanged glances. This wasn't their problem. They had enough troubles without adding mine investigations to the list.

But the corruption was spreading. The Blood Beast. The church basement. Now the mines. Mareatha's domain was becoming unstable, and whatever was causing it would only get worse.

They left the unconscious miner in the care of the tavern keeper and headed north to investigate.

Blood Beasts at the Entrance

The entrance to the northern mines was a gaping wound in the hillside north of the Lesser Sacral District — a tunnel mouth reinforced with timber beams, lit by flickering torches that cast uncertain light into the darkness beyond.

No guards. No workers. The mines should have been active even at this hour — Veinspire's industrial heart never truly slept — but the northern tunnels were silent.

Sol and Jonas entered cautiously, weapons drawn.

They didn't get far.

The first Blood Beast emerged from the shadows barely thirty yards in — a coagulated horror similar to the one they'd fought at the canal, but smaller, faster. It had been feeding on something. The remains of a miner lay scattered nearby.

Then another emerged. And another.

The tunnel entrance had become a nest.

Combat — Blood Beasts

Enemies:
  • Blood Beasts (3)
Battlefield: The mine entrance tunnel. Narrow confines. Flickering torchlight. Limited room to maneuver.

The Blood Beasts attacked with savage hunger, their coagulated forms surging forward in the cramped space. Sol's fire magic proved effective once again — heat causing their bodies to solidify and crack. Jonas held the line, his new breastplate absorbing blows that would have killed an unarmored man.

The fight was brutal but brief. Three Blood Beasts were dangerous, but Sol and Jonas had learned from their first encounter. They knew how these things moved, how they attacked, how they died.

When the last Beast collapsed into a steaming pool of ichor, Sol and Jonas stood in the tunnel entrance, breathing hard.

Victory. But the deeper tunnels remained unexplored.

Retreat

They could have pressed deeper. The miner's story suggested something worse lurked in the northern tunnels — something creating these Blood Beasts, something corrupting the workers.

But they were tired. Wounded. And Kael's midnight meeting was approaching.

"We'll come back," Jonas said, looking into the darkness beyond the torchlight. "When we know more. When we're better prepared."

Sol nodded. The mines weren't going anywhere. And neither, it seemed, was the corruption.

They returned to The Scarlet Hearth. The miner was still unconscious, but his color had improved. The tavern keeper had bandaged his hand and was watching over him.

Jonas set the blood crystal on the table. It was cool now, inert, its power faded.

"Keep this safe," he told the keeper. "The man will want it when he wakes."

Then they waited for midnight.

Part Six — The Resonance Theorists

Midnight Meeting

After midnight, when the common room of The Scarlet Hearth had emptied and the fire had burned low, Kael appeared.

He emerged from the shadows near the back entrance, still nervous, still glancing over his shoulder. But there was something else in his expression now — hope, perhaps. The hope that he had found allies.

"You came back," he said. "Good. Follow me."

Carveth

The leader stepped forward to greet them.

Carveth was a middle-aged man with grey-streaked hair and the weathered face of someone who had spent years running from something. His eyes were sharp, assessing, calculating. He carried himself with the authority of a scholar who had seen too much to be afraid anymore.

"So," he said, studying Sol and Jonas. "You're the ones who descended into the Heart Below. The ones Seraphine Vale has marked as potential heretics."

He smiled — a thin, humorless expression.

"Welcome to the resistance."

Carveth Role: Leader of the Resonance Theorists Age: Mid-fifties Status: Alive (this session) Appearance: A middle-aged man with grey-streaked hair that had once been dark, worn long and tied back in a practical tail. His face was weathered, lined with the stress of years spent in hiding. He wore scholar's robes that had seen better days, patched and mended repeatedly. His hands were calloused — not from labor, but from decades of handling books and instruments. His eyes were the most striking feature: sharp, calculating, and utterly unafraid. Personality: Pragmatic to the point of coldness. Carveth had been running the Resonance Theorists for over a decade, watching friends be captured and executed, rebuilding cells that were discovered and destroyed. He had learned that sentiment was a luxury he could not afford. But beneath the pragmatism was a genuine passion for truth — a burning need to understand what the world really was, regardless of the cost. To the Party: "The Church teaches that the Sovereigns are gods. We believe they are something else entirely — parasites feeding on the corpse of the true divine. If you want to survive in this world, you need to understand what you're really dealing with."

The Corpse-World's Divine Memory

Carveth explained what the Resonance Theorists believed.

The world was built on death. Specifically, it was built on the corpse of Aedwynn the Maker — a being of true divinity who had been murdered by the Thirteen Sovereigns during the event called the Usurpation. The Sovereigns had carved up Aedwynn's body like butchers dividing a carcass, each claiming a piece of divine power for themselves.

But death was not the end. The Maker's corpse still retained... echoes. Memories. Fragments of consciousness embedded in the divine tissue that now formed the foundation of reality. The Theorists called this the corpse-world's divine memory — information encoded in the very substance of existence.

"The Church teaches that the Sovereigns are our rightful rulers," Carveth said. "That they brought order to chaos, light to darkness. But the truth is simpler and uglier: they are thieves. Murderers. They killed a god and are wearing its skin."

He gestured to the papers and diagrams covering the cellar walls.

"We study the divine memory. We try to understand what Aedwynn was, what the Sovereigns truly are, and whether there is any way to... correct what was done."

The implications hung in the air. These people weren't just studying forbidden knowledge. They were seeking a way to undo the Usurpation itself.

The Offer

"We can help you," Carveth said. "We have contacts outside Veinspire. Safe houses in the Unclaimed territories. Ways to move people past the Church's checkpoints. If you work with us, we can eventually get you out of the city."

"And in return?"

"In return, you help us." Carveth's eyes were steady. "You've already proven you can handle yourselves. You've descended into places the faithful fear to tread. We have need of people like you."

He paused.

"There's something specific we need. A text held in the Church archives — the Resonant Codex. It contains information about the divine memory that we desperately need for our research. We've been trying to acquire it for years, but the archives are heavily guarded."

"You want us to steal it."

"I want you to retrieve it," Carveth corrected. "For the good of everyone who wants to understand the truth of this world. Will you help us?"

Sol and Jonas looked at each other. The choice was clear: ally with heretics and risk everything, or remain alone and wait for the Inquisition to destroy them.

They made their decision.

"We'll help."

Kael's face broke into a relieved smile. Carveth simply nodded, as if he had expected nothing less.

"Good. We'll discuss the details of the Codex retrieval tomorrow. For now, rest. You've had a long day."

He was right about that.

Session Conclusion

Dawn Approaches

Sol and Jonas emerged from the Theorists' cellar as the first grey light of dawn touched the sky. The Lesser Sacral District was stirring — early workers heading to their shifts, vendors setting up their stalls, the eternal rhythm of a city that never truly slept.

They returned to The Scarlet Hearth, exhausted but no longer hopeless. They had allies now. They had a purpose. They had a path forward, however dangerous.

The Inquisition was still watching. Seraphine Vale was still hunting. The northern mines still held dangers unexplored. And somewhere beneath the city, the Heart Below still beat.

But for the first time since arriving in Veinspire, Sol and Jonas felt like they had a chance.

Obligations & Restrictions

Obligation Details
Cannot Leave Veinspire Forbidden by Seraphine Vale
Report to Chapel of Inquiry Every 3 days to confirm presence
Resonant Codex Mission Promised to help Theorists retrieve it
