items.title: Session 13: The C-5 Descent
items.content:
Session 13: The C-5 Descent

Part One — Into the Terminus

Jonas Enters Alone

While the others waited at the sealed Terminus Ω door, Jonas forced it open alone.

The cracked seam groaned. Rust flaked away. Warm, stale air rushed outward — the breath of a room sealed for decades.

Jonas slipped through.

The door ground partially shut behind him. He was separated from the party.

The Terminus Ω-I Chamber

Dimensions: 20 ft × 20 ft, 10 ft ceiling Walls: Entirely metal Floor: Smooth steel covered in thin dust Air: Warm, stale, preserved

Jonas's lantern revealed:

1. A Dead Body in the Corner

Slumped against the far-right wall. Human. Skeleton half-exposed. Uniform rotted away. Fingers worn to bone — from clawing at the door.

Cause of death: Starvation or suffocation. Not violence.

One worker. Locked inside when the chamber sealed. Never rescued.

2. The Null-Flesh Specimen

In the center of the room — a metal containment rack holding a hardened mass the size of a human torso.

Fossilized. Calcified. Completely inert.

This was once a divine organ experiment — tissue that tried to become something but collapsed instead. Terminated when containment failed.

The Codex had classified it: "Zero Consciousness. Zero Threat."

3. A Manual Terminal

On the left wall — a metal console with broken glass, dead buttons, and an emergency lever.

Unpowered. Dust-covered. But potentially containing data if power were restored.

4. A Floor Vent

Warm air cycling through. The clicking sound came from below — the APR machine in the level beneath.

Jonas Investigates the Corpse

The worker's remains revealed:

  • Uniform: Pale gray jumpsuit with a high collar and metal insignia (I Ω designation)
  • Badge: "BIO-SECTOR INTERNAL — SUBUNIT 4"
  • Keyring: Three keys (one broken, one fused, one intact with an odd square shape)
  • Shattered Vial: Dried residue labeled "null-tissue stabilizer"
  • Metal Stylus: For the manual terminal
  • Torn Notebook: Pages fused together, one page salvageable

The salvaged page read:

"— specimen began collapsing, mass losing cohesion,

— backup seal failed, Omega-door triggered override,

— lift-table detached,

— I am trapped inside,

— something in the vent is clicking,

— I hear breathing but the specimen looks dead,

— I hope someone—"

The sentence ended mid-word. The worker died with the pen in hand.

Jonas Opens the Specimen Compartment

Beneath the containment rack — a small drawer. Jonas opened it.

Contents:
  1. A Thin Metal Logbook (Intact)
Labeled: "Ω–I / INTERNAL TERMINUS LOG / SUBUNIT 4 – REPORTING" Handwritten entries. Pre-Sovereign scientific language. Diagrams. Emergency notes.
  1. A Stoppered Sample Vial (Stable)
Dark, dried flakes. Dull purple-black residue. Label: "Null-Flesh Fragment — Stage 3 / Final Residue / Non-reactive."
  1. A Reinforced Keycard Panel
Engraved: "ACCESS: INTERNAL CONDUIT C-5 / PRIORITY CLEARANCE REQUIRED" Matches the intact key from the corpse.

The Logbook Entries

Jonas read the metal logbook:

Day 1:

"Specimen recovered from the western arterial canal. Fragment originally appeared responsive to harmonic stimuli. Mass allocated to Ω–I chamber for isolation and study."

Day 3:

"Organogenesis proceeding irregularly. Structure attempts to form chambers but collapses within minutes. Tissue mass displays pseudo-sentience but no cognition."

Day 4:

"Null-Flesh designation confirmed. Sample expresses rejection of form and returns to undifferentiated state."

Day 7:

"Stabilizer proves ineffective. Applied harmonic resonance via Choir-tuning fork. Temporary cohesion achieved. Structure held for 41 seconds."

Day 10:

"Specimen exhibiting respiratory-like expansion. No lung tissue present. Expansion seems to mimic ventilation cycles from the Auto-Pulse Regulator below."

Day 13:

"Primary containment seal ruptured. Specimen attempted extrinsic expansion along floor plane. Mass reaching toward ventilation vent. Emergency termination administered (Protocol 3-Ω). Specimen reverted to inert fossil-state."

Day 13 (continued):

"Lift-table detached unexpectedly. Chamber triggered automatic lockdown. Door sealed. Assistance requested — no reply. Something is wrong with the mainline systems."

Day 14:

"Air thinning. I hear breathing through the vent but specimen terminated. APR malfunctioning. Lift-table was removed intentionally— Why?"

The final sentence trailed off. Ink fading.

Conclusion: The lift-table was sabotaged. Someone intentionally trapped the worker inside.

Part Two — The T-Intersection

Jonas Explores Deeper

Jonas left the Terminus chamber and followed the corridor to a T-intersection:

LEFT — "C-5 ACCESS"
  • Metal plate: "C-5 INTERNAL CONDUIT / AUTHORIZED PERSONNEL ONLY"
  • Keyplate receiver slot matching Jonas's keycard
  • Dust disturbed around the slot — someone used this mechanism long ago
RIGHT — UNMARKED
  • No symbols, no plates, no writing
  • Completely undisturbed
  • Colder and slightly damp
  • No signs of travel

Jonas advanced 40 feet down the unmarked corridor. The temperature dropped sharply. The air went silent. Tally marks scratched into the wall:

```

```

Someone counting days, steps, or breaths. Then they stopped.

Jonas felt wrongness in his bones. He turned back.

The C-5 Door Opens

Jonas inserted both the keycard and the intact key into the C-5 mechanism.

CLICK. KRNNN—CHKK. THOOM.

The door slid open. Warm air rushed outward. The smell hit him:

  • Metal
  • Dust
  • Old chemicals
  • Faint antiseptic
  • Something sweet, almost floral — but wrong

A preservative. This section had been kept intact.

The corridor beyond was:

  • Smoother walls
  • Less damaged
  • Floor graded downward
  • Pipes intact
  • A faint hum of machinery

Something in this section still received residual power.

Part Three — The Party Descends Together

The Spiral Ramp

The whole party descended the C-5 corridor together.

Marching Order:
  1. Jonas
  2. Fursen
  3. Sol Raven
  4. Kael

The passage opened into a circular chamber with a spiraling ramp descending around a central shaft.

The faint pulse echoed up:

**PSSSH—thoom

PSSSH—thoom

PSSSH—thoom**

Not alive. Mechanical. Ancient divine-tech hydraulics.

First Landing — Archive Node (Subunit 2)

A metal plaque:

"C–5 LOWER ARCHIVE NODE (SUBUNIT 2)

POWER: LOW

STATUS: LOCKED"

The door was sealed, unpowered. They continued down.

The Conduit Hub

At the bottom — a circular chamber, 40 feet across.

A single half-functioning conduit tube ran up the wall, filled with slowly circulating orange light. The pulse was visible inside:

A wave of orange light moving upward → disappearing → resetting.

The room contained:

  1. A central machinery pillar — covered in conduits, valves, gears, ancient markings
  1. Three sealed doors:
- SUBUNIT 3 — "BIOCELL STORAGE" - SUBUNIT 6 — "CONDUIT MANIFOLD" - SUBUNIT 7 — "ARCHIVE LOWER CORE"
  1. A small terminal console — dead, dust-covered
  1. A grated floor section — warm airflow rising through

Kael's Codex flipped pages:

"C-5 LOWER CORE — ACCESS POTENTIAL: HIGH RISK / HIGH VALUE."

Sol Raven felt almost watched — not by a creature, but by the facility itself recognizing the divine echo in him.

Part Four — Subunit 6: The Manifold

Sol Raven Approaches

Sol Raven examined the Subunit 6 door (Arcana, passive 16):

  • The door once opened electronically — now dead
  • Not magically locked
  • Seams warm from machinery behind
  • Safe — no traps

Sol felt a faint echo of Aedwynn's breath-cycle — not divine presence, but machinery built to mimic it.

Forcing the Door (Natural 20)

Jonas and Fursen grabbed the reinforced seams.

HHRRNNNNK—THRAKK—VOOOOM

The door broke free and slid fully open. The nat 20 meant:

  • Locking pins sheared cleanly (door won't slam shut)
  • Machinery didn't destabilize
  • Internal emergency lights flickered ON

Amber strips ignited along the floor edges. Partial power restored to C-5.

Inside the Manifold

A wide, circular control chamber — 30 feet across. Every surface lined with conduits, pressure tubes, valves, monitoring instruments.

The centerpiece: a massive regulator engine shaped like a cylinder wrapped in ribbed layers.

**PSSSH—thoom

PSSSH—thoom

PSSSH—thoom**

This was the functioning divine-ventilation heart of C-5.

Important discoveries:

  1. The regulator was stable — not failing, not hostile
  1. A MAIN POWER SWITCH existed — a large lever labeled:
> "PRIMARY CONDUIT RE-ROUTE — ARCHIVE ACCESS ENABLED."
  1. A secondary hatch on the left wall — maintenance access, slightly ajar
  1. A tool rack with a single intact item — a divine-conduction calibrator
  1. The facility recognized Sol Raven — amber strips brightened when he stepped in

The Maintenance Catwalk

The party investigated the maintenance hatch. A short crawlspace led to a narrow metal catwalk suspended over a vast mechanical chamber.

Below them: the Auto-Pulse Regulator (APR-7) — the working unit. A massive cylinder rotating with pressure rings, glowing amber conduits, slow expansion and contraction like mechanical breathing.

The clicking they'd heard since entering — explained. An old machine still doing its job.

On the catwalk:

  • A dead diagnostic console (unpowered)
  • A broken section of railing with an old boot-print
  • A second hatch labeled "Maintenance C-7" (leading toward Subunit 7)
  • A loose dataplate: "ANATOMICAL RESONANCE CONTROL — Lower Core Authorized Personnel Only"

Part Five — The Lever

Jonas Pulls the Lever

Jonas gripped the Primary Conduit Re-Route lever.

KRNNNNNNNK—THRAKK—VOOOOM

The lever slammed into "ACTIVE."

The chamber shook. Dust fell. Pulses raced through the conduits.

FWOOOM—FWOOOM—FWOOOM

Amber light flooded the pipes. The ventilation cycle surged.

Immediate Effects:
  • Lights snapped on across C-5
  • Terminals activated with weak blue glow
  • All subunit doors unlocked: CHUNK—CHUNK—CHUNK
  • The ventilation cycle synchronized perfectly

And then—

Part Six — The Awakening

Something Wakes Up

SKKKK—t-t-t-t—SSHHHHH—CLNK—CLNK—CLNK

Metal. Joints moving. Legs realigning.

From the darkness of the ramp behind them, a shape emerged.

Shadows crossed the amber strips. Then limbs. Too many limbs.

A thin, skeletal frame made from:

  • Metal struts
  • Tendon-cables
  • Preserved sinew
  • Dull glass eyes
  • A skull-like head of welded plates
  • A glowing amber core in its chest

Static-filled voice:

**"Maintenance… node… compromised.

Preservation… protocol…

ACTIVE."**

It rose to full height — 9 feet tall — multi-jointed arms braced with bone-like struts.

C-5 PRESERVATION CUSTODIAN

It rose to full height — 9 feet tall — multi-jointed arms braced with bone-like struts.

Built to protect the core. Not to recognize intruders. Not to reason. Just to eliminate anything unregistered.

The facility registered:

  • Sol Raven's divine memory signature = THREAT
  • Unregistered organics = THREAT
  • Power restored = Patrol Mode

Its amber core flashed. The machine crouched.

It sprang.

Combat: The Preservation Custodian

Battlefield: C-5 Conduit Manifold Environmental Features:
  • Conduits (half cover)
  • Warm vents (2 fire damage if struck near)
  • Railings (can be broken, creates fall hazards)
  • Machinery (may spark if overloaded)
  • Catwalk above (10-15 ft drop if fallen)
  • The lever (targeting it dims lights, gives Custodian advantage)
The Battle:

The Custodian prioritized Sol Raven due to his divine signature. It used:

  • Serrated arm-blades with 10 ft reach
  • Resonance pulses that pushed targets into machinery
  • Magnetic pulses that yanked metal weapons
  • Wall-climbing to reposition in three dimensions
  • Deflective frame to reduce damage

The party fought together:

  • Jonas held the front line, hammer strikes denting its plating
  • Fursen flanked and disrupted its targeting
  • Sol Raven's magic found purchase on its divine-tech frame
  • Kael provided tactical information from the Codex

The Custodian's Maintenance Protocol activated at low HP — gaining AC and attack bonuses but becoming slower.

The killing blow came from concentrated party assault. The construct shuddered, its amber core sputtering.

**"Preser…va…tion…

pro…to…col… ter…mi—"**

THOOM.

The light died. The Custodian collapsed.

Part Seven — Victory

The Aftermath

The facility stabilized. The vibrations ceased. The lighting steadied.

Three doors disengaged:

  • CHUNK — Subunit 2 (Archive Node)
  • CHUNK — Subunit 3 (Biocell Storage)
  • CHUNK — Subunit 7 (Archive Lower Core)

Emergency consoles lit up. Terminals became readable.

The facility recognized the party. Amber lights brightened when Sol Raven approached.

The Three Paths Now Open

SUBUNIT 2 — Archive Node (Upper)
  • Lab terminals, readable logs, facility history, staff rosters
  • Safest choice
SUBUNIT 3 — Biocell Storage
  • Preserved (dead) divine organoids, failed experiment samples
  • Safe but unsettling
SUBUNIT 7 — Archive Lower Core
  • Divine-tech data, pre-Sovereign records, memory experiments
  • Most important, most dangerous

The session ended with all doors unlocked and the facility waiting to reveal its secrets.

Part Eight — The Biocell Storage

Subunit 3: The Frozen Vault

The party approached the Subunit 3 door. Unlike the Manifold, this one wouldn't budge when pushed.

A control panel sat recessed into the wall beside it — still powered from Jonas's lever pull. Sol Raven examined it and found a simple interface: temperature warnings, containment status, and an access toggle.

He activated it.

CHUNK—HSSSSSS

The door slid open. Cold air rushed outward — not natural cold, but preserved cold. The kind that keeps things from changing.

Inside: Biocell Storage.

The Vats

The chamber was long and narrow, lined with cylindrical containment vats — eighteen in total — each filled with viscous liquid and connected to ceiling-mounted tubes.

The party surveyed the vats:

Status Count Description
Black/Shattered 1 Cracked open, contents long dried, residue black and foul
Amber 2 Murky orange-brown liquid, shapes visible inside
Green 15 Stable, glowing faintly, contents unclear but intact

The temperature regulation had kept this room functional for centuries. Whatever was inside those vats had been preserved since before the Sovereigns existed.

Fursen Investigates the Black Vat

Fursen approached the shattered black vat. The residue inside had dried into a tar-like crust. His Lionen instincts told him something was wrong, but curiosity won.

He leaned in and sniffed.

Constitution Save: Failed.

The smell hit him like a physical blow — not rot, not death, but wrongness. Something that had tried to be alive and failed catastrophically. The scent wormed into his sinuses and stayed there.

Effect: Disadvantage on all d20 rolls for 24 hours. His senses were compromised, his reactions dulled.

Fursen staggered back, eyes watering.

Fursen: "Don't... breathe near that one."

Jonas Throws His Hammer

Jonas studied the amber vats. Shapes floated inside — humanoid, but wrong. Too still. Too patient.

He made a decision.

He threw his hammer.

CRASH.

The amber vat shattered. Liquid spilled across the floor in a thick, syrupy wave. And from within —

A figure emerged.

The Bioweapon Specimen

It unfolded from the broken vat like something being born and waking simultaneously.

Appearance:
  • Skin: Pure white, almost translucent
  • Hair: None
  • Eyes: Black, unblinking
  • Claws: Long, curved, designed for tearing
  • Teeth: Rows upon rows, too many for any natural mouth
  • Build: Lean, muscular, every line designed for killing

It took a moment to adjust — joints cracking, muscles remembering how to move after centuries of stillness.

Then it attacked.

Combat: Bioweapon Specimen (Alpha)

Battlefield: Biocell Storage Environmental Features:
  • Slippery floor (spilled preservation liquid)
  • Remaining vats (cover, but risk of releasing more specimens)
  • Cold temperature (no mechanical effect, but thematic)
  • Narrow space (limited maneuverability)
The Battle:

The specimen moved with terrifying speed and precision. It was designed for one purpose: killing.

But Sol Raven recognized something. The creature was still covered in preservation liquid — and that liquid was flammable.

Sol Raven: "Fire! Use fire!"

Sol's flames found purchase. The liquid ignited across the creature's skin, causing it to shriek — a sound no human throat could make. The fire bought them time, disrupted its movements, turned its greatest advantage into vulnerability.

The party pressed the attack:

  • Jonas's hammer struck true despite the creature's speed
  • Fursen fought through his disadvantage, landing crucial blows
  • Kael provided support and tactical coordination
  • Sol Raven's fire magic proved devastatingly effective

The specimen fell.

Examining the Corpse

The party gathered around the dead bioweapon.

Up close, the design was even more disturbing:

  • No hair anywhere — nothing to grab in combat
  • Claws that could punch through armor — bone-reinforced, self-sharpening
  • Multiple rows of teeth — designed to tear, not chew
  • Muscle density far beyond human — compact, efficient, powerful
  • No visible reproductive organs — this thing was manufactured, not born

Kael (quietly): "It was designed for something specific. But what?"

No one had an answer. But the implications were clear: someone had built living weapons before the Sovereigns even existed.

Part Nine — Deeper Into the Facility

The Back Door

Behind the Biocell Storage, a second door had unlocked when they opened the first. It led into a long corridor — dark, cold, and branching.

Three directions:
  • Left
  • Straight
  • Right

The party chose left.

The Rest Area

The left corridor opened into a small chamber — clearly a staff rest area from the facility's operational days.

Contents:
  • Collapsed cots (ancient, rotted fabric)
  • Medical supply cabinet (partially intact)
  • Expired rations (pre-Sovereign packaging, centuries old)
  • Emergency lighting (flickering weakly)
Loot Found:
  • Medical kits (×2)
  • Bandages (enough for basic first aid)
  • Expired rations (inedible, but historically interesting)

The party took a short rest here. Given their wounds from both the Custodian and the specimen, it wasn't much — but it was something.

Pressing Forward

After the rest, they continued. The corridor led to another crossroads:

Two directions:
  • Straight
  • Right

On the wall beside the right passage, they noticed something: markings. Smeared in a thick liquid that looked disturbingly similar to the preservation fluid from the vats.

Something had been here. Recently.

The party chose right. They attempted to stealth.

Stealth Check: Failed.

The Insectoid Specimen

They crept down the corridor, weapons ready, eyes scanning—

They were looking in the wrong direction.

It was above them.

Clinging to the ceiling like a spider made of nightmares — limbs too long, joints bending backward, body segmented like an insect but sized like a man. It had been waiting.

It dropped onto Jonas.

Combat: Bioweapon Specimen (Beta)

The creature moved nothing like the first specimen. Where the Alpha was a killer, this was a hunter.

Appearance:
  • Insectoid anatomy — segmented limbs, chitinous plating
  • Multiple eyes — clustered, unblinking
  • Mandibles — designed for grasping, not biting
  • Wall-climbing capability — moved in three dimensions
  • Longer, thinner build — built for ambush, not direct combat
The Grapple:

Jonas was grappled and restrained before he could react. The creature wrapped around him, limbs pinning his arms, mandibles pressing against his throat.

He couldn't move. He couldn't breathe properly. He was going to die.

Kael: "JONAS!"

Kael didn't hesitate. He cast Dimension Door, grabbing Jonas and teleporting them both out of the creature's grip.

They materialized twenty feet away. Jonas gasped for air.

Kael: "RUN!"

The party ran.

The specimen did not follow. It watched them go with those clustered eyes, then retreated back to the ceiling. Patient. Waiting.

Part Ten — The Archive

The Straight Path

The party backtracked and took the only remaining direction: straight.

The corridor opened into a larger chamber — an archive. Technological interfaces lined the walls. Terminals. Data storage. The accumulated knowledge of a pre-Sovereign research facility.

Sol Raven Activates the Systems

Sol Raven approached the central terminal. The interface was alien — not magical, but technological in ways that predated modern understanding.

Arcana Check: Success.

He placed his hands on the console. The divine signature in him triggered something — old protocols recognizing old authority. The screens flickered to life.

Terminal: "WELCOME. ACCESS GRANTED: PARTIAL. USER CLASSIFICATION: DIVINE-ADJACENT."

The Specimen Files

Sol Raven searched the database. He found digital files on all specimens:

Designation Purpose Status
Alpha Series Combat / Assassination Multiple units, most in stasis
Beta Series Infiltration / Ambush Multiple units, some escaped containment
Gamma Series Labor / Construction All units terminated (obsolete)
Delta Series [REDACTED] [CLASSIFIED]
Critical Discovery: All specimens shared a neural network — a hive-mind connection. They knew what happened to each other.

The Alpha they killed? The others already knew.

Sol Raven: "They're connected. They know we killed one of them."

The Purge Protocols

Sol Raven dug deeper. He found emergency protocols:

PURGE OPTIONS:
Level Target Effect
Stage 1 Biocell Storage Only Terminates specimens in vats
Stage 2 Conduit Manifold Destroys central systems
Stage 3 Entire Facility Complete purge — nothing survives
Requirement: Two access cards required for Stage 2 or higher.

Jonas had one. They needed another.

Emergency Exits

Sol Raven also found three emergency exit routes:

Route Risk Level Description
Exit 1 High Through specimen territory
Exit 2 Moderate Underneath, through maintenance tunnels
Exit 3 Low Back through entry point, service chute with grate

Finding the Second Keycard

The party searched areas they hadn't explored. In a side chamber similar to the first room where they'd found the dead worker, they discovered another body — another victim of the lockdown.

This one had a second access card.

They returned to the archive terminal.

Initiating Purge Protocol: Stage 3

Sol Raven inserted both keycards.

Terminal: "PURGE PROTOCOL STAGE 3 SELECTED. CONFIRM?"

He confirmed.

Terminal: "PURGE INITIATED. EVACUATION RECOMMENDED. TIME TO COMPLETION: 4 MINUTES."

Alarms began to sound. Red light flooded the facility.

Sol Raven: "GO! NOW!"

Part Eleven — The Escape

Exit 3: The Service Chute

The party ran for Exit 3 — the safest route. Back through the corridors they'd already cleared, toward a service chute that led to the surface.

They found the chute. A metal grate blocked the end.

Jonas grabbed it and pulled.

Strength Check: Natural 1.

The grate didn't budge. Rusted. Fused. Immovable.

Jonas: "It won't—"

Kael: "MOVE! EXIT 2!"

Exit 2: The Maintenance Tunnels

They backtracked. The purge gas was already spreading — a thick, yellowish vapor that smelled of chemical death.

Exit 2 led them through maintenance tunnels beneath the main facility. Tight spaces. Emergency lighting. The sound of machinery dying around them.

They saw the exit door ahead.

One by one, they dove through:

  • Sol Raven — through
  • Jonas — through
  • Kael — through
  • Fursen —

Fursen was last. The gas was on his heels.

He made it through the door — but not before inhaling a small amount of the purge toxin.

The door slammed behind them. The facility died.

Part Twelve — Return to Pallid Crossroads

The Shorter Route

The exit had deposited them closer to civilization than where they'd entered. They took a direct route back to Pallid Crossroads, arriving within the day.

The party was on death's door:

  • Sol Raven: Exhausted, depleted
  • Jonas: Battered, barely standing
  • Kael: Drained from multiple spellcasts
  • Fursen: Poisoned, weakened, and furious about it

Mira's Clinic

They went straight to Mira — the settlement's healer.

Jonas collapsed into a chair, finally allowing himself to rest.

Fursen, still suffering from the toxin and the 24-hour debuff from the black vat, looked at Jonas.

And bit him.

Jonas went down.

Mira stabilized him immediately, then turned to Fursen with a look of sheer disappointment.

Mira: "...Was that necessary?"

Fursen said nothing.

Fursen's Condition

After Jonas was stabilized, Mira examined Fursen. The purge toxin he'd inhaled was extremely deadly — pre-Sovereign chemical warfare designed to kill anything biological.

He'd only gotten a small dose. But even a small dose required treatment.

Mira: "You need to stay here. Three days. Minimum. If you leave before the toxin is fully neutralized, you will die."

Fursen would spend the next three days under Mira's care at her clinic.

Session Conclusion

The C-5 facility was destroyed. The specimens were dead. The knowledge within — most of it — was lost forever.

But the party had survived. Barely.

And they'd learned something important: before the Sovereigns divided the god's corpse, mortals had already been experimenting with divine biology. Building weapons. Creating horrors.

The Sovereigns weren't the first to play god.

They were just the ones who succeeded.

items.title: Session 14: The Wrong Thought
items.content:
Session 14: The Wrong Thought

Part 1 — The Misremembered Returns

Three Days of Recovery

The party spent three days recovering at Pallid Crossroads under Mira Hemm's care:

  • Fursen: Cleared from clinic observation, lungs clean, given herbal packet
  • Jonas: Ribs fully healed
  • Kael: Leg strain recovered
  • Sol: Wounds sealed (undead regeneration)
Party Status at Session Start: Full HP, no conditions, combat ready.

The Forge — Day Two

During the second day of rest, Jonas visited Orin's Forge. The smith had returned from his travels and was working the anvil when Jonas entered.

Orin was a broad-shouldered man with burn scars climbing up his forearms and a beard that had clearly caught fire more than once.

Jonas pulled out the Custodian armplate and set it on the anvil.

Jonas: "Can you make anything from this?"

Orin examined it. Turned it over. Tapped it with a small hammer. Struck it harder. The metal didn't respond at all.

Orin: "What in the Waste IS this?" He struck it again. "Won't bend, won't mark, won't... anything. My forge isn't hot enough to work this metal."

He offered to try anyway—said it might take a while, but he could attempt it.

Jonas refused. He didn't want to leave the armplate behind.

Fursen wandered in shortly after, still recovering from inhaling the AGENT-TERMINUS toxin in the C-5 facility. His lungs were mostly clear now, but he moved carefully. His eyes landed on a rack of simple leather goods.

Fursen: "How much for the cap?"

Orin: "Two silver."

Fursen paid. The leather cap fit awkwardly over his leonin ears, but it was something. Another piece of clothing.

Items Acquired Leather Cap (Fursen) — 2 silver. Simple protection from elements.

The Settlement Goes Wrong

On the third day of their rest, something felt... off. The party peered out the tavern window and there it was—that same figure from before, standing in the empty street. Everything felt frozen in time. The innkeeper was not present. It felt like the entire town had simply "disappeared."

Jonas and Fursen pushed Sol Raven out the tavern door and closed it behind him.

Confrontation with the Misremembered

The Misremembered approached Sol Raven in the empty street, its form wrong in ways that hurt to perceive.

"You are a wrong thought. You need to be erased... for my master. Don't resist, or do—it's always more fun when they resist."

It extended a gnarly finger toward Sol, inching closer with predatory patience.

Jonas's Intervention:

As the Misremembered reached for Sol, Jonas threw open the tavern door and hurled his hammer at the creature's hand. The blow connected, injuring it and initiating combat.

Battle with the Misremembered

  • Medium aberration made of stolen memories and wrong thoughts
  • Could teleport, regenerate, and erase existence with its touch
  • Spoke in stolen voices
  • Servant of Karthayne the Hollow Crown
The Truth Revealed:
  • Sol is a "wrong thought"—his connection to Aedwynn the Maker makes him unrecordable
  • Karthayne's perfect memory cannot contain something connected to a god who died before she existed
  • The Misremembered intended to erase Sol from existence entirely—not kill him, but make it so he never was
Combat Highlights:
  • Jonas's hammer tore pages from its conceptual form
  • Fursen's claws ripped through impossible flesh
  • Kael destabilized its resonance using the Codex
  • Sol burned it with fire carrying Aedwynn's lingering warmth
Defeat: After much effort, the party drove it back. The Misremembered began folding into itself at inhuman speeds—angles collapsing into angles, form compressing along dimensions that shouldn't exist—until it simply vanished.

A single sheet of paper remained where the entity stood:

NOT CORRECTED. NOTED. WILL RETURN.

Aftermath

Everything returned to normal. Pallid Crossroads' residents emerged from buildings confused, with no memory of the Misremembered or why they had been hiding. Only the party remembers what happened.

Mira rushed out of her clinic and asked them what happened. They explained in full detail what they had just dealt with, and she invited them into the clinic for a "check-up."

Part 2 — Mira's Request

After treating them in her clinic, Mira asked the party for help. Before they had arrived at Pallid Crossroads, someone in the town had been asking about her to the locals—how long she'd been here, what she does, that kind of thing.

The Mission:
  • Go to Dusthollow, an extremely small settlement half a day west
  • Dusthollow consists of: a tavern, a well, a stable, and a handful of tiny houses
  • Find out who this man "Vorath" is and what he wants
  • In exchange, Mira would tell them the truth about herself

The party agreed.

Part 3 — Dusthollow Investigation

Journey to Dusthollow

The party rented horses from the stable. Fursen specifically rented the span-runner he had bonded with during their previous stay.

They set off and arrived the same day at late evening.

At the Stables

The party handed their horses to the stablehand for safekeeping. Jonas immediately began intimidating the young man, demanding information on "Vorath."

The stablehand, panicking and almost crying, spurted out everything he knew:

  • Vorath was a regular at the tavern
  • He would go out in the afternoon and return at midnight
  • Thin man, grey hair, bad leg

Jonas continued intimidating him for "fun"—that's just how Jonas is.

Fursen approached the terrified stablehand afterward, handed him a gold coin, and whispered: "Sorry for my companion's behaviour. He can be a bit stupid."

At The Dry Cup

Inside the tavern, they found:

  • A couple eating their food
  • An elderly man enjoying his bread
  • A hooded figure seemingly sleeping in the corner

Fursen asked the tavernkeeper about Vorath and received the same information the stablehand had provided.

Jonas's "Interrogation"

While Fursen gathered information, Jonas approached the couple, sat right between them, and started staring at the man. The man, visibly terrified, asked: "Can I help you?"

Jonas did not respond. Instead, he ordered an ale from the tavernkeeper and kept sitting there, staring, downing his ale. After a while, he started slamming the table and laughing, clearly drunk—all while maintaining that same unblinking stare.

The woman started crying while her boyfriend comforted her, also visibly terrified.

Fursen's Discovery — Vorath's Room

Fursen rented a room (2 silver) and went upstairs. Instead of sleeping in his own room, he used his claws to pick the lock on Vorath's door.

Found on Desk:
  • A kill list with names crossed out
  • Orders from Seraphine Vale to find and capture "the heretic" and bring her to the Tribunal
Found in Box Under Bed:
  • A dagger with a poison injection feature
  • A vial of white liquid (purpose unknown at this time)

Fursen took everything.

Part 4 — Return to Pallid Crossroads

Instead of spending the night, the party immediately left the tavern, retrieved their horses, and rode back to Pallid Crossroads. They met with Mira at her clinic.

Mira's True Identity Revealed

After seeing the evidence, Mira revealed the truth:

  • Real name: Mira Alethain
  • Former Mareathan priest and templar
  • Deemed a heretic after discovering the Arterial Texts—documents containing Mareatha's foul crimes and deeds that the Church had hidden
  • She had been on the run for 30 years
  • They had somehow found her
The White Liquid: Mira identified it as a truth serum—likely intended to make her confess where the Arterial Texts were hidden. The Party's Persuasion: The party convinced Mira that running wouldn't solve anything. It was time to face her pursuers.

She packed the belongings she needed, and they departed immediately back to Dusthollow.

Part 5 — Vorath's Elimination

They arrived within a few hours. In the pre-dawn darkness, they spotted a figure in the distance getting ready to mount a horse and flee toward Veinspire.

The Chase

  • Party barreled toward him on horseback
  • Jonas threw his hammer at Vorath as he climbed onto the horse—missed
  • The hammer struck the horse instead, knocking Vorath to the ground

Confrontation

Vorath got up and realized his fate was sealed. He knew how powerful Mira was.

Mira asked him for information. He refused.

"Fine. I have other ways to extract information."

She raised her fist and bashed him in the head three times, killing him. She wiped the blood from her knuckles and cast Speak with Dead.

Five Questions Asked

  1. Who gave you your orders?
- "Seraphine Vale. High Inquisitor."
  1. Who gave Seraphine her orders?
- "Kaleth Vorn. Tribunal Hand. Veinspire Catacomb. Seraphine's blade in shadow."
  1. What is the purpose behind interrogating Mira about the Arterial Texts?
- "The Texts contain the Vein-Mother's mortal writings. Her doubts. Her failures. Her words before divinity. The Tribunal must destroy them before they spread. Alethain knows where they are hidden. She is the last who remembers."
  1. Is Seraphine Vale still hunting the party?
- "Four heretics. Fire mage. Branded warrior. Leonin escapee. The anomaly. Vale's secondary priority. Standing orders: capture alive if encountered. Primary focus remains the Alethain extraction. You are... unfinished business."
  1. What is the High Inquisitor's current location?
- "The Crimson Sanctum. Cathedral's upper spire. Quarters and chambers of the High Inquisition. She does not descend to the lower districts. The faithful come to her."

They took Vorath's body and buried it behind the stables, far from prying eyes.

Part 6 — Morning at The Dry Cup

The party rented rooms and slept until morning.

Morning Breakfast:
  • Jonas: Well over a dozen eggs
  • Fursen: Normal amount
  • Kael: Normal amount
  • Mira: Normal amount
  • Sol: Nothing (doesn't eat)

Kael's Breakdown

Fursen pointed at Kael and asked Mira directly: "What did you mean when you said we don't understand what our friend is? What is he?"

Mira's Explanation:
  • Kael reeks of the smell of Vor'Kael the Hollow Empress
  • Vor'Kael claimed the Maker's stomach—the organ of digestion
  • She breaks down, processes, and incorporates concepts and ideas
  • Even a god's stomach rejects some things—incompatible, contradictory, poisonous ideas
  • When this happens, she doesn't destroy them—she EXPELS them
  • Kael is a "vomited fragment"—a piece of concept Vor'Kael tried to consume and couldn't stomach
  • This explains his insatiable hunger for knowledge
  • He was INSIDE her once, part of an idea she attempted to digest
  • She spat him out
  • This is why he doesn't exist in Imhuran's temporal records
  • Vor'Kael will spend eternity trying to finish what she started
Kael's Reaction:
  • Had a mental breakdown
  • Questioned his own existence
  • Fled the tavern

Sol's Intervention

Sol followed Kael and found him behind the tavern, sobbing.

Sol comforted him by sharing his own existential crisis:

  • He is a skeleton
  • He doesn't remember his past
  • He doesn't know if his memories are his own or belong to someone who died
  • "It doesn't matter. Because I'm here. Right now."
  • "Whatever I was before—whatever made me—I'm making choices NOW. That's real. That's mine."
  • "Maybe we're both impossible. Maybe we're both things that shouldn't be. But we ARE. And that terrifies them."
  • "A mistake who survived. The most stubborn kind."

The situation stabilized. They returned to the tavern.

Kael's Return:
  • Returned to find Jonas had eaten his eggs
  • The suspect? Jonas. (Obviously.)
  • Managed a small laugh—"Fair enough"

Part 7 — Route Planning

After eating, they discussed routes to Veinspire.

Three Options:
  1. Direct to the Gates — Risky due to patrols
  2. Near the Blooming Rot — Risky since it belongs to the Verdant King and they don't know how he would react
  3. Through the Underways — Underground passage
Decision: The Underways.

Part 8 — The Underways

The party went south, led by Mira, where they found a hidden entryway to the underground. They entered and embarked on the journey.

The Cistern Depths

  • Passed eyeless beasts that avoided their torchlight
  • Rested in not-so-safe places
  • Finally made it through

The Bone Galleries

As they approached the Bone Galleries, they were stopped by three Bone Wardens—desiccated guardians with green flame eyes.

The wardens challenged them: "Why do you seek passage, those who reek of sovereignty?"

Jonas stepped forward to try and convince them. Alas, he is marked by Azerach—the wardens detected the brand immediately. His persuasion failed spectacularly.

Just before they tore Jonas to pieces, Mira stepped in and convinced them that he was not lying, that they truly did not intend to defile the sacred ground, and that the brand had been forced upon him against his will.

The Bone Wardens, convinced, granted them passage.

Mira's Lesson to Jonas

After they were safely past, Mira gave Jonas an earful:

"Really? 'I'm not Azerach's slave?' Can you be any less convincing?"

"Defiance without wisdom gets people killed. Ancient beings see your brand as 'claimed' regardless of your intent."

"You should have said: 'I was marked against my will. I carry the brand but not the loyalty.'"

"Down here, pride is a luxury. Precision keeps you alive."

Short Rest

The party found a defensible spot ahead and settled in for a short rest.

NPCs Updated

NPC Update
Mira Hemm True name: Mira Alethain. Former Mareathan priest/templar. Hunted for 30 years.
Kael Revealed as "vomited fragment" of Vor'Kael

Party Status

Character Condition Notes
Sol Raven Healthy Hunted by Karthayne
Jonas Healthy Nearly killed by Bone Wardens
Fursen Healthy —
Kael Shaken Processing existential revelation
Mira Alethain Healthy Now traveling with party

items.title: Session 15: The Maker's Final Breath
items.content:
Session 15: The Maker's Final Breath

Part 1 — The Arterial Tunnels

After traversing the Bone Galleries, the party finally made it to the Arterial Tunnels. Mira led the way, pointing them in the direction that would take them up to the Lesser Sacral District.

Blood-Drinker Ambush

As they continued onwards through the tunnels, a group of blood-drinkers emerged from the walls. Mira materialized her Oathkeeper and they engaged them, making short work of the creatures with her at their side.

Fursen's Attempt

As they continued walking, Fursen tried to flirt with Mira.

She looked at him with pity and complete uninterest.

The party noticed the ring on her finger afterward. They didn't know what it meant yet.

Part 2 — The Patrol

A little further ahead, they could hear movement and voices. Three men and one woman.

As they continued onwards, they faced the patrol and were asked to drop their weapons. Two soldiers approached them while a third stayed behind, dragging a woman.

Compliance

Everyone complied:

  • Fursen — Doesn't really have a weapon
  • Sol Raven — Uses a focus, not a weapon
  • Kael — Uses a book, not a weapon
  • Mira — Can simply unsummon her greatsword

Which leaves Jonas. Jonas dropped his hammer.

All the while, a Blood Beast was situated above the party as insurance for the Church patrol.

Jonas's Ambush

As the soldier approached Jonas to secure him, Jonas recalled the bound weapon to his hand and smacked him, surprising everyone.

They made short work of the Blood Beast and soldiers with Mira around.

Part 3 — Vela Thorne

After defeating the patrol, they rescued the woman and identified her as Vela Thorne, an archivist librarian working in the Church of the Merciful Vein.

The Truth: Kaleth had used her as bait to lure Mira in. He was a cynical and calculating man who knew that something had happened to Vorath even before it happened. He anticipated everything.

Part 4 — Kaleth's Arrival

After a short while, the party heard marching approaching their location. A big group of people.

The party tried to hide on the edges, but Kaleth was smart and had anticipated this.

Sol Raven tried to fire two Fireballs—both were counterspelled.

And then, the battle began.

Kaleth's Speech

Kaleth gave a cynical speech about how all of Mira's friends met their ends, especially her husband Elias. Every word dripped with cruel satisfaction.

The Sanguine Siphon

Mira, filled with rage, tried to attack. But Kaleth threw a Sanguine Siphon—a device designed against heretics to completely deplete them of the energy borrowed from Mareatha.

Mira collapsed on the ground, motionless.

The Battle

The party had to fend against the members of the Tribunal as well as Kaleth himself.

Jonas tanked a Finger of Death.

The fight was brutal, desperate—

And then something changed.

Part 5 — Undying Conviction

Mira started radiating an orange-ish aura, far different from the red aura that radiates from Mareatha's followers.

She got up.

She started muttering the names of the fallen. And kept repeating her husband's name, over and over and over again.

"Elias... Elias... Elias..."

She lunged at Kaleth.

She deleted him in one attack.

The whole room was stricken with fear and could not move. Some of the Tribunal members tried to escape, but it was impossible with Mira in her current state.

None survived.

Part 6 — Aftermath

Kaleth's Remains

They inspected whatever was left of him—a corpse essentially split in half, the halves scorched by radiant energy.

Found:
  • Letters addressed to him by an entity known as "S"
  • A key (hidden in Kaleth's boot)
  • Kaleth's Journal — personal writings documenting his work
  • Tribunal Seal — Kaleth's identification badge

Kaleth's Journal

The journal was damning. Kaleth had documented everything with cold, clinical precision:

  • The Seven Heretics — Names, locations, methods of death for each of Mira's friends
  • Elias Alethain — "Pushed. Verdant Pass. Made it look like a fall. He begged at the end."
  • His Philosophy — Kaleth didn't believe in the faith. He saw the Church as a tool for power, nothing more.
  • Seraphine Vale — Described as "the ideal instrument" — moldable, loyal, useful
  • References to "S" — His superior, someone he reported to but rarely met
  • The Cardinal — Mentioned in passing, someone above even "S"

Mira read the entry about Elias in silence. Her hands shook. Thirty years of wondering how he died, and it was written here in neat handwriting like a ledger entry.

Mira's Exhaustion

Mira dropped to her knees, completely exhausted (3 levels of exhaustion). Fursen helped her up, and she relied on her blade to continue walking.

Part 7 — The Door

They continued onwards until they found a door that felt... off.

Jonas opened it with the key they had found hidden in Kaleth's boot.

The Chamber of the Final Breath

The room radiated with warm energy, kind of like a hug.

Sol Raven felt it the most but was hesitant to go in.

Jonas entered first.

Below, he found a fragment of Aedwynn—stronger than most, shaped like her—underneath a golden tree.

Part 8 — The Maker's Gifts

Jonas

Jonas approached her and touched her.

He felt a voice in his head asking him if he wanted to "deal with the curse placed upon him."

Jonas refused.

The Maker accepted his choice without judgment.

Fursen

Then Fursen came down and did the same thing.

She asked him: "Do you wish to reclaim your people? To set them free?"

Fursen said yes.

He was flooded with 10,000 names of his Leonin brethren—every ancestor, every story, every act of defiance against Imhuran's attempt to erase them from existence.

Sol Raven

Finally, Sol Raven came down and touched her.

She told him:

"I revived you because your death was unfair. Tell me... will you be my witness? I'm not angry at my children for what they did, and you can do what you have to do to bring my teaching back to this world."

Sol Raven accepted.

He has become her Witness.

Sol Raven — Witness of the Maker As Aedwynn's chosen Witness, Sol gained the following:
  • Immunity to effects that would erase his existence
  • The ability to share memories through touch
  • A divine purpose: to bring the Maker's teachings back to the world

Part 9 — Mira's Plea

As the fragment's power depleted, she began to enter a slumber once more.

Mira rushed to her and touched her, pleading and crying:

"Please, tell me where my husband is... his remains... please."

Mustering the last of the fragment's power, Aedwynn burned an image into Mira's mind—the location of her husband Elias's remains.

A cave in the Verdant Pass, away from any Sovereign's reach.

He has been there for decades.

Mira thanked her as the fragment fell into slumber.

Part 10 — Long Rest

The party decided to long rest in the Chamber of the Final Breath, protected by whatever ancient sanctity remained in this sacred space.

NPCs Deceased

NPC Cause of Death
Kaleth Vorn Annihilated by Mira's Undying Conviction
Tribunal Patrol Killed by party
Tribunal Forces Killed by Mira

Gifts Received

Character Gift Description
Jonas Refused Chose to bear Azerach's curse alone
Fursen The Names 10,000 Leonin ancestors, their stories, their defiance
Sol Raven The Witness Aedwynn's chosen witness to bring her teachings back
Kael None Did not get the chance to touch the Maker's fragment before it fell into slumber

Party Status

Character Condition Notes
Sol Raven Healthy Now Aedwynn's Witness
Jonas Healthy Refused the Maker's gift; tanked Finger of Death
Fursen Healthy Carries 10,000 Leonin names
Kael Healthy Did not interact with the Maker
Mira Alethain 3 Exhaustion Knows where Elias's remains are
Vela Thorne Shaken Rescued from Kaleth

Revelations

Discovery Details
"S" Unknown entity giving Kaleth orders
Elias's Remains Cave in the Verdant Pass, away from Sovereign reach
Sol's Origin Aedwynn revived him because "his death was unfair"
Mira's True Power Undying Conviction is her own, not borrowed from Mareatha

items.title: Session 16: The Diverging Paths
items.content:
Session 16: The Diverging Paths

Part 1 — Awakening

The party woke in the Chamber of the Final Breath, surrounded by the warm golden light of the slumbering Maker's fragment.

Everyone felt refreshed — except Mira.

She moved slowly, still carrying 2 levels of exhaustion from her Undying Conviction. But her eyes held something they hadn't before: purpose. She knew where Elias was. After thirty years, she finally knew.

The Choice

Mira wanted to retrieve Elias's body from the Verdant Pass.

But the party understood that uncovering who "S" was — and stopping whatever "The Confluence" meant — had to take priority. The letters from Kaleth's body pointed to something larger. Something imminent.

Mira (quietly): "Elias waited twenty-two years in that cave. He can wait a little longer."

She said it like she was trying to convince herself.

They pressed on toward Veinspire.

Part 2 — Return to the Lesser Sacral District

The party climbed through a sewer grate and emerged in an alleyway very close to the Church of the Merciful Vein in the Lesser Sacral District.

And there, standing at the church steps, was a figure they hadn't seen in a long while.

Seraphine Vale.

Reconnaissance

Fursen's keen sense of smell picked up details the others couldn't:

  • People inside the Church — guards on standby
  • Another guard stationed behind the building
  • Seraphine herself, standing at the front

They needed a plan.

Part 3 — The Exotic Cat

Sol and Mira would confront Seraphine directly.

But Jonas and Fursen needed to deal with the guard behind the church. Fursen had an idea.

He handed Jonas a rope and tied the other end around his own neck like a leash.

Fursen: "I'll pretend to be your exotic cat. You walk me past the guard."

Jonas: "Absolutely not. That's humiliating."

Fursen: "It'll work."

Jonas: "I'm not doing it."

Fursen leaned over to Sol and whispered something. Sol nodded almost imperceptibly.

Jonas felt the words wash over him — not spoken aloud, but pressed directly into his mind with the gentle insistence of absolute truth. The Maker's voice, channeled through her Witness, suggesting that this was reasonable. That this made sense. That he should comply.

His will buckled. Not broken — bent. The suggestion took root before he could resist it.

Then Fursen removed his loincloth.

The cloth was covered in sweat and musk — Fursen hadn't showered since... well, since before his temporal imprisonment. Centuries of theoretical grime. He handed it to Jonas.

Fursen: "Wear this over your face. To hide your identity."

Jonas's hands moved without his permission. He took the cloth. He wrapped it around his face. He breathed in.

His eyes watered. His stomach lurched. You could feel his rage seeping through — but the compulsion held. He had to trick the guard behind the church. He had to wear the cloth for twenty-four hours.

Those were the conditions.

Mira looked at this development, facepalmed, and said nothing. She was too exhausted to comment.

Sol Raven — Mass Suggestion Sol gained Mass Suggestion from his ascension in Session 6. Once per long rest, he can compel others to act. Condition: Jonas must trick the guard and wear the cloth for 24 hours.

Part 4 — The Infiltration

Mira and Sol — The Confrontation

Mira and Sol walked past the church steps toward Seraphine. They waited for the High Inquisitor to be distracted.

Jonas and Fursen — The Back Entrance

Once Seraphine's attention was on Mira and Sol, Jonas and Fursen made their move.

Fursen dropped to all fours. Jonas held the rope like a leash. They walked around the side of the church, toward the back where the guard was stationed.

The guard spotted them immediately.

Guard (squinting): "What the— Bah, take your exotic cat out of here. Citizens aren't allowed back here."

Jonas pretended to fumble with the leash. It slipped from his fingers.

Fursen crawled toward the guard on all fours. Then he rolled onto his back, paws up, awaiting belly rubs.

(Deception: Natural 20)

The guard stared. His brain tried to process what he was seeing — a massive leonin, clearly intelligent, acting like a housecat.

He was completely bewildered.

And completely distracted.

Jonas lunged.

He wrapped his arms around the guard's neck in a chokehold. The guard struggled, clawing at Jonas's arms, but couldn't break free. After several seconds, he went limp.

Fursen looked at the unconscious body.

Fursen: "We should kill him."

Jonas didn't argue. They stabbed the guard while he slept, then dragged his body into one of the mausoleum coffins nearby and shut the stone lid.

One problem solved.

Part 5 — Seraphine's Faith Shatters

Mira and Sol stood face to face with Seraphine Vale.

The High Inquisitor's hand rested on her weapon. Her guards were inside, ready to be called. She had the advantage.

Seraphine: "Don't step any closer, heretics!"

Mira didn't flinch.

Mira: "I remember your mother, Seraphine. I helped deliver you into this world thirty-two years ago. Your mother was so happy when you were born — she wept with joy. She let me hold you in my arms. You were so small. So precious. She named you after the seraphim because she believed you would grow up to be something holy."

Seraphine's expression flickered. Uncertainty where there should have been conviction.

Mira: "I watched you take your first steps in the lower chapel. I saw your mother's pride when you were accepted into the Inquisition. And I wept — because I knew what they would make you into."

She pulled out Kaleth's journal and tossed it at Seraphine's feet.

Mira: "What you believe is a lie. Read it yourself."

Seraphine caught the journal. She opened it.

She read.

Her eyes moved across the pages — the kill list, the methods, the names of the Seven Heretics and how each one died. She saw entries about herself, how Kaleth had cultivated her faith, shaped her beliefs, used her as a weapon.

Then she reached the line:

"Seraphine Vale — the ideal instrument."

Something shattered.

Mira and Sol could feel it — a psychic crack, the sound of thirty-two years of faith collapsing. Seraphine's understanding of the Church, of her purpose, of everything she had done in Mareatha's name — all of it crumbling.

She cursed Kaleth in ways the party didn't expect. Vile, venomous words that would have made a sailor blush. The mask of the composed Inquisitor fell away, revealing raw fury and betrayal.

When she finished, she looked up at Mira with eyes that had aged a decade in minutes.

Seraphine: "Come back in one hour. I need to... deal with some things."

She handed them a letter.

Seraphine: "A blacksmith named Garrett in the Lesser Sacral District. He has no ties to anyone. He'll give you shelter while I... process this."

Part 6 — Garrett's Forge

The party found The Whetstone and Anvil easily enough — the sound of hammer on metal echoing through the street.

Garrett was a stocky man with arms like tree trunks and a face permanently squinting from years of forge-light. He read Seraphine's letter, grunted, and nodded.

Garrett: "You can stay. One hour, maybe longer if you need it. And you're always welcome back if you need a place to hide."

He meant it. No questions asked.

Jonas and the Heretic's Edge

Jonas asked if Garrett had any items of interest.

Garrett showed him the usual fare — mundane boots, helmets, armor. Some with minor enchantments, others purely cosmetic.

Then he brought out the swords.

One blade called to Jonas. He could feel it humming, reaching for him.

The Heretic's Edge.

Jonas grabbed it. The weight felt perfect. The balance, ideal. He asked to test it.

Garrett pointed to a training dummy near the furnace.

Jonas swung with incredible force.

Nothing happened.

Not a scratch. Not a mark. The dummy was completely unharmed.

Jonas swung again, harder.

Same result. The blade passed through the air, connected with the dummy, and did absolutely nothing.

Jonas: "What—"

Garrett took the sword and swung at the dummy himself. The blade bit deep, leaving a visible gash.

Garrett: "Maybe you didn't put enough strength into it?"

Fursen tried. The sword worked fine.

Sol Raven tried — a skeleton with no sword experience and no muscle mass. The blade effortlessly pierced the dummy.

The party turned to Mira.

She took the sword, closed her eyes, and extended her senses into the weapon.

Mira: "It's partially sentient. And it refuses to serve anyone under a Sovereign's influence." She looked at Jonas's branded hand. "Azerach's mark. The sword recognizes it. In your hands, it will never cut anything."

Jonas handed it back, disappointed.

The Custodian Armplate

Instead, Jonas pulled out the Custodian armplate and asked if Garrett could fashion a shield from it.

Garrett examined the metal with obvious amazement. He tried to bend it. Strike it. Heat it. Nothing worked.

Garrett: "This metal... it refuses to listen. My forge doesn't burn hot enough." He paused. "If you want this worked, you'd need divine fire. The Cathedral forges, maybe. But the Cathedral would be certain death for you."

He offered Jonas gold to examine the metal further and attempt to work on it. Jonas agreed to leave it with him temporarily while the party handled other business.

The Rumors

While Garrett worked, Jonas asked about rumors — items of interest, legendary artifacts.

Garrett shared what he knew. Four rumors, all word of mouth, all unconfirmed.

(See Garrett — Legends Shared)

Part 7 — The Frayed Codex

While Jonas watched Garrett work, the rest of the party went to find The Frayed Codex — Thessaly's bookshop.

The building was unassuming from outside — but inside, it was vast. Shelves stretched toward the ceiling, crammed with tomes of every size and age. The smell of old paper and dust hung thick in the air.

At the back, they found the owner.

Thessaly was ancient — even older than Mira by perhaps thirty years, making her possibly the oldest living person any of them had ever seen. Her skin was like parchment, her eyes milky but somehow still sharp. She moved with the careful deliberation of someone who had learned that rushing was pointless.

She recognized Mira immediately.

Thessaly: "Mira Alethain. It's been a very long time."

They had history — from two thousand years ago, back when Mira was a loyal templar of Mareatha. They exchanged greetings and caught up, two relics of a forgotten age sharing memories that no one else alive could understand.

Then the party asked about Sovereign texts.

Thessaly raised an eyebrow. She looked at the group:

  • A skeleton
  • A Leonin
  • Someone holding an "interesting" book (Kael with the Resonant Codex)
  • Mira Alethain

She didn't question them further.

Thessaly: "A Leonin. I haven't seen one since before the Usurpation."

She disappeared into the stacks and returned with three books.

The Doctrine of Still Air (Azerach)

Sol sat down and opened the first book.

It contained detailed accounts written by someone who had worshipped Azerach — the Whispered King, the god of silence and secrets. The worshipper had gained power over quiet spaces and forbidden knowledge. But gradually, they lost their ability to speak. Then they disappeared entirely, becoming nothing more than a whisper in history.

A cautionary tale. Or a promise, depending on perspective.

The Tome of Vor'Kael

Sol tried to read the second book.

The book started reading him instead.

Words appeared on the pages describing Sol — his composition, his nature, what made him delicious. The Hollow Empress's hunger, given literary form.

Sol closed it immediately and returned it to Thessaly.

The Ledger of Moments (Imhuran)

Fursen opened the third book.

It contained detailed accounts of all Leonin in temporal stasis. Every name. Every prison. Every moment frozen.

And it was updating itself.

As Fursen watched, new entries appeared. Names shifting. Statuses changing. The Regent of Hours' records, somehow captured in physical form.

Fursen ran back to the counter.

Fursen: "Please. I need this book. Please."

Thessaly looked at him — a Leonin, potentially the last of his kind, begging for information about his lost people.

Thessaly: "You can have it. But when you complete your quest and bring back your people... come back and see me. Tell me all about it."

No gold exchanged hands. Just a promise.

Items Acquired The Doctrine of Still Air (Sol Raven) — Azerach lore, read at Thessaly's and returned The Ledger of Moments (Fursen) — Self-updating record of Leonin in temporal stasis

Part 8 — Seraphine's Intelligence

One hour passed.

The party regrouped and returned to the Church of the Merciful Vein.

They knocked on the doors.

Seraphine came out to greet them.

No guards. No weapons. Nothing.

She looked different. Older. The conflict was written in every line of her face — but her cold demeanor and decades of Inquisitorial training allowed her to maintain composure.

Seraphine: "I've dismissed my guards. The ones inside think I sent them on assignment. We have time."

She told them about "S."

Savaros

Seraphine: "His name is Savaros. High Keeper of the Catacomb Reliquary. I've never seen him — no one has, as far as I know. But I heard Kaleth speak to him once."

She paused.

Seraphine: "His voice sounds like paper tearing."

Savaros was Kaleth's superior. The one giving orders. The one behind the thirty-year hunt for the Seven Heretics.

The Cardinal

Seraphine: "The Cardinal isn't a person. It's a position. Someone who speaks for something higher — a Tribunal above the Tribunal. Every major Church decision passes through them."

She hesitated.

Seraphine: "Rumors say... the Cardinal hasn't been human for a very long time."

The Confluence

Seraphine: "The Church is preparing for something called the Confluence. It happens every few years — a gathering of high-profile individuals within the Church and beyond. Cardinals, High Inquisitors, wealthy patrons, political allies."

She paused, her expression troubled.

Seraphine: "But this one feels... off. There's more secrecy than usual. More urgency. Kaleth was afraid of it. He wrote that when it completes, 'nothing will be the same.'"

The Confluence was happening at the new moon — days away, not weeks.

Part 10 — The Arterial Tunnels

The tunnel connected to the Arterial Tunnels — the same living passages they had traveled before. Walls of pulsing flesh. The copper taste of divine blood in the air.

As they approached an intersection, they saw movement.

A blood golem emerged from the congealed flesh wall. It looked left. Looked right. Then sank back into the wall and disappeared.

Thirty seconds later, it happened again.

Mira: "A sentry. Tasked with identifying intruders and disposing of them. It checks on a cycle."

Fursen stepped forward.

Mira: "Wait—"

But Fursen was already walking toward it.

He pulled out Kaleth's Tribunal Seal — the badge they'd taken from the Tribunal Hand's corpse — and held it up as the golem emerged.

The golem examined the seal.

Then it spoke, its voice wet and gurgling:

Golem: "IDENTIFY YOURSELF."

Fursen opened his mouth.

And realized he had forgotten Kaleth's name.

His mind went blank. The name was right there, he'd read it a dozen times, but in that moment — nothing.

Fursen: "I... the seal bearer... from the..."

The golem's form rippled.

Blood surged around them as two more golems emerged from the walls.

Combat began.

Battle — 3 Coagulated Guardians

With Mira in the party, the fight was brutal but quick. Her Oathkeeper cleaved through congealed flesh. Sol's fire burned away ichor. Jonas's hammer shattered semi-solid forms. Fursen's claws tore chunks from bodies that tried to reform.

Three guardians fell.

But these creatures alerted others.

Mira: "Move. Now. They know we're here."

The party ran.

Part 11 — The Catacomb Reliquary

They sprinted through the arterial passage until they reached a sphincter-like door made of flesh. It was open.

They passed through.

It closed behind them with a wet schlorp.

The chamber beyond was different. Stone instead of flesh. Ancient architecture predating the current Church. Cold, dry air instead of humid warmth.

And above them — the sound of pages turning.

Someone was reading.

The voice hummed tunelessly. A sound like paper tearing.

Mira (whispering): "Savaros."

Session End

The party stands in the lower level of the Catacomb Reliquary.

Above them, Savaros waits.

NPCs Updated

NPC Update
Seraphine Vale Faith shattered by Kaleth's journal; provided intelligence and escape route

Items Examined

Item Result
Heretic's Edge Useless to anyone branded by a Sovereign
Custodian Armplate Requires divine fire to work — Garrett cannot forge it

Intelligence Gained

Topic Details
Savaros High Keeper of Catacomb Reliquary. Kaleth's superior. Voice sounds like "paper tearing."
The Cardinal Not a person — a position. Speaks for something higher. May not be human anymore.
The Confluence Gathering of high-profile Church individuals every few years. This one feels "off" — more secrecy, more urgency. Happening at new moon (days away).

Party Status

Character Condition Notes
Sol Raven Healthy Used Mass Suggestion on Jonas
Jonas Furious Compelled to wear Fursen's loincloth for 24 hours
Fursen Healthy Has The Ledger of Moments
Kael Healthy —
Mira Alethain 2 Exhaustion Still recovering
